abstract: Metropolitan Fair for United Stated Sanitary Commission; Officers and Committees
snippet: Metropolitan Fair for United Stated Sanitary Commission; Officers and Committees
lead_paragraph: A Metropolitan Fair is to be held in the Metropolitan City of New-York, commencing 28th of March, 1864, for the relief of the sick and wounded of the National Army. It is designed to be something much larger than a "fair" in the modern acceptation of that term. Every branch of agriculture, trade, industry and art, will be invited to contribute its choicest and costliest products for exhibition and sale. Musical and dramatic artists will be invited to aid the common cause with their talent and genius. All the material resources of the great City of New-York and of the region directly tributary to it, are to be invoked. The farmers of New-York, Pennsylvania, Connecticut, New-Jersey, and the adjacent States, will send in specimens of their finest stock; our factories will contribute locomotives, grand pianos, sewing machines, steam plows and all the mechanical products of Northern intelligence and industry, in aid of the great cause of National Unity.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen yesterday received and referred to a Special Committee a communication from the Commissioners of Health, stating that there has been a great increase of malignant fevers in certain localities of the City, and recommending that an ordinance be passed compeling some more efficient system of ventilation in tenement houses.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen yesterday received and referred to a Special Committee a communication from the Commissioners of Health, stating that there has been a great increase of malignant fevers in certain localities of the City, and recommending that an ordinance be passed compeling some more efficient system of ventilation in tenement houses. The Board concurred in the substitute resolutions of the Council Board requiring the Eighth-avenue Railroad Company to run cars regularly up to Eighty-fourth-street- They also concurred in appointing over two hundred Commissioners of Deeds to fill vacancies caused by the expiration of the terms of as many of those officers. They further concurred to increase the pay of the pavers and laborers employed by the Croton Board to $2 per day. The Board adjourned to 11 o'clock A.M. on Saturday.

abstract: Piracy; Chesapeake Case; Troublesome Questions with Great Britain; Question of Supplies to
snippet: Piracy; Chesapeake Case; Troublesome Questions with Great Britain; Question of Supplies to
lead_paragraph: We see it stated, from Washington, that Lord LYONS is having long interviews with the State Department during these days, probably in reference to the case of the Chesapeake. We can very well believe it, for there are certainly some knotty points of international law in the case. It would require some discussion probably to come to a clear and satisfactory conclusion on the question whether the vessel herself shall be given up to our authorities or to her owners, for that involves, doubtless, the question whether the pirates who captured her were acting under a regular commission from JEFF. DAVIS or not. If they were not; the case was one of pure piracy. But if they were, the question of recognizing the capture as legal, is one on which the British Government and our own would be very likely to take different views. Yet even if we accept the view which the English would be apt to take, and allow the capture to be a lawful one, according to their views of belligerency, what can they do with the vessel? She has never been condemned in any Prize Court. She has been recaptured by our vessels, although in British waters, and by us put into the hands of the British authorities. They would hardly go so far as to put the vessel into the hands of the pirates again, if they were impudent enough to make a claim for her. Probably the best way for England to settle it will be to say, "We will not discuss any of these troublesome questions of lawful capture, &c. All we know about it is that you have put into our hands a vessel, which you say is yours, and which you want us to give back to you; and so, to avoid trouble, we will give her to you. As for the wrongful act, which you have been guilty of in seizing her within our waters, we will, under the circumstances, overlook that. That is a matter which concerns us alone, and JEFF. DAVIS has no just cause of complaint against us for avoiding a quarrel."

abstract: RECRUITING IN THE CITY. -- The enlistment of volunteers in this City, under the new call, is constantly on the increase, and there is every prospect of the quota being filled, if not by the time fixed by the War Department, at least much sooner than the men could be raised by draft. Mr. BLUNT now pays bounties to nearly 100 per day. The number enlisted up to Saturday last was 3, 107, as follows: Month ending Nov. 30, 770; week ending Dec. 5, 609; week ending Dec. 12, 637; week ending Dec. 19, 591; week ending Dec. 26, 500. Total, 3, 107.

abstract: Rebel Senator of Mississippi, Desperate Speech of; the Armies and Finances of the
snippet: Rebel Senator of Mississippi, Desperate Speech of; the Armies and Finances of the
lead_paragraph: The picture of what the South has to become in order to succeed in its rebellious struggle, which was traced a few days ago in the rebel Senate by Mr. BROWN of Mississippi, is worth studying as one of the most remarkable attempts on record to embody despair in legislation. In the first place, a tax of some kind has to be levied, which will reduce the currency by $500,000,000, and which win supply $400,000,000 for the expense of government during the coming year -- nine hundred millions in all -- and it must be raised during the coming six months in order to be of any use. This would, we need hardly say, be a burden which would cause the pillars of any State in the world to tremble to their base, even in time of profound peace, with resources still untouched and confidence still unshaken.

abstract: The Fortieth (Mozart) regiment, Col. EGAN, arrived here yesterday afternoon, on thirty days' furlough. They were received at the wharf by a detachment of the Seventy-first regiment, and escorted to the Park Barracks. They will have a formal reception by the City authorities at the City Hall this afternoon, at 2 o'clock, and make parade under escort of the Seventy-first. The Fortieth have re-enlisted for the war, and are here on thirty days' furlough.

abstract: A MAN SHOT BY A WOMAN.--About 2 o'clock yesterday morning, a party of young men who had been celebrating New-Year's until the "small hours," entered the saloon of Mme. BELL, on the corner of Broadway and Prince-street, where they partook of divers refreshments. Soon one of the number, named THOMAS GORMAN, doing bus
lead_paragraph: A MAN SHOT BY A WOMAN.--About 2 o'clock yesterday morning, a party of young men who had been celebrating New-Year's until the "small hours," entered the saloon of Mme. BELL, on the corner of Broadway and Prince-street, where they partook of divers refreshments. Soon one of the number, named THOMAS GORMAN, doing business in Washington Market, took exception to a picture of Engine Company No. 14, which was hanging upon the wall. To him it seemed so offensive that he promptly demanded of the proprietress that the picture should be removed. The latter refused to comply with this request, and thereupon GORMAN became highly excited, used very violent language toward her, and according to the Police reports, he made an assault on Madame BELL. While things were in this State, the latter drew a small pistol and shot GORMAN in the neck, inflicting a serious though not dangerous wound. The Police interfered, and the wounded man was conveyed to the New-York Hospital. Officer HUGMES, of the Fourteenth Precinct, arrested the woman, and yesterday morning Justice DOWLING committed her to the Toombs to await the result of GORMAN's injuries.

The gunboat Marblehead, while on a reconnoissance up Stono River, was fired upon from a...
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the Arago, HENRY A. GADS- DIN commanding, at this port, yesterday, we have received intelligence giving the details of a skirmish which took place at Legreeville, on the 25th of December. The gunboat Marblehead, while on a reconnoissance up Stono River, was fired upon from a rebel battery situated in the rear of Legreeville. The battery mounted eight pieces, and had been masked until that time. The gunboat replied vigorously, but having been pierced with thirty-two shot was compelled to call upon the assistance of the land forces [???] disperse the rebels and seize the battery. Three men were killed and five wounded on the gunboat.

abstract: On Thursday the United States steamer Algonquin was launched at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, in the presence of a large number of spectators. She was floated off the stocks at 13 o'clock exactly, and was christened by a young lady friend of Admiral PAULDING. The launch was a very successful one, no accident whatever occurring. The Algonquin is 240 feet long, 35 feet wide, and 12 feet deep. She will carry eight broadside guns, and be schooner-rigged. Her engines will be very powerful for a vessel of her size. In other respects she is an exact prototype of the 27 double-enders which were commenced some months since, and all of which are now afloat. Of these, the Mendota, Metacomet, Chenange, Lennepee, Otsego, Shamrock, Mackmaw and Proria were built in the neighborhood of New-York, and are by far the best of any constructed of this class. After the launch the vessel was towed into the whar[???]. The persons who were building her machinery have been informed of the completion of her hull, and requested to hurry up her engines.

abstract: Provably no more expressive compliment could be paid to a public man than the one Wednesday afternoon paid to Hon. GEORGE OPDYKE. About 5 o'clock, when His Honor was immersed in business, all the attaches of his office "skedaddled," and he was left alone in his glory. They repaired to the parlor of Mr. ROOME, Keeper of the City Hall, who courteously surrendered its use, and City Marshal BROWN, by order, returned to the Mayor's office, and summoned his Honor before those who for two years have been most pleasantly associated with him. The secret had been well kept, and the surprise was entire. His Honor was promptly addressed on his appearance, by one of the clerks of his office, in behalf of twelve assembled associates, and an acknowledgment made of the pleasure of the Association, and of the uniform courtesy, Kindness and consideration which had marked his relations with them. Reference was made to his official career as defying criticism or investigation; and the hopes of a long and happy future were expressed, accompanied by the gift of a superbly mounted ebony cane, heavily gold-headed. The head has four tablets, each very admirably engraved, beside the top, on which in most artistic style is the City seal; one tablet bears the figure of Justice, another the symbol of commerce, another a representation of the City Hall, and the last a modest inscription, with the names of the donors. It is a most beautiful, costly and artistic piece of work, by the famed TIFFANY & Co., and it can safely be said that with all their taste and skill they have never excelled it. Mayor OPDYKE received the gift with unconcealed surprise and equally unconcealed gratification, responding to the address in a most cordial, hearty and appreciative speech. As he is about retiring from office, and can confer no further political favors, there is a significance and sincerity in the motive of this present which any public man might recognize with pride and gratification.

lead_paragraph: That the "domestic relations" of the Astor House are of the most amicable character possible none will deny who had the pleasure of being present last evening on the occasion of the grand annual ball of the domestics of that establishment. Joy was unconfined, and the dance went on until 1864 became a recognized date. The evening's entertainment commenced in the large dining-room by a speech from JOHN E. DEVLIN, Esq., which was replied to by Col. TROY, formerly engineer of the Astor House, but now a soldier in the Army of the Potomac.

abstract: MURDER IN BROOKLYN--A WOMAN KILLED BY A SOLDIER.--A woman named Bridget Dailey, wife of Dirkett Dailey, residing at No. 55 Tallman-street, was murdered last evening by a soldier in the rear of a house on Gold-street, midway between York and Prospects streets. It appears that she left home about 5 1/2 o'clock, for the purpose of getting some groceries...
lead_paragraph: MURDER IN BROOKLYN -- A WOMAN KILLED BY A SOLDIER. -- A woman named BRIDGET DAILEY, wife of DIRKETT DAILEY, residing at No. 55 Tallman-street, was murdered last evening by a soldier in the rear of a house on Gold-street, midway between York and Prospects streets. It appears that she left home about 5 1/2 o'clock, for the purpose of getting some groceries for Sunday. She staid so much longer than usual, that her daughter, about ten years of age, went after her to ascertain the cause of her detention. She met her in York-street, near Charles, led by some persons, and bleeding profusely. She managed to walk half a block farther when she fell down exhausted. She was conveyed to her residence, and as she was perfectly conscious, every effort was made to ascertain who committed the deed, but without avail. She refused to say anything to implicate any one, and soon after died. The blood was traced to an outhouse in the rear of the building in Gold-street, where large pools lay upon the floor. The deed had doubtless been perpetrated there. The neighbors saw deceased and a man dressed in the uniform of a U.S. soldier, go into the outhouse. They heard them quarreling, and she cried out. "That's the man that did it," while at the same time the soldier was seen making his escape to the street. That was the last seen of him. She made her way out, and walked along until discovered by her daughter. The soldier was a tall, slim man, but no definite description could be obtained. Coroner NORRIS made a superficial examination of the body of deceased, and found an incised wound through the abdomen over the region of the stomach, about a inch in length, and which extended to some vital part. The deceased died of internal hemorrhage a few minutes after being taken to her house. A postmortem examination will be made to-day, and an inquest held. Meanwhile every effort will be made to arrest the murderer.

abstract: SABBATH SCHOOL CONCERT IN BLOOMFIELD. -- A delightful entertainment was given on New-Year's Eve in Bloomfield, N.J., by the children attached to the different Sabbath Schools in that place and Montclair, under the supervision of Professor W.B. BRADBURY, the well known composer and vocalist. Notwithstanding the violent storm, nearly four hundred children and a large audience were in attendance, and after a number of songs had been sung, Santa Claus descended an improvised chimney and distributed his gifts most generously among the juvenile members of the assemblage, to their great surprise and gratification. Mrs. JAMIESON, Miss STRONG and Miss MARKHAM, and the Bloomfield Glee Club, assisted in the vocal part of the entertainment, and the whole affair passed off in a manner which showed that Mr. BRADBURY, in giving his energies to extracting harmony from wood and iron manufactured into pianos, as he has lately done, has not lost his skill in eliciting sweet sounds from the throats of children. The proceeds of the entertainment are to be divided between the Ladies' Army Relief Associations in Bloomfield and Montclair.

abstract: -- An absurd effect was produced recently at Marseilles, where they were playing "The Hugue-acts." When the soldiers tried to fire on Marcel, Valentine and Raoul, in the last act, it was found that the powder had not been put into their muskets. Naturally the caps alone exploded: but this did not present Valentine and Raoul talling down dead, amidst the roars of the audience. Marcel, an old soldier, stood up like a man till a scene shifter took a shot at him from behind the slips, when he full over the bodies of his prematurely deceased friends, and the curtain tell upon the group.

abstract: CHARLES E. JENKINS, Esq., has resigned the office of Provost-Marshal or the Ninth Congressional District, (composed of the Twelfth, Nineteenth and Twenty-second Wards,) and his resignation has been accepted by the President. First Lieut. GUSTAVUS URBAN will act as Provost-Marshal until Capt. JENKINS' successor shall be appointed. Capt. JENKINS has made a very acceptable and efficient officer, and his resignation is very much regretted by the residents of the district. We trust the Government may find a fit successor of so accomplished and courteous an officer.

abstract: The rumor that the Right Rev. Archbishop HUGHES died at his residence this morning, happily proves to be unfounded. At 1 o'clock this afternoon he was still alive, although his physicians announce that there is no hope of his recovery, and grave fears are entertained that he cannot live through the day. He is still conscious, but is so weak that he is unable to speak, or even raise his hand. The Vicar-General, the Rev. Father STORRS, has been in constant attendance on him during his illness.

abstract: Close of the, probable

lead_paragraph: No one subject probably is pondered so much in America, or is presented to each person's mind in so many different lights, at the present time, as the manner in which this rebellion will be closed. Such vast pecuniary interests, such immense political results, and so many far-reaching moral questions, depend upon the precise mode and time in which this great drama of civil war shall come to its conclusion, that the matter -- though theoretical only, and yet in the distance -- deserves the most careful and impartial consideration.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, about four o'clock, the Jersey City ferry-boat John S. Darcy, when about, midway the river from Cortlandt-street, was run into by the schooner Mary C. Townsend, loaded with hay. The schooner was coming down the river and seemed persistently bent on running into the Darcy, which s owed, backed and maneuvered to avoid her, but in vain. The Darcy was struck forward of the wheel and the gentlemen's cabin was stove in and entirely demolished; a number of persons, there were hundreds on board, were slightly injured, but no one at all seriously. There was great alarm and confusion on the ferry-boat at the time of the collision, which continued until she reached Jersey City.

abstract: For about a week past, United States Marshal MURRAY and his officers have been actively "working up a case" of great importance, and in which a number of citizens are criminally implicated. It was ascertained that a large order for the printing of Confederate bonds and money had been received in this City, and that the work on them had been progressing for some time. Particulars of the operations of the officials have not been made public, but that they were successful in not only ferreting out the whole matter, but in arresting a number of the guilty parties, and in seizing about six million of Confederate bonds and one million of Confederate money, all ready for use save the signatures, can be stated. The work was being done in several places in the City. The type, dyes, presses, were all seized along with the operators, and the latter at once sent to Fort Lafayette. It is one of the most important matters which the Marshal has had charge of, and when the entire story is allowed to be told it will be found one of no little interest. The work was being done at different places, and on Thursday night and Friday morning the final discovery and the arrests were made.
lead_paragraph: For about a week past, United States Marshal MURRAY and his officers have been actively "working up a case" of great importance, and in which a number of citizens are criminally implicated. It was ascertained that a large order for the printing of Confederate bonds and money had been received in this City, and that the work on them had been progressing for some time. Particulars of the operations of the officials have not been made public, but that they were successful in not only ferreting out the whole matter, but in arresting a number of the guilty parties, and in seizing about six million of Confederate bonds and one million of Confederate money, all ready for use save the signatures, can be stated. The work was being done in several places in the City. The type, dyes, presses, were all seized along with the operators, and the latter at once sent to Fort Lafayette. It is one of the most important matters which the Marshal has had charge of, and when the entire story is allowed to be told it will be found one of no little interest. The work was being done at different places, and on Thursday night and Friday morning the final discovery and the arrests were made.

abstract: About one o'clock P.M. on Friday, Officer SWENEY, of the Fourth Precinct, while on post duty in Cherry-street, discovered about half a dozen notorious thieves and rowdies chasing a Chinaman. The officer stopped them to inquire the cause, when some of the gang said the Chinaman had drawn a knife on them, and they were going to pay him off.
lead_paragraph: About one o'clock P.M. on Friday, Officer SWENEY, of the Fourth Precinct, while on post duty in Cherry-street, discovered about half a dozen notorious thieves and rowdies chasing a Chinaman. The officer stopped them to inquire the cause, when some of the gang said the Chinaman had drawn a knife on them, and they were going to pay him off. The officer said he would take the "Celestial" to the Station-house, and that they must go along to make a complaint against him. This all positively refused to do, and defied the officer to take them, at the same time using violent threats, and throwing stones and brickbats at him. They said they would kill both the officer and Chinaman on the spot. SWEENEY then rapped for aid, and Officer SHEA came to his assistance. The two took hold of the man who seemed to be the ringleader of the gang, with the intention of taking him to the Station-house. The latter thereupon drew a heavy navy revolver and fired at Officer SWEENEY. The ball took effect in the upper part of his right thigh extended to the bone, and thence glanced downward about eight inches, coming out just above the knee. The wound is a very dangerous one, and fears are entertained that it will be fatal. After this, the same man fired two more shots in quick succession, one of which took effect in the right shoulder of Officer SHEA, inflicting a bad, but, probably, not a dangerous wound. The ball was extracted soon after by a Police Surgeon at the Fourth Precinct Station-house. The patient was, this morning, doing well. As soon as these shots were fired the alarm was given, and a posse was sent from the Station-house, but before they arrived the offenders had all made their escape. Late in the night, one of them, named MICHAEL MURRAY, was arrested in Brooklyn for another offence, and yesterday morning he was conveyed to New-York. One of the others was arrested by the Fourth Precinct Police. The remainder are still at large.

abstract: Two days' later news from Europe reaches us via Cape Race, by the arrival there yesterday morning, of the steamship City of Baltimore. We learn from the brief abstract of her news furnished by the telegraph, that the American ship Living Age, from Akyab for London, had been captured by the rebel pirate Tuscaloosa, and released on giving bonds. The London Times insinuates that the Archduke MAXIMILIAN will decline the honors of the Mexican crown, and LOUIS NAPOLEON will have to seek another brow to wear them. The disturbances in India are reported to have grown more serious, and the British troops were losing heavily. KOSSUTH is said to be at the head of a revolutionary movement in Hungary. The English Cotton and Breadstuffs markets showed a downward tendency in prices. Provisions were dull, and Consols at 91@91 1/2 for money.

abstract: While the glorious arrival of the year 1864 was ushered in with becoming eclat and joy by many of our citizens, none could be more jubilant on the occasion than were the officers and crews of the Cunard steamers now in port. After the departure of the Australasian and Hecla on the Wednesday previous, three of the company's steamers still remained at the docks, namely, the Persia, Olympus and Corsica. The officers and crews, although not at home in Liverpool with their families, determined that the Old Year should receive a suitable farewell, and that the New year 1864, should be welcomed with joy and gratitude. The more effectually to carry out this desirable purpose, they remained up until 12 o'clock, and when the clock had struck twelve the bells of each of the latter vessels began their merry chimes, which had the effect of gathering a large number of citizens to the ???eck gates. Some of the best "old wine in bottles" was then introduced, and these happy and contented mariners toasted each other with the well-known salutation, "Jim, Joe, Bil???, I wish you a long life and prosperity." This ceremony was decorously and joyously gone through, and at its conclusion the bells ceased to ring, and all retired to rest with the happy consciousness that a great overruling Providence had spared them to see the commencement of another year.

abstract: Blundering Report by; Emperor Napoleon's Invitation to Continental Congress and England's refusal
snippet: Blundering Report by; Emperor Napoleon's Invitation to Continental Congress and England's refusal
lead_paragraph: The brusque refusal of England, and the evident reluctance of the great Continental Powers, to accede to his proposition, have, it is said, determined the French Emperor to change his base. When he announced his scheme to the French Chambers, his tone was confident and menacing. He could not "fail to be listened to, since" he spoke "in the name of France;" and the rejection of his appeal "would cause" him "to suppose the existence of secret projects which shunned the light of day." But now his Majesty sees the propriety of descending from this high ground, and adopting a milder and less mandatory style. Unable to return satisfactory answers to the interrogatories of the Powers, and dreading a general combination against him, he no longer insists on a Congress; and "is ready to come to an understanding with the Governments who shall think it useful to debate pacifically among themselves those questions which, if left to chance circumstances, might conduct to the most fatal complications." Instead, then, of a great ecumenical Congress of European States to abrogate the treaties of 1815, and to reconstruct the political system of Christendom, NAPOLEON would now be content with a series of informal conferences between the Governments favorably disposed for the discussion of unsettled questions, and the promotion of general peace. Well, even the realization of this scheme, different though it is from that originally conceived, would perhaps prove agreeable to the French Emperor, as serving in some measure to render his discomfiture less galling. But, save as balm for his wounded vanity, what would be the use of it? The holding of such conferences would be a waste of time and dialectics. It would he an absurdity to expect that these cabinet coteries would be equal to the solution of problems and the arrangement of difficulties with which even a general congress could not successfully deal. The Ministers of the several Powers might meet and interchange views -- they might make more apparent how antagonistic and irreconcileable were their opinions -- they might reveal to the world how inordinate were the selfishness and ambition which lay hid beneath their assumed garb of disinterestedness -- they might irritate each other by criminations and recriminations, and sow the seeds of future strife and trouble, but for the achievement of good they would be impotent.

abstract: Confidence, Want of, London Times on
snippet: Confidence, Want of, London Times on
lead_paragraph: The Richmond correspondent of the London Times, though thoroughly in sympathy with the rebel cause, bears open witness to the lack of faith among the Southern people in their ultimate success. His language is that all their past successes "have altogether failed to inspire the masses of the South with a tithe of that confidence in themselves which neither defeat, nor disaster, nor hope deferred, nor delusions dispelled, have ever shaken out of the Northerners."

abstract: The United States vs. the Steamer Wilson. The United States vs. the Schooner G.H. Smoot, -- In these cases, libels were filed to forfeit the vessels as prizes. Process was issued and returned, served by publication, the vessels having been taken for the use of the Government. No one appeared, and the default of all persons was issued. No proof whatever was offered to the Court, and a year and a day having expired since the defaults, and no one having appeared to defend, the Court now issued final decrees of condemnation against the vessels.

abstract: La France on Cost of European Armaments
snippet: La France on Cost of European Armaments
lead_paragraph: La France insists that the Congress is necessary were it only to check the immense expenditure of money for armaments each year in Europe. It founds his arguments on calculations published by M. LEGOTT, chel-de-division at the Industry of Agriculture, Commerce and Public Works and, consequently, in a position to arrive at reliable information. Our cotemporary says: "Austria keeps up an army of 467,000 men, which costs her 336,000,000f.: France an army of 573,000, which costs 688,000,000f.[???] Prussia an army of 214,000 men which costs her 150,:000,000f.; England an army of 300,000 men, which costs her 677,000,000f.; and Russia an army of 100,000 of men, which costs 529,000,000f. That is, out of the total budget of each of those States, an expenditure of 37 per cent. in Austria, or more than a third; 33 per cent. in France, 30 la Prussia, 39 in England, and 42 in Russia. Let us also mention Italy, where 329,000,000f. are expended [???] keeping up a force of 314,000 men; Turkey, weighed down by an army of 424,000; Denmark and Sweden, the first with 50,000, and the second with 67,000 men, by which their budgets are increased to 37 and 40 per cent. respectively. The other secondary States follow in an analogous proportion. Switzerland is the only European State that neither increases her army nor her budget. M. L[???], adding together the effective of all the European armies according to estimates which he considered rather below than superior to the reality, arrives at the fearful number of 3,815,847 men, and as on[???] of 3,500,000.000f.

abstract: The new year opened quietly in general business. Breadstuffs, Provisions, Groceries and Whisky were moderately dealt in, and were held with much firmness. Cotton was quiet. Tallow was in limited request. A moderate inquiry prevailed for Hay, Hops, Hides, Wool, Petroleum and Tobacco. Freights were dull.

abstract: The Mayor elect, C. GODFREY GUNTHER, received his friends on New-Year's Day at the City Hall, between the hours of 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. Mr. GUNTHER arrived at the City Hall about 11, accompanied by Messrs. PHILIP W. ENGS, A.J. DELATOUR and JOHN S. MILLS. He and his friends were immediately ushered to the Governor's Room by Mr. GEO W. ROOME, Keeper of the City Hall, followed by a considerable crowd of people, who had gathered to see the new Chief Executive officer of the City. Beyond the friends who accompanied him, no one was admitted with Mr. GUNTHER to the elegant rooms which the Common Council had kindly appropriated for the reception, till exactly 11 o'clock. Then, on opening the doors, there was a rush for a few minutes. Each visitor was introduced to the Mayor elect by Mr. DELATOUR.
lead_paragraph: The Mayor elect, C. GODFREY GUNTHER, received his friends on New-Year's Day at the City Hall, between the hours of 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. abstract: The steamship Arago, from Charleston Bar on Wednesday last, arrived yesterday. She brings information of a brilliant little affair between the rebels and our forces near the village of Legreeville. The enemy opened fire with eight pieces upon the gunboat Marblehead, and after a brisk fight, in which our infantry took part, was re-...
lead_paragraph: The steamship Arago, from Charleston Bar on Wednesday last, arrived yesterday. She brings information of a brilliant little affair between the rebels and our forces near the village of Legreeville. The enemy opened fire with eight pieces upon the gunboat Marblehead, and after a brisk fight, in which our infantry took part, was repulsed with a loss of four field-pieces, which they abandoned. The night of the Arago's departure an expedition was to leave Morris Island with the object of destroying the rebel [???]salt-works at Secessionville. Of news respecting siege operations there is absolutely nothing to report. Firing between the opposing batteries is continued night and day with little intermission, but with no other result than to pile up mounds of sand and riddle buildings in the business part of Charleston. A few nights since a signal was made from Fort Sumter, notifying the batteries that GILLMORE's working parties were engaged, when a furious fire from all the rebel works put a stop, for the time, to operations.

abstract: Annual Convention
snippet: Annual Convention
lead_paragraph: This College fraternity concluded, on Wednesday evening, in this City, its annual convention. The convention assembled on Monday, at the Lodge of the Free Academy, in Broadway, with delegates from nearly all the chapters in the Northern States. About one hundred were in attendance. Much important business was transacted during the sittings of the convention, and propositions entertained of deep interest to the members of the Society.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamship Evening Star, from New-Orleans, we have advices to the 27th. There was nothing of special importance transpiring in the Department of the Gulf. Our forces in Texas, were making very encouraging progress, and meeting with very little resistance. Gen.
lead_paragraph: By the arrival of the steamship Evening Star, from New-Orleans, we have advices to the 27th. There was nothing of special importance transpiring in the Department of the Gulf. Our forces in Texas, were making very encouraging progress, and meeting with very little resistance. Gen. MAGRUDER, commanding the rebel forces, had issued a proclamation, calling out everybody for the defence of the State, avowing that the defence of Western Texas "would not be given up, as reported;" that San Antonio and Austin must be fortified, and that the invaders "should be driven back to their ships." The Free State Convention in New-Orleans had concluded its labors and appointed a full delegation to the National Convention at Louisville. The full delegations from the colored societies were admitted. There was no news in the city. General gayety prevailed through the holidays, and social reunions were numerous and largely attended.

abstract: Two days' later news from Europe reaches us via Cape Race, by the arrival there Saturday morning of the steamship City of Baltimore. We learn from the brief abstract of her news furnished by the telegraph, that the American ship Living Age, from Akyab for London, had been captured by the rebel pirate Tuscaloosa, and released on giving bonds for $160,000.
lead_paragraph: Two days' later news from Europe reaches us via Cape Race, by the arrival there Saturday morning of the steamship City of Baltimore. We learn from the brief abstract of her news furnished by the telegraph, that the American ship Living Age, from Akyab for London, had been captured by the rebel pirate Tuscaloosa, and released on giving bonds for $160,000. The Paris correspondent of the London Times insinuates that the Archduke MAXIMILIAN will decline the honors of the Mexican crown, and LOUIS NAPOLEON will have to seek another brow to wear them. The London Globe discredits the statement that Lord LYONS had predicted the speedy closing of the war in the United States. There was no new features in the Schlesing-Holstein question. The Russian military authorities continued to send Polish subjects to Siberia. The disturbances in India are reported to have grown more serious, and the British troops were losing heavily. KOSSUTH is said to be at the head of a revolutionary movement in Hungary, which was causing much alarm. The English Cotton and Breadstuffs markets showed a downward tendency in prices. Provisions were dull, and Consols at 91@ 91 1/2 for money.
headline: {'main': 'FROM EUROPE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FROM EUROPE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: One of the most interesting events of New Year's Day was the reception of our veteran soldiers and their famlies, at Hope Chapel, by the Pastor of the Christian Alliance, Rev. C.C. Goss. Between eight and nine hundred honored him with calls. The chapel was decorated with banners and flags, some of which had been badly tattered by the balls of the enemy. The sight was most gratifying to the humanitarian. The old and young, rich and poor, met on a common level. Many of the soldiers from the Invalid corps were there, most of them, as Mr. Goss said, with "the nation's mark upon them." Many met for the first time since they fought together on the battle-field. As they recounted the scenes through which they had passed, they exhibited an enthusiasm to engage again in defence of the honored flag. The wives and children all partook of the same feeling. Many widows and their children were there whose husbands had fallen. The thanks of many of them were often showered upon the pastor for calling them from their cheerless abodes to spend the day so delightfully. A well-  dressed gentleman announced himself as a rebel; something was said about not allowing him to partake of the refreshments ; said Mr. Goss, "yes, feed him, he doubtless needs it; we have food enough at the North to Need every rebel in the land, besides the Bible says, 'if ???hy enemy hunger, feed him.'" One gentleman asked Mr. GOSS to show him the creed of his church, so that he could read it. "My creed," said he, "all the creed we have is to be good and do good." The table was richly loaded with all kinds of refreshments, much of which had been sent in By kind friends. In the centre was a huge pound ??? with a tall Zouave upon it, ??? in one hand the Stars And Stripes and with the other holding a shield of defence. Music consisting of songs, marches and patriotic airs, was interspersed and added to the other enjoyments. Much credit is due to the ladies who cooperated with Mr. GOSS in such a praise worthy efforts. There is great want among the families of our ???unteers at present, and we know, of no more efficient agency than the Alliance, to seek out and make provision for them.

abstract: Bonds; Great Seizure of in Spruce-street, New-York
snippet: Bonds; Great Seizure of in Spruce-street, New-York
lead_paragraph: One of the most important Government cases ever worked up in this City, which was given in brief detail in yesterday's TIMES, was completed at a late hour on Saturday night, and has resulted in the seizure of about $6,000,000 in Confederate bonds, $1,000,000 in Confederate Treasury notes, and a large quantity of dies, printing presses, lathes, and other machinery for doing fine bank note engraving. One of the most important Government cases ever worked up in this City, which was given in brief detail in yesterday's TIMES, was completed at a late hour on Saturday night, and has resulted in the seizure of about $6,000,000 in Confederate bonds, $1,000,000 in Confederate Treasury notes, and a large quantity of dies, printing presses, lathes, and other machinery for doing fine bank note engraving. The history of the case from beginning to end is full of incident, and the measures taken by Marshal MURRAY to ferret the matter out and bring to justice the parties implicated, are highly creditable to the skill of that officer and the efficiency of his aids. The services of Chief YOUNG, of the Metropolitan Detective force, and of Detective SMITH, now of the Marshal's office, were also invaluable in securing the persons engaged in the transaction, and the documentary and mechanical evidences of their guilt.

abstract: NON-ARRIVAL OF THE FORTIETH NEW-YORK  This gallant regiment, which unanimously reenlisted for the war, is now en route from the Army of the Potomac to this City. Since Saturday afternoon the arrival of the regiment, via Philadelphia, has been hourly expected. The pleasing duty of receiving the veterans was assigned to the Seventy-first NewYork, Col. TRAFFORD.
lead_paragraph: NON-ARRIVAL OF THE FORTIETH NEW-YORK. -- This gallant regiment, which unanimously reenlisted for the war, is now en route from the Army of the Potomac to this City. Since Saturday afternoon the arrival of the regiment, via Philadelphia, has been hourly expected. The pleasing duty of receiving the veterans was assigned to the Seventy-first NewYork, Col. TRAFFORD. On Saturday last, so confident ??? officers of the Seventy-first of the arrival of the Fortieth, that a general order was issued by Col. TRAFFORD, commanding a parade, with a view to the reception of the heroes. Accordingly, yesterday afternoon, about 2 o'clock, the Seventy-first turned out at their armory, corner of Centre and Broome streets, and accompanied by a fine band of music, proceeded to the Battery, where they remained until 5 o'clock. At that hour the Colonel received a dispatch from Washington, stating that the Fortieth would not, probably, arrive in New-York before Tuesday next. This was a serious disappointment to all, more especially the hundreds of relatives and friends of the Old Mozart, who had congregated to receive them. The veterans will come some???time this week, when all who desire to greet the heroes of twenty actions can meet them.

abstract: EFFECTS OF THE COLD WEATHER.  On Friday night the Susquehanna froze up so tightly that the railroad ferry-boat, with three hundred passengers on board, was locked up in the middle of the river, immovably tight. From that day to this not a mail has arrived in Washington; not a traveller has come to one of the hotels.

abstract: The Most Reverend Archbishop JOHN HUGHES, after a lingering illness of nearly one year, died at his residence in Madison-avenue, Corner of Thirty-  sixth-street, at thirty-one minutes past 7 o'clock last evening. His last moments were very quiet, being scarcely able to articulate, although retaining his senses until his death. He was surrounded by his immediate family connections and a number of the Catholic clergy. He was born in the fore part of the year 1798, in the North of Ireland. He was nearly 66 years of age. His remains will be interred on Thursday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The Most Reverend Archbishop JOHN HUGHES, after a lingering illness of nearly one year, died at his residence in Madison-avenue, Corner of Thirty- sixth-street, at thirty-one minutes past 7 o'clock last evening. His last moments were very quiet, being scarcely able to articulate, although retaining his senses until his death. He was surrounded by his immediate family connections and a number of the Catholic clergy. He was born in the fore part of the year 1798, in the North of Ireland. He was nearly 66 years of age. His remains will be interred on Thursday afternoon.

abstract: Mr. GABRIEL HARRISON, of the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, offers a novel attraction to-night, and one to which we can refer with pleasure, inasmuch as it is fully as interesting to New-Yorkers as to Brooklynites. This very energetic manager has organized an English opera company, and to-night introduces the same in BALFE'S popular opera of the "Bohemian Girl."
lead_paragraph: Mr. GABRIEL HARRISON, of the Park Theatre, Brooklyn, offers a novel attraction to-night, and one to which we can refer with pleasure, inasmuch as it is fully as interesting to New-Yorkers as to Brooklynites. This very energetic manager has organized an English opera company, and to-night introduces the same in BALFE'S popular opera of the "Bohemian Girl." The leading members of the troupe are already favorably known to the public in the concert, and the greatest interest prevails concerning their success on the stage. Mr. WM. CASTLE is the tenor, Mr. S.C. CAMPBELL the baritone, and Mme. BORCHARD the prima donna. The gentlemen possess admirable voices, better, we think, than any that have been heard in English opera. They are young, ambitious and good-looking -- qualities, even the last, which is conducive to success. Of Mme. BORCHARD it is only necessary to say that she was for several seasons the principal singer of the Paris Opera Comique, and subsequently of the New-Orleans French opera. She is of English parentage, and speaks the language with perfect fluency. As an artiste, she is not inferior to LOUISA PYNE. Here, then, are three artists of acknowledged rank. The smaller parts have necessarily to be intrusted to newer hands, but the success of the experiment will not depend on the smaller parts. An orchestra of sufficient numbers, and of the highest individual excellence, has been secured by Mr. THEODORE THOMAS, who will conduct. There will be no failure there. The chorus has been in training for several weeks, and much is expected of it. A glance at the personnel of the Company is sufficient to excite the liveliest interest in the performance. We hope to assist to-night at a great success.

abstract: THE FIRST LONG ISLAND REGIMENT. -- The term of service of this veteran regiment will expire in a few months. Some days since all the men, numbering about two hundred and fifty, accepted a proposition to reenlist for three years, whereupon they were granted a furlough of thirty days. They were expected to arrive yesterday, but it appears were disappointed in obtaining transportation from Washington. They will be here this morning, and will be welcomed by the Mayor. The City Hall bell will be struck twelve times in rapid succession as soon as they land. The regiment was originally commanded by Col. ADAMS. It is now commanded by Col. CROSS. They have participated in eighteen battles, and a number of skirmishes.

abstract: New-Orleans Friends of Freedom and Colored Delegates
snippet: New-Orleans Friends of Freedom and Colored Delegates
lead_paragraph: -- We find by the report of the proceedings of the "Convention of the Friends of Freedom," held in New-Orleans last month, that there was no little trouble caused by the admission of negroes to seats as delegates. A resolution was introduced upon the subject, but the Chair decided it to be out of order. Subsequently one of the delegations made the admission of colored men the ground of withdrawal. It is a great misfortune that at this moment there should be such causes of dissension introduced among the loyal men of the reclaimed Southern States. If the process of political reconstruction has to be delayed in all the rebel States that are successively brought within the military lines of the Union until such time as the social status of the various races is settled, we fear that the thing will not go on as rapidly as might be desired. It is true that if the settlement of this question were a necessity of reunion, no one could complain that it was brought forward and forced to a settlement. But such is not the case; and the whole Union might be reconstructed tomorrow with this question left in abeyance for such solution as might come from discussion, time and circumstance.

abstract: Tactics of, and Democratic Selection
snippet: Tactics of, and Democratic Selection
lead_paragraph: If experience were of any value in electioneering, which, as is well known, it is not, we should never witness again the nomination, either express, or implied, of a General for the Presidency in the first year of a great war. There could not have been a more striking illustration of the danger of such a course than the selection of Gen. MCCLELLAN by the Democratic party for their candidate almost at the very moment when it first became evident that the struggle with the South was destined to be something very much longer and more formidable than a ninety days' campaign. The more uncertain the is sue began to appear in the eyes of the rest of the world, the more certain a class of politicians seemed to become that it was nearly over, and that Gen. MCCLELLAN'S campaign in Virginia had given it the finishing stroke. What was most curious about it all was, too, that those who fell earliest and with most ostentation into this delusion were the very men who professed to be most satisfied of Southern determination and obstinacy. It will probably never be satisfactorily explained how it was that Gen. MCCLELLAN became a great military hero for having failed in a series of important military operations against a people on whom we were told no military operations could ever make any impression. There can be no doubt, however, that this mysterious occurrence would never have taken place if it were not that the Democratic party had not been just then in serious want of a leader. Under him its scattered and demoralized squadrons might rally, if the chief of it had had a little more experience of the uncertainty of war.

abstract: Hughes, Archbishop; Sketch of his Life, >amp;c.
snippet: Hughes, Archbishop; Sketch of his Life, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: His Grace Archbishop HUGHES expired at his residence in Madison-avenue, last evening, at 7 1/2 o'clock, after a lingering illness, in which he suffered much, but endured with fortitude. He has been failing in body for more than a year past. During the past Summer he has been continually under the care of his physicians, Drs. CLARKS and WOOD. On the ???th of December he was first confined to the bed of sickness from which he was never to arise. His decease, although apprehended, was not considered imminent until last Thursday, when he commenced ??? rapidly, and, in???, came so near his end that rumors of his death were circulated and generally believed. He received the last Sacraments of the Church, and shortly after became speechless, but still retained his consciousness.

abstract: Seymour, Gov., and New-York Police Commissioners
snippet: Seymour, Gov., and New-York Police Commissioners
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR has shown more than Falstaff's "alacrity at sinking." We did not suppose it possible for him, after the July riots, to add anything which should lower the public estimate of his personal independence or his official courage. We confess our mistake We had underrated his capacity of disappointing and mortifying both his friends and his enemies. There is little left for the former now but to deplore the feeble vascillation which even moves the latter to contemptuous pity.

abstract: The Navy Department has received official advices of the attack upon the gunboat Marblehead in Stono Riyer, S.C. The engagement between the vessels and rebel battery was quite severe. The Marblehead, Pawnse and C.P. Williams were engaged. The rebels were finally driven from their battery, leaving two guns, which were captured by an expedition from the vessels. The Marblehead was considerably injured, being struck five times. Our loss was 3 killed and 4 wounded.

abstract: The Mayor's office was crowded before noon yesterday with people anxious to observe the departure of Mayor OPDYKE and the arrival of Mayor GUNTHER. The last-mentioned of these two events occurred at about 11 1/[???] o'clock, and so quietly that but little attraction to the fact was occasioned. Mayor OPDYKES departure was of a very different character. His outgoing was headed by the music of a brass band, and he was escorted from the City Hall by a very large deputation of friends and admirers. This manner of vacating his office was not in accordance with the habitually quiet bearing of Mayor OPDYKE, but was simply because his friends so willed it, and he could not help it.

abstract: Our Government will not permit Gen. BUTLER to be outlawed by JUDAH P. BENJAMIN. The exchange of prisoners, committed solely to him, will be continued in his hands. Secretary STANTON determined to-day to enlarge his powers and confirm his agency, by putting all the rebel prisoners in the United States under his care. There will be thirty thousand of them at Point Lookout within three weeks.

abstract: It is alleged that WILLIAM A. SMALLEY, who is implicated with the blockade-runners, as published yesterday, signed the bonds without, knowing the parties for whom he signed. It is also stated that he has acknowledged that he did so as a mere "matter of business," and that the mere matter amounted to the sum of $800. Further it is reported that he has expressed a willingness to pay the bonds if the matter can be thus settled, but this the authorities will scarce dare assent to. He is under arrest by order of Gen. DIX, executed by Marshal MURRAY, but is confined to his house by illness. It is very reasonably imagined that if his case be followed up, developments will ensue which will startle the community. That it shall be followed up the public demand. It he is innocent of what suspicion attaches to him, he should not only be anxious for but court inquiry.

abstract: Farewell Collation to and his Address
snippet: Farewell Collation to and his Address
lead_paragraph: Ex-Mayor OPDYKE was taken in charge at the Mayor's Office a short time after l2 o'clock yesterday, by the Committee of Escort, appointed for the ovation, which has been in contemplation. The Committee consisted of R.F. Andrews, R.L. Darragh, Abraham Brown, Epes E. Ellery, Wm.H. McKinney, Frank E. Howe, Richard Busteed, Wm. H. Gilson, H.J. Williamson, and Wm.J. Orton. The Committee and their guest moved in procession to the Astor House, escorted by the Seventh regiment band. They were there received by Messrs. P. JORDAN, O.W. LAIMBEER, DAVID R. JAQUES, ALEXANDER WILDER, CHARLES SPENCER, E. DELAFIELD SMITH, ISAAC O. HUNT, D.T.T. MARSHALL, ORISON BLUNT, the Committee of Reception.

abstract: A BROADWAY STORE ROBBED THE BURGLAR ARRESTED. Last Wednesday night the optical instrument establishment of Mr. BENJAMIN HORN, No. 212 Broadway, was entered by forcing open a door of the show-room, and property to the amount of over $600  consisting mainly of telescopes, opera and ...
lead_paragraph: A BROADWAY STORE ROBBED -- THE BURGLAR ARRESTED. -- Last Wednesday night the optical instrument establishment of Mr. BENJAMIN HORN, No. 212 Broadway, was entered by forcing open a door of the show-room, and property to the amount of over $600 -- consisting mainly of telescopes, opera and field-glasses -- was stolen therefrom. Officer GOLDEN, of the Sixth Precinct, afterward learned that various glasses, answering the description of those stolen, had been pledged at pawn shops on the east side of the City. He obtained a description of the person who thus disposed of them, and on Sunday afternoon he arrested, in the Bowery, a man who is known as THOMAS BUENS alias COMBS. The latter made great resistance when notified that he was a prisoner, and in a few moments more than twenty thieves surrounded the two, with the obvious intention of effecting a rescue of their companion. The sight of a revolver deterred them, however, and after much difficulty he was taken to the Tombs, where Justice DOWLING committed him. The accused is a well-known sneak-thief and pickpocket. He has already served two years in the penitentiary for picking pockets in stages and cars. When before the magistrate, yesterday, he made a partial confession of the burglary.

abstract: And the N. Y. Police Commissioners
snippet: And the N. Y. Police Commissioners
lead_paragraph: Small men cannot do great things, but they can do extraordinary ones. In fact, it is your smaller class of men -- those who cannot see far, who cannot think broadly and deeply, who are easily carried away by prejudices and resentments -- that are most likely to take to strange ways. Especially is this the case with such men when in high office at a momentous period. Their acts then can hardly help being extraordinary; for the very fact that these acts are in character with themselves makes them out of character with the situation.

She is now in the most excellent condition, and fit for any duty for which she may be assigned. Commodore DRAYTON, late Inspector of Ordnance at this ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, Rear-Admiral FARRAGUT sailed from the Navy-yard in the flagship Hartford, to assume command of the East Gulf Squadron. The Hartford, as stated some time since, has recently been renovated and completely overhauled in every way. She is now in the most excellent condition, and fit for any duty for which she may be assigned. Commodore DRAYTON, late Inspector of Ordnance at this port, and commander of the Passaic during DUPONT's attack on Charleston, sailed also in the Hartford, to assume position as Fleet-Captain. The following is a list of the officers of the Admiral's Staff: Rear-Admiral, DAVID GLASGOW FARRAGUT; Fleet-Captain, Percival Drayton: Fleet-Lieut., John C. Watson; Admiral's Secretary, Ed. C. Gabandon. The following is a list of the officers of the ship: Commodore James S. Palmer; Lieut.-Com., L.W. Kimberly; Lieut., W.B. Tyson; Surgeon, J.J. Gibson; Assistant-Surgeon. James Hugg; Paymaster, W.T. Meredith; Acting-Master, F.G. Pryor; Chaplain, F.W. Taylor. Marine Officers, Captain, Charles Heyward; Ensigns, H.T. Grafton, C.D. Jones, and Larue P. Adams; Acting Ensigns, W.H. Whiting and D.G.B. Glidden; Acting Master's Mates. W.H. Childs, G.R. Avery, W.H. Hathorne and J.J. Tinelli; Engineers, Chief, Thomas Williamson; First Assistant, E.B. Latch; Second Assistant, John Wilson; Acting Third Assistants, C.M. Burchard and Alfred Hoyt; Boatswain, Robert Dixon; Gunner, J.D. Staple; Carpenter, O.F. Stinson.

abstract: Supervisors, Mistaken Action on Bounties to Veterans
snippet: Supervisors, Mistaken Action on Bounties to Veterans
lead_paragraph: - We have been surprised to learn of the action of the Board of Supervisors in establishing a rule to pay the County bounty of $300 to those reenlisting veterans only whose present terms of service expire previous to the fourth day of July next. We cannot but consider this a serious error, and that the Board has established this rule without weighing well all the facts before them. A few plain and forcible facts, existing to-day to our serious detriment, under this rule, will show how the regulation will defeat the very much desired object that the Board, as well as the whole loyal public, are endeavoring to accomplish. All the low numbered New-York regiments up to and including the 38th, were two-years' troops, which comprised about all the organizations sent out of the State prior to July 4, 1861. Of three years' troops there were not to exceed ten regiments, who were organized and mustered early enough in 1861 to bring the expiration of their terms prior to the same date this year, while over fifty regiments go out of service after that date.

abstract: Mr. JACOB B. HERRICK, founder, and senior member of the firm of Messrs. JACOB B. HERRICK & SON, died at his residence, Hunter's Point, Westchester County, N.Y., on Saturday, Jan. 2, after a very brief illness, in the 64th year of his age. Mr. HERRICK had been in business in this City for nearly half a century. He was one of the oldest and most eminent of the produce merchants of New-York. As receivers of Western produce, particularly of breadstuffs, his house ranked with the first in that branch of trade, keeping pace with the growth of the great interest with which the firm was most intimately connected. Mr. HERRICK was widely known as an intelligent, industrious, affable and upright merchant. His memory is without a stain. The flag on the Produce Exchange was at half-mast, yesterday, as a token of respect. The Directory of the Produce Exchange Association, it is understood, at a special meeting convened for the purpose, adopted a series of resolutions of appreciation and sympathy.

abstract: The funeral of Archbishop HUGHES will take place on Thursday morning, at 10 o'clock, from St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Mott-street. His remains will be exposes at the cathedral to-day and to-morrow, from 9 o'clock in the morning until 9 at night, so that all who wish may behold them. Great preparations are making to have the ceremonies as solemn and imposing as possible.
lead_paragraph: The funeral of Archbishop HUGHES will take place on Thursday morning, at 10 o'clock, from St. Patrick's Cathedral, in Mott-street. His remains will be exposes at the cathedral to-day and to-morrow, from 9 o'clock in the morning until 9 at night, so that all who wish may behold them. Great preparations are making to have the ceremonies as solemn and imposing as possible. The cathedral is to be draped in black and lit with tapers. In the centre aisle will be exacted a catafalque covered with black velvet and crape, and illuminated with wax tapers. On the top of this the body will be placed until the day of the funeral, when it will be placed in front of the altar. Mayor GUNTHER yesterday sent a message to the Common Council in relation to the death of Archbishop HUGHES, which will be found in another column. In pursuance of his suggestion, the Common Council sent a "Committee to wait upon Very Rev. Father STARRS, V.G., announcing their intention to attend the funeral in a body. The Friendly Sons of St. Patrick, the Father Mathew Temperance Societies, and various other Societies and Associations will be present. The Grand High Mass of Requiem and the other ceremonies are expected to occupy nearly the entire day. His remains will be interred in the vaults of St. Patrick's Cathedral.

abstract: The absence of Senator WHITE, now a prisoner at Richmond, leaves the Senate a tie vote. It will be claimed that in this case the existing officers of the Senate are entitled to retain their positions until successors are elected. If the Democrats concede this (which is not probable) the Senate will organize immediately. If not the contest will be prolonged.
lead_paragraph: HARRISBURGH, Monday, Jan. 4.

abstract: The remains of Archbishop HUGHES were laid in state yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. During the entire day, from 5 in the morning until the doors were closed at 8 o'clock in the evening, the streets and avenues leading to the Cathedral were thronged with pilgrims to the shrine of His Grace, the late Archbishop of New-York.
lead_paragraph: The remains of Archbishop HUGHES were laid in state yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. During the entire day, from 5 in the morning until the doors were closed at 8 o'clock in the evening, the streets and avenues leading to the Cathedral were thronged with pilgrims to the shrine of His Grace, the late Archbishop of New-York. On entering the Church the visitors were required to pass up the centre aisle, passing the corpse, thence around in front of the altar and so out by the side aisle. In the center aisle, near the altar, is the catafalque, a platform covered with black cloth and crape, surmounted by a canopy of black and white cloth, the whole illuminated by six wax tapers. Upon this the body is laid, being, as yet, uncoffined. The corpse is dressed in the robes of office worn by deceased in life.

abstract: The Report of
snippet: The Report of
lead_paragraph: We published, yesterday, an abstract of Gen. MCCLELLAN's report of his operations while Commander of the Army of the Potomac. The original document will, probably, never meet the eyes of one of a thousand of our readers. Its enormous bulk of a thousand printed pages precludes general circulation. The book, properly speaking, is not an official document at all. It has none of the succinctness and simplicity which belong to that class of productions. Military annals, either in Europe or in America, may be searched in vain for any report of a General in command, of one tenth part of the magnitude of this. WELLINGTON, though seven years in the Peninsula, never wrote a paper that would fill twenty of these pages. GRANT, though his achievements have been a hundred times greater, has told them all in reports the whole collection of which may be read in sixty minutes. This report is, in fact, nothing else than the Military Memoirs of George B. McClellan, printed at the expense of the Government.

abstract: Both Houses reassembled yesterday. In the House, Mr. SMITH, of Kentucky, introduced a bill providing for the pay of bounty and pensions for soldiers called out in the Departments of Ohio and Kentucky. Two messages were received from the President: one recommending that the Bounty Appropriation Act, passed before the holidays,
lead_paragraph: Both Houses reassembled yesterday. In the House, Mr. SMITH, of Kentucky, introduced a bill providing for the pay of bounty and pensions for soldiers called out in the Departments of Ohio and Kentucky. Two messages were received from the President: one recommending that the Bounty Appropriation Act, passed before the holidays, be so modified as to permit the payment of bounties until Feb. 1; the other informing the House of the labors of the Peruvian Commission, and recommending an appropriation to meet the awards. The messages were appropriately referred. Mr. FENTON, of New-York, gave notice of his intention to introduce a bill to reimburse loyal citizens for damages sustained during the war. Mr. HARRINGTON, of Indiana, gave notice of a bill to pay bounties and pensions to soldiers honorably discharged, who had served a less period than three years. Mr. COFFROTH, of Pennsylvania, introduced a resolution, which was adopted, calling on the Secretary of the Treasury for information concerning the connection of JAY COOKE & Co., of Philadelphia, with the sale of the Government loan. Messrs. CHANLER and NELSON, of New-York, both introduced bills providing for the reduction or repeal of the duties upon coal. Mr. BRANDAGEE, of Connecticut, introduced a resolution providing for the appointment of a Select Committee to examine into a new route for postal and other purposes, between New-York and Washington.

abstract: - The gentlemen appointed by Gov. SEYMOUR as Police Commissioners met yesterday, and organized by the election of Mr. MCMURRAY as President, and Mr. LEWIS as Treasurer. They resolved that they would take no further steps toward the assertion of authority over the present Police force until the decision of the Courts should be had as to the legality and validity of their appointment. This is a very proper and commendable decision, and will be received with satisfaction by the whole community. It relieves us from all fear of the renewal of such disgraceful and dangerous proceedings as took place when Mayor WOOD resisted the introduction of the present system.
lead_paragraph: - The gentlemen appointed by Gov. SEYMOUR as Police Commissioners met yesterday, and organized by the election of Mr. MCMURRAY as President, and Mr. LEWIS as Treasurer. abstract: On National Affairs; His Message
snippet: On National Affairs; His Message
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR's Message shows that his sympathies are still with the rebellion. He discusses national affairs at length and with earnestness; -- but all his zeal, all his rhetoric all his arguments, are aimed at the Government of the United States. His whole soul is enlisted in the effort to degrade that Government in the estimation of the world; to represent it as unpatriotic, ignorant, reckless, selfish and tyrannical; -- to alarm the country by exaggerated pictures of the ruin it is bringing upon it; -- to array public passion against its action -- and thus to cripple and paralyze its endeavors to suppress the rebellion, and conquer a just and permanent peace. In this as in his previous message Gov. SEYMOUR has nothing whatever to say in condemnation of the rebellion, nor does he take into account in a single instance those acts of the rebel authorities which have compelled our Government to persevere in the exertion of force for the restoration of peace. He charges the Government with prolonging the war for selfish, partisan and vindictive purposes -- and with refusing to avail itself of an alleged readiness, on the part of the rebels, to lay down their arms and resume their allegiance to the Constitution. It would be difficult to believe Gov. SEYMOUR serious in these allegations, if his whole official career had not proved his readiness to act upon them.

abstract: Police Commissioners, the New, Organize and Abide Further Action
snippet: Police Commissioners, the New, Organize and Abide Further Action
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon Messrs. BOSWORTH, MCMURRAY and LEWIS, named as Police Commissioners by Gov. SEYMOUR, met at No. 61 William-street, Room No. 18, for the purpose of effecting an organization. On motion of Mr. MCMURRAY, a vote was taken for President, and Ex-Judge BOSWORTH was elected. The latter, in a few words, thanked the members of the Commission for the honor they had conferred upon him, but respectfully begged leave to decline, on the ground that the duties of his profession occupied so much of his time, that it would be impossible for him to devote himself to the business, at least for the present and for as much t[???]e as the responsible duties required. His resignation was thereupon received, and Mr. MCMURRAY was elected President, and WM.B. LEWIS, Esq., was appointed Treasurer.

abstract: Fair and the War
snippet: Fair and the War
lead_paragraph: One of the most remarkable features of the present war is the humane aspect given it by the non-combatant population of the North. Willing, as rich and poor alike have been, to give the required quota of their substance, and fathers, mothers, wives and sisters to yield up their loved ones in the national cause, they have also striven to do something, to indicate that although interested in a prodigious war, they did not abandon the cherished ideas of Christianity and civilization. Professing no special chivalric sentiment, the North has manifested the tenderest devotion to those who fought its battles and secured its salvation, and has not neglected to care for the physical wants of its stricken and conquered enemies. In this movement the United States Sanitary Commission has made itself historical. No story of the great war for the Union can ever be complete which neglects to chronicle the efforts of noble men and women throughout the land, under its auspices. What has been accomplished by its means has been again and again acknowledged by Government, by Generals at the head of armies, and better than all, by suffering and fainting soldiers in hospital and camp and field. The nation knows, the world knows much of the good wrought by this Commission; all of that good can never be known until that day when it shall be said: "Inasmuch as ye have done it unto the least of these, ye have done it unto Me."

abstract: Steamers Built in 1863
snippet: Steamers Built in 1863
lead_paragraph: On the first day of January, 1864, the United States possessed the fastest navy in the world. The chief vessels composing it have all been constructed during the year 1863. It affords us great pleasure to be able to enumerate these vessels, and to name the rates of speed which they have attained, in order to show the success which has attended the energy and perseverance of our Government in its determination to have ships-of-war capable of rapid movements.

abstract: Casualties by, How replaced
snippet: Casualties by, How replaced
lead_paragraph: Economists have always spoken of "efficiency" of labor as one great source of wealth that is, the application of forethought, invention and industry to production, so that the greatest possible result is obtained for the force applied. It is this peculiarity of American labor which is so rapidly now replacing the losses of this war, and which is each day opening new sources of wealth. To many minds both here and in Europe, the financial condition of this country, during this fearfully wasteful war, has been a mystery and an anomaly. How a nation could be throwing into the sea, as it were, several hundreds of millions every year, and not be plunging into bankruptcy and ruin, was something at first inexplicable to students of finance and economical science.
headline: {'main': 'The Losses of War How they are to be Replaced.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Losses of War How they are to be Replaced.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Navy Department was yesterday in receipt of official dispatches from Rear-Admiral BAILEY, commanding the East Gulf Blockading Squadron, detailing some very important operations in which a portion of his force had lately engaged. An expedition or series of expeditions, under the direction of Acting-Master BROWNE, of the bark Restless, had explored the waters of Lake Ocala and the West and St. Andrew's Bays, landing repeatedly, and destroying the very extensive salt-works from which the rebel Confederacy has mainly received its supplies. Nearly two hundred of these salt-boiling establishments, with their boilers and manufactured stock were destroyed, and the value of the property is estimated at $3,000,000. The town of St. Andrew's which was occupied by a rebel force, was shelled and burned to ashes. In the Suwannee River, the United States schooner Fox had surprised a blockade-running steamer, which she could not bring out, and was compelled to burn. The Fox had also captured the British schooner Edwin, attempting to run the blockade.

abstract: -- We presume it is generally known that all bounties to volunteers from this State beyond the State bounty of seventy-five dollars, authorized by the Act of the Legislature of 1862, whether paid by cities, counties, towns, villages or individuals, are really illegal, being in violation of the law mentioned, which, for the purpose of securing a uniform bounty throughout the State, prohibited all corporations and individuals from paving any other bounties. But the late calls of the President for more troops have necessitated extraordinary exertions to raise the men, and nearly every corporation in the State has paid extra bounties. We see that bills have very promptly been introduced into the Legislature to legalize the acts of these corporations, and thus give validity to the ordinances upon which the money has been obtained.
lead_paragraph: -- We presume it is generally known that all bounties to volunteers from this State beyond the State bounty of seventy-five dollars, authorized by the Act of the Legislature of 1862, whether paid by cities, counties, towns, villages or individuals, are really illegal, being in violation of the law mentioned, which, for the purpose of securing a uniform bounty throughout the State, prohibited all corporations and individuals from paving any other bounties. But the late calls of the President for more troops have necessitated extraordinary exertions to raise the men, and nearly every corporation in the State has paid extra bounties. We see that bills have very promptly been introduced into the Legislature to legalize the acts of these corporations, and thus give validity to the ordinances upon which the money has been obtained.

abstract: Comptroller's (Lucius Robinson) Annual Report
snippet: Comptroller's (Lucius Robinson) Annual Report
lead_paragraph: We have received the Annual Report of Hon. LUOIUS ROBINSON, Comptroller of the State of NewYork. It is a very interesting document, but we have room only for an abstract of its principal features. The Comptroller introduces his report, by remarking that "the Government of this State is organizes upon principles of strict economy. Its ordinary and necessary expenses are very light. A yearly tax of less than one mill upon each dollar of the valuation would be sufficient to pay them. And yet, with a tax four times that amount, the close of the last fiscal year found the treasury overdrawn, and the General Fund revenue heavily deficient. This arose from the large appropriations made by the Legislature for objects outside of the ordinary expenses of the Government, the extent of which could not be anticipated, and for which no reliable estimates could be given."
headline: {'main': 'THE STATE FINANCES.; Abstract of the Annual Report of the Comptroller.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE STATE FINANCES.; Abstract of the Annual Report of the Comptroller.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Both Houses got comfortably at work yesterday. In the House of Representatives Mr. KELLEY was excused from serving on the Select Committee on a National Bankrupt act. Mr. BRANDEGEE'S resolution for the appointment of a select committee to consider the feasibility of a new railroad route from NewYork to Washington, was adopted.
lead_paragraph: Both Houses got comfortably at work yesterday. In the House of Representatives Mr. KELLEY was excused from serving on the Select Committee on a National Bankrupt act. Mr. BRANDEGEE'S resolution for the appointment of a select committee to consider the feasibility of a new railroad route from NewYork to Washington, was adopted. The municipal authorities of Washington are urged by resolution to take measures for the prevention of the spread of small-pox. Mr. FARNSWORTH, of Illinois, offered a resolution extending the time for the payment of bounties to March 1, which, after discussion, was passed unanimously. A resolution, offered by Mr. SWEAT, of Maine, was passed, authorizing an investigation, by a scientific Board, into the construction of naval vessels. The expediency of including nine months' volunteers in the coming draft is to be considered, The Secretary of the Navy is required to communicate the reason of the delay in distributing prize-money. The House, in Committee of the Whole, considered the Post-office Appropriation Bill, which drew out a spicy discussion on the miserable postal and traveling arrangements between New-York and Washington -- intensified by the recent experiences of a large number of Congressmen. The bill was finally passed. The consideration of the Presidents Message was taken up. Mr. ARNOLD, of Ill., spoke at length, warmly indorsing the President's views, and arguing the total extinction of slavery as a necessity to the complete salvation of the country. Adjourned.

abstract: RIVER ITEMS. -- The new ferry building at the foot of Whitehall-street, is rapidly approaching completion. Most of the fron work has been put up, and the roof will probably be laid some time next month. A new landing at the Battery, the building of which for a long time has been in contemplation, is about to be constructed. It is to consist of suitable steps to the water, and a building to cover the same. The warehouses demolished by the Bavaria at the new steamship docks in Hoboken, are being rebuilt.
