abstract: on "Wise Statesmanship" and "Conciliatory Policy"
snippet: on "Wise Statesmanship" and "Conciliatory Policy"
lead_paragraph: Gov. SEYMOUR devotes all the latter portion of his message to an indictment of the Administration for not manifesting a "wise statesmanship" and a "conciliatory policy." Like all men factiously inclined, he is very careful, however, to confine himself to general phrases. He does not indicate the particular line of "statesmanship" which wisdom demands, nor the particular "policy" which is to secure conciliation. He goes in for a milder form of war, especially as relates to Slavery, but does not show, nor attempt to show, how such mildness would promote loyalty, or hasten peace. He either does not know, or he affects not to know, that it depends altogether upon circumstances whether forbearance is wisdom or weakness; whether mildness is a lure to peace or an encouragement to resistance.

abstract: In the Senate the Secretary or War, on motion of Mr. DAVIS, was requested to furnish all the papers relating to the exchange of prisoners. On motion of Mr. FESSENDEN, the Bounty Bill was referred to the Finance Committee. The Enrollment. Act was taken up, and all the amendments adopted save that repealing the $300 clause. Mr. DAVIS, of Kv., found occasion, during the discussion, to get off his usual tirade against the loyal efforts of the Government. Mr. HOW, o Wisconsin, introduced a bill, which was laid over and ordered printed, reciting the sufferings of our prisoners in the hands of the enemy, and authorizing the President to call out one million of men for ninety days, and put them under the command of Gen. GRANT, for the purpose of carrying food and freedom to every national soldier in a rebel prison. Mr. NESMITH gave notice of an amendment to the Enrollment Act, providing that persons who may be pronounced physically exempt from the draft, shall, if their incomes exceed $1,000 per year, pay $300 to secure their exemption.

abstract: Bright, John, and London Times on Land Ownership
snippet: Bright, John, and London Times on Land Ownership
lead_paragraph: The controversy growing out of the charge made by the London Times against Mr. BRIGHT, and resented so keenly in his behalf by Mr. COBDEN, of seeking a division amongst the poor of the estates of the great landholders, has drawn public attention anew to the general subject. The editor of the Times disclaims any intention of having attributed to either of these gentlemen the advocacy of a forcible division of landed estates; but Mr. BRIGHT's language was sufficiently equivocal to give the interpretation put upon it an air of plausibility. But no one who has paid the least attention to the political and economical theories of "the Manchester school," as preached during the last twenty years by its two great apostles, can fail to know that there is nothing it deprecates so much as legal interference with the distribution of wealth. Its cardinal doctrine is, that property should be allowed to go where-ever it would naturally go, if men were permitted to follow their inclination, without let or hindrance, in dealing with it. It seeks to make real estate in England subject to the same rules of law as personal property; to make its transfer a transmission as simple and as cheap as would be consistent with security, or, in other words, to subject it to the ordinary laws of trade; and Mr. BRIGHT advocates this because he foresees that it would lead there, as it leads here, to a more equal distribution of the land of the country amongst the inhabitants, and would counteract, if not reverse, that tendency to the accumulation of large estates in the hands of single families, which, all acknowledge, is one great cause of English poverty.
headline: {'main': 'The Ownership of Land in England--what the Real Evil is.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Ownership of Land in England--what the Real Evil is.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Advices from Cumberland Gap say that a body of Union troops, numbering about 300 men, stationed at Jonesville, Western Virginia, to guard a region which was an excellent place for foraging, was surprised on Sunday last, by an overwhelming force of rebels, estimated at 4,000, under Gen. SAM JONES. Our men made a desperate resistance, continuing form 7 A.M. to 3 P.M., and only surrendered after losing 30 killed, and 30 wounded, one gun and two small howitzers.

abstract: -- Our correspondent in China sends us a very interesting letter which we publish this morning, concerning an important advance of the Chinese Government, in its relations with the rest of the world. A translation of WHEATON's work on International Law has been made, and is about to be adopted by the Chinese authorities, as their guide in regulating their foreign affairs. It is pretty clear from this that the era of isolation for China is closed. In spite of all her efforts, she must assume her place as one of the family of nations, and recognize her responsibility to the rules and regulations which govern the intercourse of independent Powers. Our correspondent awards high credit to Mr. BURLINGAME, our Minister in China, for the part he has taken in bringing about this very important step.
lead_paragraph: -- Our correspondent in China sends us a very interesting letter which we publish this morning, concerning an important advance of the Chinese Government, in its relations with the rest of the world. A translation of WHEATON's work on International Law has been made, and is about to be adopted by the Chinese authorities, as their guide in regulating their foreign affairs. It is pretty clear from this that the era of isolation for China is closed. In spite of all her efforts, she must assume her place as one of the family of nations, and recognize her responsibility to the rules and regulations which govern the intercourse of independent Powers. Our correspondent awards high credit to Mr. BURLINGAME, our Minister in China, for the part he has taken in bringing about this very important step.

abstract: Hughes, Archbishop; Funeral Rites of
snippet: Hughes, Archbishop; Funeral Rites of
lead_paragraph: The vicinity of St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday, as early as 5 o'clock in the morning, began to furnish indications that some event of unwonted interest was about to transpire. Men, women and children were collecting in knots and groups in front and rear of the church long before daylight, discussing the virtues and goodness of their late Archbishop, the character of the ceremonies of the day, and the chances of getting a view of the inside of the sacred edifice which contained the remains of the father of the Catholic Church in America. By daylight the scattering groups had consolidated and increased to thousands, requiring the unremitting attentions of 200 policemen to keep them within bounds and limits. Ropes were stretched across in Mulberry and Mott streets, and with this assistance a cordon of police kept the crowd from blocking up the entrances to the Cathedral. Those who had a right to enter, or who had received proper invitations, got in by edging through the outsiders as best they might. Those whom, owing to the limited accommodations, the Trustees were compelled to exclude, exhausted themselves in vain supplications to the guardians of the public peace for the privilege of a moment's admission, -- their appears and expostulations being made in every cadence of the Milesian brogue.

abstract: Capt. B.F. FLINN, of the bark Edisto, of Boston, abandoned at sea, reports: Sailed from New-York, Dec. 5, for Cette, with a full cargo of staves, Dec. 6 commenced with heavy gales from N. and N.N.W., with a very head sea; vessel laboring heavily, and decks flooded. The vessel making considerable water, was obliged to throw the deck load overboard to ease ship. Dec. 10, very heavy gales from N.W. to W., and very high sea running; pumps constantly going, ship making 18 inches water per hour; men and pumps giving out; cut away topmasts to case ship. Dec. 12, made a sail to southeast; sounded pumps and found six feet of water in the hold; kept away for the sail intending to abandon the ship; at 5 P.M. got boats out and went alongside. She proved to be the British schooner Hagar, from New-York, bound to Gibraltar, she having had her decks swept of everything, bulwarks gone, fore and aft, but were willing to take us on board. About 8 o'clock P.M., while getting things into the boat, suddenly perceived the cabin on fire; rushed for the chronometer, barometer and several other articles which were lying in the cabin all ready to take away, but found the smoke and fire so intense, were obliged to abandon everything. The fire must have originated by the upsetting of a lamp which was left burning in the cabin. After being on board the schooner for four days, spoke the British ship Mary Durkee, Capt. CROSBY, from Cardiff for New-York, who kindly took us all, twelve in number, on board, and brought us to this port. Our position when we abandoned her was lat. 36° 15′, long. 63° 20′. The Edisto was 365 tons burden, belonged to and was owned at Boston, by B.F. FLINNE and others, and was probably insured.

The fire must have originated by the upsetting of a lamp which was left burning in the cabin. After being on board the schooner for four days, spoke the British ship Mary Durkee, Capt. CROSBY, from Cardiff for New-York, who kindly took us all, twelve in number, on board, and brought us to this port. Our position when we abandoned her was lat. 36 15, long. 63 20. The Edisto was 365 tons burden, belonged to and was owned at Boston, by B.F. FLINNE and others, and was probably insured.

abstract: The ship Neptune, belonging to the C.H. Marshal line, arrived here, yesterday, from Liverpool, with 368 passengers. She left Dec. 6. On the evening of Dec. 30, the first mate, GEORGE HACON, who shipped at Liverpool, was killed by some of the crew, being struck with a capstan bar while standing at the port galley. His skull was fractured, and he died in a short time after. The evening was dark, and who committed the act is unknown. On the arrival of the vessel, Capt. ENOCH W. PEABODY laid in the stream and sent word to the Second Precinct Station-house. Capt. MILLS, Sergeant VAUGHAN and eight men were detailed, who took a steamer and proceeded to the vessel, arresting, as witnesses, THOS. WARBURTON, second mate; JACOB DALE, steward, and seven of the crew, among whom, undoubtedly, is the principal. Sergeant VAUGHAN and the force brought them to the United States Marshal's Office, last evening, and surrendered them to Marshal MURRAY, who committed them to jail. The most of them are us villainous, murderous-looking beings as the eve ever lit upon. The murdered mate, from the commencement of the voyage, had had difficulty with a portion of the crew, some of whom were thieves, and in an altercation, the night before his death, had threatened to kill one of them. The mate is known here as "Balty Higgins," was reputed a bad and dangerous man, and Marshal MURRAY has been in search of him some time, on a serious charge, of one time having his officers in chase of him to Chicago, where he gave them the slip.

abstract: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning, flames were discovered issuing from the building No. 101 West Eighteenth-street, which rapidly spread to the adjoining houses. Before the firemen could gain control of the fiery element six buildings and must of their contents were destroyed. The premises where the fire originated were occupied by Hose Company.
lead_paragraph: About 2 o'clock yesterday morning, flames were discovered issuing from the building No. 101 West Eighteenth-street, which rapidly spread to the adjoining houses. Before the firemen could gain control of the fiery element six buildings and must of their contents were destroyed. The premises where the fire originated were occupied by Hose Company No. 35, a new organization. They had no apparatus in the house at the time, and the damage to them is not great. The two-story house. No. 99, was destroyed with its contents. It was occupied by THOMAS KELLY as a feed store. He lost two valuable horses, which were burned before they could be rescued. KELLY estimates his loss at over $4,000. He is insured for $500 in the Harmony Insurance Company. The loss on building is $1,500; insured for $300 in the Harmony. One of the horses burned was valued at $500, the other at $150. They were insured for the sum of $100 each. Adjoining the house above-named, were several frame stables, occupied by Mr. DOWD. Two of his horses, valued at $250 each, were burned to death. They were insured for $150 each in the Peter Cooper Insurance Company. A large amount of other property, consisting of wagons, carriages, horses, &c., was also destroyed.

abstract: It will be remembered that United States Marshal MURRAY made the arrest several days since of LOUIS BENJAMIN on the charge of having shipped goods to Nassau, the ultimate destination of which was for the South. BENJAMIN was at once sent to Fort Lafayette, and all the papers found is his office, his
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that United States Marshal MURRAY made the arrest several days since of LOUIS BENJAMIN on the charge of having shipped goods to Nassau, the ultimate destination of which was for the South. BENJAMIN was at once sent to Fort Lafayette, and all the papers found is his office, his office safe, account books, letter books, &c., taken possession of by the Marshal. The safe was found securely locked, and there was very little in the papers and books found that could be considered evidences of the prisoner's guilt. Nothing was known at the contents of the safe, but Marshal MURRAY was convinced it would be policy to know just what it did contain, and on Tuesday afternoon succeeded in opening it.

abstract: Further information transpires regarding WOLFE and HOFFNUNG, the individuals mentioned in the TIMES of Sunday and Monday last, as being engaged in blockade running from Nassau to Confederate ports. They were not residents of New-York at the opening of the war, as was supposed at the Custom-house, but came to this City from Montreal, Canada, last Spring, from whence they are charged with absconding without paying their debts. WOLFS and HOFFNUNG are brothers-in-law, and the former married the daughter of an English Jew, named MORRIS LUMLEY, a man of notorious character, who is now in the Eldridge-street jail under charge of extensive fraud. Prior to January, 1863, he was for many years a dealer in ready-made clothing in Toronto, where he had made money, and established a good credit at home and abroad. During the latter half of 1662 he purchased on credit in Montreal, in England and in Scotland, over $200,000 worth of merchandise, under pretence that it was intended for his legitimate Canadian trade. All these goods he converted into money, in New-York and Philadelphia, before any of his paper, given in payment, had matured, and on the 8th of January, 1863, he came to Montreal to reside. He paid none of his notes, would not state what had become of the goods he had received, nor give any information whatever to his creditors. Seversl of them, therefore, arrested him, about the 1st of February, and lodged him in the jail of that city.
lead_paragraph: Further information transpires regarding WOLFE and HOFFNUNG, the individuals mentioned in the TIMES of Sunday and Monday last, as being engaged in blockade running from Nassau to Confederate ports. abstract: System, Our
snippet: System, Our
lead_paragraph: Nobody is so foolish that he does not now and then say a sensible thing, and Gov. SEYMOUR is no exception to the rule. His remarks, in his Message, touching the necessity for keeping up the State militia, are peculiarly sound, just and forcible. They would have been so even if made in time of peace, and they are doubly so now in time of war. There ought in every State to he a militia composed of all the arms-bearing population, and as well armed, and well drilled, and well officered as it is possible for a militia to be. Everybody who is fit for military duty, and either will not or cannot enlist in the army in the field, ought to be compelled to enter the militia, and to devote a certain amount of his leisure time to its duties. If this were done, we should, in the first place, enjoy perfect security against domestic violence and peril, which, in our great cities, is increasing every year; and in the second, we should possess a respectable reserve in case of great disaster to the army in the field, and be spared the pain and humiliation of witnessing such wild "uprisings" as followed on LEE'S invasion of Pennsylvania last summer. And this militia, instead of being wasted in companies and other small bodies, ought to be in regiments, and brigaded, under the command of proper generals, and kept constantly, as far as equipments and organization go, for active service.

abstract: The newspaper mails (thirty-six bags) forwarded from the Post-office in this City, via 5 oclock P.M. train over the Erie Railway, on the 29th of December last, for the following offices, were destroyed by fire near Adrian, N.Y., about 4 oclock A.M., on the 30th: Cleveland, 7 bags; Chicago, 9 bags; Columbus, 1 bag; Cairo, 1 bag; Cincinnati, 3 bags, Nashville, 1 bag; St. Joseph, 2 bags; St. Louis, 3 bags; Denver City, 1 bag; Dubuque, 1 bag; Fort Wayne, 1 bag; Indianapolis, 2 bags; Louisville, 2 bags; St. Paul, 1 bag; Toledo, 1 bag; Mareitta and Cincinnati Route Agent, 1 bag. The bags for the offices named were placed in the forward end of the express car, and took fire, it is supposed, from sparks from the engine, admitted through the aper[???] through which passes the bell-rope. When the Mail Messenger discovered the fire, he immediately endeavored to stop the train by pulling the bell-cord; but this having a ready being burnt off, his efforts were of no avail; the motion of the train served to increase the flames, and before the train was stopped, and efforts made to extinguish the fire, the contents of the car were about consumed.

abstract: the Poor and the Cold Weather
snippet: the Poor and the Cold Weather
lead_paragraph: These bitterly cold nights and wintry days must remind us all of the great numbers of poor people in our City exposed at this season of the year to cold and hunger. It is a fortunate and providential circumstance that the calamity of war has brought no new sufferings to the masses of destitute and unbefriended persons who always crowd certain portions of New-York. On the contrary, the two Winters of civil war past have been seasons of uncommon good fortune and comfort to our poorer classes. The icy winds themselves have been tempered to these unfortunate people, and Winter for two years has been shorn of half its terrors to those who live in the streets or whose bleak hovels are seldom brightened by a fire.
headline: {'main': 'The Poor and Our Charities.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Poor and Our Charities.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We received a copy of the report of Hon. H.H. VAN DYCK, Bank Superintendent, at a late hour last evening. The amount of circulating notes outstanding at the close of the fiscal year was $42,192,645. The securities held in trust at the close of the fiscal year amounted to
lead_paragraph: We received a copy of the report of Hon. H.H. VAN DYCK, Bank Superintendent, at a late hour last evening. The amount of circulating notes outstanding at the close of the fiscal year was $42,192,645. The securities held in trust at the close of the fiscal year amounted to $37,639,236 CO. This was divided -- New-York State stock, $17,344,140; limited States stock, $15,797,850; bonds and mortgages, $3,862,097. The increase in United States securities during the year reaches $3,898,490. The report is chiefly devoted to combatting the plans and views of the Secretary of the Treasury. The Superintendent says: "The people and banks of New-York cannot but look with apprehension at the palpable indications from Washington of a design, on the part of the Secretary of the Treasury and his subordinate officers, to foster oppressive legislation by Congress toward the institutions of this State, with the apparent purpose of compelling an abandonment of their present organizations, and an adoption of the national system."

abstract: In the senate, yesterday, a bill was introduced and referred, proposing a reorganization of the Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners, and naming THOMAS C. ACTON for eight years, WILSON SMALL for six years, JOHN G. BERGEN for four years, and SAMUEL JONES for two years ...
lead_paragraph: In the senate, yesterday, a bill was introduced and referred, proposing a reorganization of the Board of Metropolitan Police Commissioners, and naming THOMAS C. ACTON for eight years, WILSON SMALL for six years, JOHN G. BERGEN for four years, and SAMUEL JONES for two years -- their successors to be chosen by the Legislature in the same manner as Regents of the University, and hold office eight years. A resolution was offerred, inquiring into the expediency of increasing the pay of officers and members of the Police force. A bill, looking to a regulation of the Brooklyn Railroad, was noticed.

abstract: A letter received at this office from a gentleman who has resided in Wisconsin, near Milwaukee, since 1845, says that the late cold spell was by far the severest he has known since his residence there. He says: "A man could not live out-doors more than fifteen minutes without being frost-bitten.
lead_paragraph: A letter received at this office from a gentleman who has resided in Wisconsin, near Milwaukee, since 1845, says that the late cold spell was by far the severest he has known since his residence there. He says: "A man could not live out-doors more than fifteen minutes without being frost-bitten Thermometers refused to indicate -- the mercury would run down in the bowl almost as soon as exposed. I froze my ears in going forty rods; and a neighbor, in exposing his bare hand three minutes, froze his fingers. The hostler at the hotel froze his fingers and ears in trying to hitch up a horse, and then had to give it up. It was fortunate he did, for if the driver had started, he would have frozen to death."

abstract: A few days since a sailor named JOHN CUTTINGTON, belonging to the ship Constellation, which arrived from Liverpool on the 29th of December, went from his boarding-house in this City to Brooklyn, where being taken sick, he was sent to the Station-house, and thence forwarded next morning, the 7th inst., by the Alms-House Department of...
lead_paragraph: A few days since a sailor named JOHN CUTTINGTON, belonging to the ship Constellation, which arrived from Liverpool on the 29th of December, went from his boarding-house in this City to Brooklyn, where being taken sick, he was sent to the Station-house, and thence forwarded next morning, the 7th inst., by the Alms-House Department of Brooklyn, in their wagon, to the Commissioners of Emigration at Castle Garden, as a recently arrived emigrant. On discovering he was a sailor for whom hospital money had been paid and properly chargeable to the Seamen's Fund and Retreat, the General Agent (Mr. CASSERLY), at once dispatched a messenger to the officer of the Retreat, No. 12 Olds-lip, with a note from Dr. STEELING, (the physician attached to the Emigrant Department) certifying to the condition of the sailor, who was suffering from dropsy and utterly helpless, and advising that he be sent to the City Hospital, to which the General Agent added a request to the same effect. On delivering the note at the office of the Seamen's Retreat, the messenger was told that he should go to the consignee of the vessel and find out if the man was a sailor, and that until he did so, nothing could be done. The messenger went and received a certificate showing the sailor to be entitled to the benefits of the Hospital Fund, whereupon the messenger was handed a card of admission, "provided the case required treatment," to the Seamen's Retreat, Staten Island, and a ferry ticket, and told that when the sailor, whom the messenger corroborated by the medical certificate, reported as utterly helpless, got to Staten Island, he would be taken to the Retreat in a vehicle which he would find there! The unfortunate sailor being unable to help himself or to reach the ferry, and the weather being very cold, and as it would endanger the man's life if compelled to go to Staten Island without any care or protection, the General Agent, on learning that nothing more would be done for the patient, addressed a note to CHARLES CAROW, Esq., No. 76 South-street, the consignee of the vessel, who, to his credit and humanity, responded with an order for the admission of the sick man to the New-York Hospital, becoming thereby responsible for his support and medical attendance, although he had already paid to the Seaman's Fund hospital money as required by law.
headline: {'main': 'Cruel Treatment of Sailors.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Cruel Treatment of Sailors.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The, Against Guerrillas
snippet: The, Against Guerrillas
lead_paragraph: -- The deeply interesting letter from our correspondent in Gen. BUTLER's Department, which we give to-day, not only reveals the negro soldier in a new phase of military activity, but helps in the solution of one of the difficult questions which possibly lies in the future. The rebels have always told us that, if the power of the North should ultimately defeat their great armies, and secure possession of the strategic positions in the South, they would simply break up into innumerable bands of guerrillas, who would ride the continent from the Potomac to the Rio Grande, harassing our troops, preventing, the reorganization of government, society and industry, destroying towns, and, in short, carrying havoc and anarchy everywhere. Of course, it is only the more desperate men who threaten all this; but our experience in the Southwest has shown us that there are enough desperate men of this kidney to cause, for a time at least, a great deal of trouble.

abstract: The steamship Africa, with three days later advices, arrived at Halifax on Thursday evening. The most interesting item of news is the an nouncement of the sudden death of WILLIAM- MAKEPEACE THACKERAY, the novelist.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Africa, with three days later advices, arrived at Halifax on Thursday evening. The most interesting item of news is the an nouncement of the sudden death of WILLIAM- MAKEPEACE THACKERAY, the novelist. Business in England was generally suspended from the 24th to the 26th of December, that the Christmas festivities might be duly observed. The London Army and Navy Gazette says that the Messrs. LAIRD have declared the Mersey rams are not for sale, refusing several offers to purchase them. The United States Ministers at London and Paris were making strenuous efforts to frustrate the escape of the rebel steamer Rappahannock from Calais. Six of the Irishmen who volunteered on the United States gunboat Kearsage had been committed for trial on a charge of having enlisted to fight in the service of the United States. There had been no collision between the Danish and Federal troops in Holstein up to the 25th ult., when telegraphic communication was interrupted. The people of Altona, a town in Holstein, had had an illumination and general rejoicing in honor of Prince FREDERICK. This town was evacuated by the Danes on the 24th, at the approach of the Federals. The rumors of an insurrectionary movement in Hungary are reported. A pacific tone is apparent in the debates of the French Legislature. The course of the Government on the Mexican question had been censured by Mr. PICARD.

abstract: The steamship Yazoo, from New-Orleans, Dec. 21, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The rainy season was at its height, and until it had passed no military operations were feasible.

abstract: Police Bill, The Proposed
snippet: Police Bill, The Proposed
lead_paragraph: A bill has been introduced into the State Legislature to amend the Present Police Law so as to remove the Metropolitan Police Department, as far as possible, from the control of party politics. It proposes that the Commission shall consist of four members, instead of three as at present, and divides it equally between the Union and Democratic parties. It gives them a long term of office, with the power to fill vacancies, and provides for the appointment of new members by the Legislature, in the same way as United States Senators and Regents of the University are now appointed. The bill retains Messrs. ACTON and BERGEN, the present members, and appoints Messrs. BOSWORTH and JONES, two Democrats.

abstract: THE RATE OF PAY TO OFFICERS.  The Senate bill reducing the pay of officers when not in the field though on duty or under orders, gives Brigadier-Generals, $3,200; Colonels, $2,800; Lieut.-Colonels, $2,250; Majors, $1,875; Captains, $1,500; Lieutenants, $1,200. When absent on leave Brigadier-Generals, $2,500; Colonels, $2,100; Lieut.-Colonels, $1,680; Majors, $1,500; Captains, $1,200; Lieutenants, $900. The pay of Major-Generals has been reduced to $4,000 when on duty, and $3,000 when on leave.

abstract: Officer MCCORD, of the Detective force, on Thursday afternoon arrested a man named RICHARD JOHNSON, under the following circumstances: On the night of the 5th inst., the premises No. 28 Bowery, occupied by Mr. JAMES SCOTT as a storage house, were entered in a burglarious manner, and five rolls of carpeting valued at $400, also plated silver ware, coats and other, property worth $170, were stolen therefrom. Detective MCCORD was detailed to work up the case, and after much time and labor expended, he succeeded, at 2 o'clock on Thursday morning, in tracing the stolen property to some stables in the rear of No. 181 East Thirty-second-street. The officer finding no person in charge of the premises at that hour, kept a diligent watch upon them until three o'clock in the afternoon, at which time, JOHNSON made his appearance, and pretended that he was going to the stables to feed his horse. The official was not to be misled, and from certain descriptions he had of the thief he felt confident he had the right man; he therefore took him into custody and made a search of his person. In JOHNSON's pockets were found a quantity of silver spoons and forks, broken in pieces. Mr. SCOTT identified them as a portion of those stolen from his store. The carpeting coats and other property stolen were found [???] in the stable, and returned to Mr. SCOTT. The [???]ed was taken before Justice MANSFIELD, and [???]ed for trial in default of $2,000 bail. He is a [???] by occupation, and resides at No. 185 East Seventeenth-street.

abstract: Adoption of International Law in
snippet: Adoption of International Law in
lead_paragraph: The letter which we published yesterday from our Pekin correspondent, announcing the acceptance by China of the code of International Law, and of WHEATON'S great work as the exponent of that code, signalizes one of the most remarkable developments of these remarkable times. It is, in fact, the most important step ever taken by that gigantic Empire toward identifying itself with modern civilization, and one of the greatest triumphs, too, of American influence.

abstract: ENGLISH OPERA. Mr. HARRISON'S operatic experiment was made on Monday night, with success. Considering that Brooklyn is a cool place, and that learned divines there make a point of preaching down amusements, we might even say with tremendous success.
lead_paragraph: ENGLISH OPERA. -- Mr. HARRISON's operatic experiment was made on Monday night, with success. Considering that Brooklyn is a cool place, and that learned divines there make a point of preaching down amusements, we might even say with tremendous success. The Park Theatre has seldom looked more bright and elegant. It was full, too; full upstairs and full down. To be sure, it does not require a heavy per centage of the entire Brooklyn population to fill an establishment of such modest proportions; but it has to be remembered sadly, that, on other occasions, the levy has been made in vain, and, not long ago, it seemed as though Brooklyn, instead of being the second city of the Union, were a paltry, psalm-smiting, one-horsed village. Let us hope that the interest which Mr. HARRISON has now awakened in his fellow-citizens will abide by the theatre of which he is the manager. Such a little gem of a place should be preserved and made prosperous, if by nothing else then by an amiable exhibition of local pride, which, in its place, is always good and creditable.

abstract: Mr. BRADY, the sun-compeller, who reflects more often the pleasures of life than its sorrows, has been privileged to give to the world the last aspects of the deceased Archbishop HUGHES. The dead prelate is represented in three positions, or rather in three points of view. 1. Watched over by the Very Reverend Vicar STARRS and Father F. MCNIERNY; 2. Lying in state; 3. In a carte de visite. These pictures are touching in their fidelity, and sad souvenirs to the thousand friends of the lamented Archbishop. Every one who remembers the deceased will undoubtedly possess themselves of these wonderful pictures.

abstract: Has the star of the Third NAPOLEON culminated, that all his latter-day schemes, devices, and enterprises have been attended with failure. During the first decade of his public career, everything he undertook prospered. He gained the Presidency and the Empire; ...
lead_paragraph: Has the star of the Third NAPOLEON culminated, that all his latter-day schemes, devices, and enterprises have been attended with failure. During the first decade of his public career, everything he undertook prospered. He gained the Presidency and the Empire; he was victorious in the Crimea[???]and in Italy; and even the legerdemain by which he aimed to filch Savoy and Nice from King VICTOR, met with success. But, for some time, his good fortune has departed from him. In peace and in war, at home and abroad, he has been alike unlucky. His plot for the establishment of monarchy in Mexico, has already broken down; his attempt to intimidate Russia, has proved abortive; his efforts to induce the Great Powers to sanction the convocation of a Congress, have been in vain; while, within the past twelve months he has experienced three rebuffs from France, more ominous than all. A French parliamentary opposition has been formed in defiance of him, and Paris, which he has done so much to embellish, has twice cast her vote against the candidates of his choice, once in May last, at the general election, and again, the other day, in favor of M. PELLETAN. M. PELLETAN, a distinguished Liberal, had been originally returned for the Ninth District of the Seine, but the satellites of the Government, in the Second Chamber, wishing to get rid of so formidable an opponent, availed themselves of some technical irregularity in the proceedings, and pronounced M. PELLETAN's election void. That gentleman, nowise disheartened by this decision, determined to renew the contest with his antagonist, though the latter was supported by the Government, the official press, and the Parisian municpalties, who left no artifice untried that could possibly tend to prevent the reelection of the obnoxious ex-deputy. The forty mayors and sub-mayors of the metropolis entered the lists against him, and issued a manifesto in which the private and public conduct of PELLETAN was painted in the blackest colors. "He was an unnatural father, a bad citizen, and a bad man. He had attacked and calumniated that which all true Frenchmen most love and venerate -- the glory and the grandeur of our country; the military services and renown of our Emperor; the combats and the victories of Italy have found no favor with him. Nay, he has even dared to assail and insult our national song-writer, the popular and immortal BERANGER." Now, could it be imagined that the Parisians of the ninth district would be so stupid as to give this bad citizen, bad critic, and bad man the victory over the immaculate PICARD, who "was bountiful to all, looked up to with affection and respect, a model of civic virtue, a liberal in politics, and devoted at once to the empire and the principles of 89?" But, alas! when was mere merit a guarantee of success? And such was the perversity of the electors in question, that they actually re-chose the wicked M. PELLETAN, by a majority of near six thousand votes, to represent them, rather than the amiable nonentity whom the Government and the municipalities patronized. This second great defeat of the Executive in the metropolis is a much more serious disaster than the Emperor's failure to effect the convocation of a Congress. For, with France blindly devoted to him, he might defy and contemn the jealousy of European potentates, but if Frenchmen continue to grow lukewarm and indifferent, if not positively antagonistic, to his cause and rule, what security can he have for the stability of his throne, or the maintenance of his prestige? NAPOLEON has, in fact, got himself into another awkward dilemma. He has gone too far, or not far enough. It is possible to uphold a despotism, and it is possible to uphold constitutional government, but to do what he is attempting -- to reconcile things in their nature irreconcilable -- is beyond even his skill. If he did not intend fairly to carry out his scheme of reform, he should never have broached it. If he did not intend, when he promised France freedom of the press and of election, to retire himself from the position of a despot, and to give her also a responsible ministry, he should never for a moment have consented to relax the reins of authority, or involved himself in difficulties by making mention of concession. What is the use of prating about freedom of the press, or freedom of election to a people, without constitutional government, without a government responsible to, and removable at the will of, the National Parliament? To promise liberty to such a people is a mockery, since as long as the great boon of a responsible ministry is denied them, they can have no liberty -- no privileges of any kind, save that which the caprice of a tyrant may grant to-day, and take away to-morrow. The case of France is an illustration in point. France has a de jure title to freedom of the press, and freedom of election, yet de facto she is in possession of neither; but let her once obtain a government accountable to the Chambers for its acts, and depending on the Chambers for its existence, and she will no more have occasion to complain of her rights being violated. This is a concession which the Emperor must promptly make, if he would allay the increasing discontent of the French people, and secure the sceptre of the empire to the Bonaparte dynasty. When such men as M. DE LA GUEROUNIERE pronounce against him, and proclaim that the time has come for the "crowning of the edifice," NAPOLEON should perceive that he can no longer safely delay putting his house in order. If he would not be the wrecker of his own fortunes, he must henceforth be content to reign, and not to govern. The white ants are gnawing at the pillars of the imperial fabric, and will presently bring it toppling down about his ears, should they be suffered to work on. Nor can he, as is too commonly supposed, venture to attempt turning the attention of the nation from home grievances by plunging into foreign war, without incurring danger of another and no less formidable character. The aggressive spirit of France is dreaded by Europe, and her Emperor could engage in no foreign war which would not lead to the formation of a coalition against him, with which even the power of the second empire would be unable to contend. There remains, then, no alternative for NAPOLEON, but to make the necesary concessions to his people, or to persist in a course that will ultimately lead to the subversion of his throne, and the downfall of his Government.

Previous to the battle of Missionary Ridge, the Union army was reduced almost to starvation, and their mules and horses were dying daily by hundred for ...
lead_paragraph: The Marietta (Chattanooga) Rebel says: "We have conversed with two young men from Chattanooga, who left that place on Tuesday last. They give a graphic picture of the Mountain City. Previous to the battle of Missionary Ridge, the Union army was reduced almost to starvation, and their mules and horses were dying daily by hundred for the want of forage. The Federals cut down all the cornstalks and ragweeds standing in the country around, and hauled them into town for their stock to eat; they also hauled in large quantities of oak leaves from the forests and fed them to their animals.

abstract: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE WOMEN'S HOSPITAL ASSOCIATION. The annual meeting of this Association was held at the Hospital, No. 83 Madison avenue, yesterday afternoon. A large audience was present, composed of many of our most wealthy and influential citizens.
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL MEETING OF THE WOMEN'S HOSPITAL ASSOCIATION. The annual meeting of this Association was held at the Hospital, No. 83 Madison avenue, yesterday afternoon. A large audience was present, composed of many of our most wealthy and influential citizens. In the absence of the President of the Medical Board, Mr. BEEHMAN, President of the Board of Directors, was called to the Chair. The annual report was read, which showed a favorable condition of affairs -- liberal donations having, been received during the year. Addresses were delivered by Rev. Mr. BARNUM. Dr. COXE and others. The following officers were elected for the ensuing year: Mrs. David Codwise, First Directress; Mrs. Wm.B. Astor, Second Directress; Mrs. Morris Ketchum, Third Directress; Mrs. Jacob Le Roy, Treasurer; Mrs. T.C. Doremus, Assistant Treasurer; Mrs. Walden Pell, Secretary; Mrs. James McKay. Corresponding Secretary. Board of Managers -- Mrs. Wm.H. Aspinwall, Mrs. H.J. Baker. Mrs. G. Bancroft, Mrs. James W. Beekman. Mrs. E.C. Benedict, Mrs. G.L. Beekman, Mrs. James Brooks, Mrs. Peter Cooper, Mrs. Thomas Dewitt. Mrs. T.C. Durant, Mrs. Horace Green, Mrs. George W. Hatch, Mrs. G.G. Howland, Mrs. Ogden Hoffman, Mrs. R.L. Kennedy, Mrs. Joseph Lawrence, Mrs. Jas. X. McLanahan, Mrs. Thomas Mason, Mrs. J.C. Miner, Mrs. L.P. Morton, Mrs. Elisha Peck, Mrs. Pickersgill, Mrs. A.H. Stevens, Mrs. Horace Webster, Mrs. E.D. abstract: University Examinations in London
snippet: University Examinations in London
lead_paragraph: The English public has been struck with surprise, by the recent presentation of ninety female competitors for the new popular University Examinations in London. These examinations are designed to raise the educational standard of the classes outside of the Universities, by applying to them University-tests, or examinations, and certain "Degrees" and "Honors" are given for proficiency in common branches of Education, as judged o[???] by accomplished scholars. Hitherto, they have been open only to the young men and lads of the middle classes; now, in that practical method of progress which characterizes England, the examiners have quietly opened them to women. Nothing has been said about "Woman's Rights," no public meetings have been held to advocate the female right to vote or to hold office; but by a simple and just educational measure, more has been practically accomplished for the elevation of women, than has been done here by all the frothy public meetings of the last half century.

abstract: For months, if not for years past, the Reading Railroad Company has suffered considerable loss in the matter of coal stolen from their cars, both at Richmond and near the Fairmount Park. Owing to the large business transacted by the Company. It is found necessary to leave cars containing coal standing upon the tracks, and night after night these cars ...
lead_paragraph: For months, if not for years past, the Reading Railroad Company has suffered considerable loss in the matter of coal stolen from their cars, both at Richmond and near the Fairmount Park. Owing to the large business transacted by the Company. It is found necessary to leave cars containing coal standing upon the tracks, and night after night these cars have been visited by men and women and boys and girls, who have helped themselves liberally to the coal. According to the sworn statement of Mr. HILLES, one of the officers of the Company, this coal is in transit, and for all deficiencies the Company is required to pay. The loss by stealing has averaged from $1,500 to $2,000 per month.

abstract: Dispatches from Cumberland, Md., give full details of the late attempted raid in West Virginia by the rebels under Gen. EARLY. Their force was three brigades of cavalry, with which they were to attempt to cut the Baltimore Railroad, between Martinsburgh and New-Creek, and capture such forces as were found on the route. But they learned that our force ...
lead_paragraph: Dispatches from Cumberland, Md., give full details of the late attempted raid in West Virginia by the rebels under Gen. EARLY. Their force was three brigades of cavalry, with which they were to attempt to cut the Baltimore Railroad, between Martinsburgh and New-Creek, and capture such forces as were found on the route. But they learned that our force at Martinsburgh were strong, and under AVERILL and they abandoned the attempt. They then set off to capture a small garrison at Petersburgh, Hardy county, and failed in that, after which they beat a retreat. Our cavalry pursued some distance, and picked up many stragglers and deserters, who gladly take the oath, and are released.

abstract: As a State Reproach
snippet: As a State Reproach
lead_paragraph: The annual messages of the Governors of Pennsylvania, Ohio, Massachusetts and the other States whose Legislatures convene in the beginning of the year, are coming to hand, all glowing with enthusiasm for the National cause, all eloquent with generous sentiment, high counsel and earnest appeal. The contrast they present in language and in spirit to the carping, churlish, cold, narrow, malignant, soulless production which has just come from Gov. SEYMOUR, is enough to make every citizen of this State hang his head for shame. What has New-York done that it should be reserved for her alone, of all the loyal States, to have her archives contaminated with these records of official infamy? Why should that State which carries the proudest of all names, the "Empire State," be singled out for this denunciation? Why should the escutcheon, which bears the loftiest of all devices, "Excelsior," be the one of all to incur this odious stain?

abstract: Snow Storm over Northwestern States
snippet: Snow Storm over Northwestern States
lead_paragraph: The Western journals come to us filled with accounts of the terrible storm of snow and wind which swept over the greater part of the Northwestern States on Thursday and Friday the last day of December and the first of January completely blockading travel by the railways, and causing immense suffering in city and country. There has been nothing approaching it in severity since the memorable Winter of 1855. We take from the Chicago Times of Jan. 4 an account of the experiences of the passengers on a railway train, which was snowbound on the prairie:

abstract: The splendid little steamer Ella and Anna, which succeeded in capturing the stolen steamer Chesapeake, has been ordered to fit out for sea at once. The Navy Department has changed her name to the Malvern, and yesterday Capt. CRESSY, one of the most valuable officers in the volunteer navy, received or- ...
lead_paragraph: The splendid little steamer Ella and Anna, which succeeded in capturing the stolen steamer Chesapeake, has been ordered to fit out for sea at once. The Navy Department has changed her name to the Malvern, and yesterday Capt. CRESSY, one of the most valuable officers in the volunteer navy, received orders to proceed to Boston and command the vessel. Capt. CRESSY will probably leave in a few days, and takes with him the good wishes of everybody here. The Ella and Anna, although a purchased steamer, is exceedingly fast and well built. A proper armament is in course of preparation for her by the Ordnance Officer of the Navy-yard, and she will be ready to sail on important cruising business within two weeks. The vacancies in her crew will be filled by first-class men from the receiving ship Ohio, and everything done to make her efficient and useful.

abstract: Message to Legislature
snippet: Message to Legislature
lead_paragraph: I feel it to be my duty in this connection to call to your attention a subject which for some time past has greatly agitated and alarmed the people in several of the counties of the State, and caused many complaints and appeals to me for interposition by some of the best and most faithful of our citizens. About four months since, recruiting officers for the first time made their appearance among the slave population of the State, with the avowed purpose of enlisting in the military service all colored persons of the required age and condition who would present themselves. No orders from the headquarters of the army authorizing such a proceeding had been made known and no rules seemed to exist establishing any certain course of proceeding. The recruiting officer exercised apparently an arbitrary discretion, stripping some neighborhoods and leaving others untouched; taking frequently the slaves of owners whose loyalty had been never questioned, in some cases when these owners were themselves absent in the army or navy struggling against the enemy, and leaving those of others whose want or loyalty was equally notorious. They frequently took not only such as were fit for the service, but many others who were entirely unfit, and who, when brought to the rendezvous in another part of the State, were turned adrift and in most cases lost both to the Government and their owners.

abstract: On Thursday night last the house of RACHEL NEWFELT, No. 69 Watts-street, was entered by means of false keys and robbed of $200 in cash, $1,000 in United States five-twenty bonds, a gold watch and chain worth $200, a bank-book showing a deposit of $100 in the Chambers-street Savings Bank, and a ...
lead_paragraph: On Thursday night last the house of RACHEL NEWFELT, No. 69 Watts-street, was entered by means of false keys and robbed of $200 in cash, $1,000 in United States five-twenty bonds, a gold watch and chain worth $200, a bank-book showing a deposit of $100 in the Chambers-street Savings Bank, and a gold ring valued at $50. From all the indications, it appears there were three thieves engaged in this bold burglary. About 2 o'clock at night they drove up to the above residence, coolly fastened their horse to a post, went through an alley to the rear of the house, and entered the basement by means of keys prepared for the purpose. Thence they ascended to the sleeping apartments of Mrs. NEWFELT, and during her slumbers they abstracted the property above specified, all of which was contained in a small safe. The latter was placed in their wagon and taken away. Two or three blocks from the scene of the robbery, the horse and wagon were found a few hours after by the Police. No arrests of the thieves have yet been made. Capt. JOURDON, of the Sixth Precinct, with two or three men, is, however, actively engaged in working up the case, and it is believed that the villains will soon be brought to justice. Mr. NEWFELT, the husband of the victim, is connected with the army, and the most of the property stolen has been saved by him within the last two years.

lead_paragraph: -- An odd trial has taken place in which the plaintiff was M. ALEXANDRE DUHAS, the defendant M. LOPEZ, the latter having represented, at the Theatre Belleville, a play purporting to be by himself and the said M. DUMAS conjointly. The novelist has sued him for stating what is untrue and calculated to make his reputation cheap. The defendant "put in" the manuscript of the piece, signed, incontestably, by M. DUMAS. But here the matter by no means came to an end. As "countercheck,"it is now stated that the play is simply an exercise in translation from the German, made some years ago by M. DUMAS, the piece being "Die Abendestunde," of Kotzebue; and that the manuscript, little cared for and mislaid, had straggled somehow into the possession of M. LOPEZ, who has appropriated it in the obnoxious manner complained of.

abstract: the President's Plan--Tennessee
snippet: the President's Plan--Tennessee
lead_paragraph: It has been remarked ever since the beginning of the rebellion, that the true aspect and relations of it seemed to be better understood in France than in England. This may not have been so in fact, but at the first the liberal men of England did not make their position so prominent as they have recently done, while GASPARIN's "Uprising of a Great People," and similar works from France, fixed our attention more upon her. Perhaps it seemed the more remarkable to us that we should receive such sympathy from, men who were living under a Government which is hardly to be charged with having too quick a sympathy for liberty, rather than from England, which has always claimed to be an especial defender of freedom. Perhaps, in the stress of the circumstances which were pinching us, words of sympathy and appreciation sounded so grateful in our ears as to prevent us from giving a fair judgment as to the comparative merit of what was said. But even yet we cannot but feel that the appreciation which has been shown by a portion of the French people for the merits of the struggle, and the interests which were really involved in it, has been very remarkable.
headline: {'main': 'The French Liberals on our Cause.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The French Liberals on our Cause.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We have had frequent occasion, recently, for noticing the immense trade growing up in this City for supplying the Chinese waters with steamers for carrying on the local trade there. Many of our largest builders have been devoting almost their entire strength to this department.
lead_paragraph: We have had frequent occasion, recently, for noticing the immense trade growing up in this City for supplying the Chinese waters with steamers for carrying on the local trade there. Many of our largest builders have been devoting almost their entire strength to this department. Until recently, however, we were unaware of the difficulties attendant upon getting these vessels to their destination, arising mainly from the fact that most of them are built for river navigation, and not for the long sea voyage they are compelled to take. The following extract is from a letter written by an officer on board the steamer Vulcan, and it shows some of the dangers she encountered since she left here in November last. The Vulcan was built for Messrs. AYMAR & CO. of this City, by JOHN ENGLIS & SON, the well-known shipbuilders, and her machinery constructed by Mr. JOHN DILLON, of Rondout, New-York:

abstract: RETURN OF THE FIFTY-NINTH REGIMENT. -- Las evening the Fifty-ninth regiment, which left this City in the Fall of '61, returned to enjoy their thirty days' furlough. The men have reenlisted for the continuance of the war. The regiment at once marched to and quartered at the Park Barracks. The Fifty-ninth belongs to the Second Army corps, and has participated in no less than eight pitched battles besides a number of skirmishes. The principal engagements were at Malvern Hill, the Second Bull Run, South Mountain, Antietam, Fredericksburgh, (both battles.) Gettysburgh, and Bristooe Station. At the battle of Antietam the regiment lost the commander, Lieut.-Col. STETSON, five Captains, three Lieutenants, and five officers wounded. Of the rank and file out of 360 who entered into the fight, 230 were killed and wounded. The men of the Fifty-ninth return with their battle flag4 which tell the tale of the hard service of the regiment more eloquently than words. Lieut.-Col. HORACE P. HUGG, who is in command, intends granting furlough to his soldiers to-day.

abstract: News from Mexico via Havana, mentions the occupation of Guanajuato by the French forces and their probable advance on Guadalajara. The report that DOBLADO had declared in favor of the intervention was denied. The indication that he would do so was simply a ruse to gain time. His troops were concentrating at Leon. The guerrillas are reported to have entirely disappeared from the high road between Orizaba and Vera Cruz.

abstract: At a late hour on Saturday night Capt. GREER, of the Third Precinct, arrested Mr. JOHN D. VERMEULE, who is a member of the firm of FRANCIS C. HALL & Co., crockery merchants, doing business at No. 282 Greenwich-street. Mr. VERMEULE is charged with having, on the night of the 12th ult., set fire to the store of the firm for the purpose of defrauding the Home, Harmony, National, New-Amsterdam, Humboldt and American Exchange Insurance Companies, in which they were insured to the amount of $16,000. The complainant in the case is Mr. HILL, one of the members of the firm, and from his affidavit, which is on file in the Tombs Police Court. It appears that the firm were very much embarrassed, pecuniarily, and that the insurance on their stock was nearly double the amount of property in the store. On the night of the fire Mr. VERMEULE was seen to go up stairs three times just previous to the closing of the store. Soon after all hands had left, a fire broke out on the third floor. The porter of the establishment testified, that on the afternoon preceding the fire, the scoused gave him a two gallon can and ordered him to have it filled with kerosene oil. The oil was procured cod used somewhere about the premises, as the can was found empty after the fire broke out. It further appeared in evidence that VERMEULE had for some time been appropriating the proceeds of sales, without making the proper entries in the books, and that immediately after the fire the latter desired Mr. HALL, the senior member of the firm to represent to the Insurance Companies that the amount of their stock was $14,000, whereas the fact was that the property of the concern did not exceed $8,000. The accused was taken before Justice DOWLIUG at the Tombs, where he was held in the sum of $5,600 to answer. Fire-Marshal BAKER is making an investigation of the case.

abstract: The German Opera has enjoyed the comparative success of one good house out of two. On Wednesday the attendance was excellent, sufficient to encourage visions of a bright and prosperous future. These were dispelled on the following night, (Friday,) when the lieges, for reasons best known to themselves, were anything but loyal.
lead_paragraph: The German Opera has enjoyed the comparative success of one good house out of two. On Wednesday the attendance was excellent, sufficient to encourage visions of a bright and prosperous future. These were dispelled on the following night, (Friday,) when the lieges, for reasons best known to themselves, were anything but loyal. "Faust" was performed on both occasions, and with a completeness of ensemble which could hardly be excelled. The fourth act of this work is represented with better effect by the Germans than by their predecessors, the Italians, owing perhaps to the cooperation of the Arion Society in the choruses, and the presence of a military band upon the stage. Germans, too, know how to make a show. Mr. CARL BERGMANN has conducted the orchestra, and will, we presume, continue to do so for some time. Mr. ANSCHUTZ has been in a very critical condition, but is now slowly mending. It is hardly likely, however, that he will be able to resume the baton for several weeks. To-night Mad. JOHANNSEN takes her benefit. BEETHOVEN's opera of "Fidelio" is the attraction -- a work which almost always attracts a fine audience. The company will be strengthened to-night by the addition of a new basso, Herr HERMAN, who makes his debut in the role of Rocco. Report speaks favorably of the gentleman's powers. On Wednesday BOILDIEU's opera of "La Dame Blanche" will be revived for the first time in many years. This will speedily give place to WAGNER's "Tannhauser," which is already in rehearsal, and will probably be brought out on Friday next. With these works the company will be able to keep up the excitement of the season, and let us hope to make it pecuniarily prosperous.

abstract: Proposition to Call Out a Million Men
snippet: Proposition to Call Out a Million Men
lead_paragraph: There are some people upon whom no amount of experience seems to produce the slightest impression, and Mr. HOWE, of Wisconsin, seems to be one of them. He introduced into the Senate, the other day, a bill worthy of Peter the Hermit, requesting the President to call out a "million of men," for ninety days' service, "to carry food and freedom to every captive held in rebel prisons, and to plant the flag of the United States upon every prison they occupy" -- the whole force to be commanded by Gen. GRANT. Of course we have no fear that this foolish bill will ever be passed, and we should not, therefore, think of devoting any space to commenting upon it, if it were not that there are all over the country a number of persons who have had, ever since the war began, down in the bottom of their souls, a lurking conviction that Richmond could be taken at once, and the rebellion overthrown, if a million or two of men and boys could be got to shoulder muskets and start southward, and who will be gratified at seeing their pet theory embodied in a preamble and four sections. The appearance of Mr. HOWE'S bill seems to afford a good opportunity for saying a few plain words to those enthusiasts on the subject of their hallucination.
headline: {'main': '"Onward to Richmond" Senator Howe\'s Proposition.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': '"Onward to Richmond" Senator Howe\'s Proposition.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: on Arkansas Affairs
snippet: on Arkansas Affairs
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. GANTT. lately an officer in the rebel army, but now staunch and loyal Union man, made a speech in Cincinnati, a few days since, on the Progress and prospects of the war, which we reprint in another column. He makes some statements well worthy of attention. He bears testimony to the excellent effect of the President's Emancipation Proclamation in weakening the rebellion and administers a very severe rebuke to the advocates of peace and Slavery in the North. He states a very striking fact in illustration of the change of sentiment in Arkansas in regard to the rebellion. One of the rebel regiments recently returned to that State from service in the field, numbering 800, among whom were some of the most respectable and influential citizens of the State. Gen. GANTT addressed them in favor of returning to the Union, and on taking a vote every man in the regiment voted in favor of it. There seems no reason to doubt that a very remarkable change has occurred in public sentiment in Arkansas, and that this State will speedily resume her position in the Union.

abstract: -- The Washington Star says that JOHN S. BARBOUR, a leading advocate of the rebel cause in Virginia, and a man of marked influence in that State, has recently declared that "there exists no hope of prolonging the rebellion beyond next Spring, its military strength having been completely exhausted in the late campaign," and that he expresses bitter regret for the part he took in bringing Virginia into her present deplorable condition. There are a good many prominent men in that State who will speedily come to share this opinion, if they do not already.

abstract: The steamship Columbia, from New-Orleans, Jan. 3, arrived yesterday. Our correspondence says that there were considerable movements in progress among the troops in the department, but they were not of a character to be made public.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Columbia, from New-Orleans, Jan. 3, arrived yesterday. Our correspondence says that there were considerable movements in progress among the troops in the department, but they were not of a character to be made public. It is quite likely, therefore, that the news brought last week, of an expedition having left, probably for Mobile, is correct. It was believed in New-Orleans that all the rebel troops which have been operating in Western Louisiana, supposed to number 20,000 men, were gathering in Central Texas, with the object of attacking the points along the coast now occupied by the Union troops. Preparations have been made by us to meet this threatened movement. Nearly all the regiments of the Nineteenth Army corps are reported to have reenlisted as veterans.

abstract: Gen. Gillmore's Attack
snippet: Gen. Gillmore's Attack
lead_paragraph: The country has ceased to look for the capture of Charleston, either by Gen. GILLMORE'S army or by the iron-clad navy, The many months that have passed since the last serious attempt by the monitors have brought with them many promises, and left behind them an equal number of disappointments; and those who anticipated that Gen. GILLMORE's reduction of Fort Wagner would instantly be followed by the seizure of Sumter's site, of Fort Moultrie, James Island, and all the works in the harbor, have waited in vain for the realization of their hopes. The navy has maintained a blockade of Charleston harbor that even the rebels must admit is effective, if not perfect; and our news has all along kept us informed that Gen. GILLMORE was from time to time training his guns upon the city, as well as "feeling" the state of matters along the important railroad line stretching between Charleston and Savannah. The recalling of these latter facts will remind those who fancy that our army and navy down there have been absolutely useless, that they, at least, are mistaken; for we do not doubt that the simple fact that Gen. GILLMORE has ceaselessly threatened the railroad line just mentioned, has held in the vicinity, and kept out of service elsewhere, a very large rebel force.

abstract: Thackeray, W. M., NEW-YORK TIMES Obituary
snippet: Thackeray, W. M., NEW-YORK TIMES Obituary
lead_paragraph: THACKERAY is dead. This startling announcement seemes to add an intenser chill to the inclemency of the season, as it strikes at the heart of so much that has delighted and refined the men of this generation, in a thousand sketches of life and character vivified by the pen of a man of consummate genius. Since SCOTT left the world, thirty-two years ago, the English reading public has not been called to mourn, such a loss; and if we would seek an earlier precedent, we must go back more than a century, to the day when prematurely worn out, at the age of forty- seven, the novelist FIELDING died en exile in search of health in Italy. FIELDING was perhaps a greater genius than THACKERAY, yet we have no impression of his being so lamented in that old England which lives to us, vital to this day in his pages as it does in no other man's writings, as doubtless THACKERAY will be sincerely mourned at this present time. The difference is in the two periods, their mind and character. We are softened now in comparison with that hard living age, when the feelings of men must have been somewhat blunted to endure the coarseness they did. There was a sense of humanity in FIELDING, but rarely such pathos of a gentle melancholy as is inwrought even in the satirical pages -- and some have thought they are all satirical -- of THACKERAY. The world has grown strangely sympathetic within this hundred years, and THACKERAY's writings represent the change.

abstract: MORE, ARRESTS OF ALLEGED BLOCKADE SPECULATORS, Yesterday, ROBERT J. TOPPLIS, EDWARD UNDEBHILL and W. E. DOTY, supposed to be confederates of J.L. lead_paragraph: MORE, ARRESTS OF ALLEGED BLOCKADE SPECULATORS. -- Yesterday, ROBERT J. TOPPLIS, EDWARD UNDEBHILL and W. E. DOTY, supposed to be confederates of J.L. OLMSTEAD, of Yonkers, were taken into custody. TOPPLIS is charged with having furnished goods to the rebels, and UNDERPHILL, who is reported to be wealthy, is accused of furnishing the money with which the goods were purchased. It is stated that papers were found on OLMSTEAD, whose arrest was reported last Saturday, which implicate him in transactions connected with the blockade-running vessels Habano, Ella, Alice and Cuba. At the time he was taken into custody; orders were found on his person for various kinds of merchandize, including army blankets, drugs, army shoes, &c. There has been no hearing as yet in the above cases.

abstract: ENGLISH OPERA IN BROOKLYN. Mr. GABRIEL HARRISON, manager of the Park Theatre, has favored the people of Brooklyn with a week of English Opera, and the enterprise has resulted in success. On each night the beautiful house has been crowded with a brilliant and fashionable audience, whose gratification was insured by a rendition all but complete. Mme. BORCHARD ae Arline, the "Bohemian Girl," fully sustained the artistic requirements of the
lead_paragraph: ENGLISH OPERA IN BROOKLYN. -- Mr. GABRIEL HARRISON, manager of the Park Theatre, has favored the people of Brooklyn with a week of English Opera, and the enterprise has resulted in success. On each night the beautiful house has been crowded with a brilliant and fashionable audience, whose gratification was insured by a rendition all but complete. Mme. BORCHARD ae Arline, the "Bohemian Girl," fully sustained the artistic requirements of the role, while Messrs. CASTLE and CAMPBELL are as good and as popular in opera as they are in the concert-room. Mr. HARRISON is subject to the usual drawbacks of metropolitan managers. His rent is excessive, his orchestra insolently exacting, and his difficulties in filling the subordinate rotes are measured by the necessities of the cast. Last night he produced the "Bohemian Girl" for the last time but one in Brooklyn. The cast, with the single and fearful exception of Miss SHAW as the Queen, being charmingly excellent.

lead_paragraph: The prompt action of the Navy Department in summarily dismissing parties from the Navy-yard upon malfeasance, as proven before a Courtmartial, has caused other misconduct to leak out. A most extraordinary occurrence took place yesterday, On the 28th ultimo it was stated, in particularizing the oppression practiced on workmen at the Navy-yard, that a system of peculation was going on in the clerical branch of the Engineer's Department, by which the Government was swindled out of considerable money. This consisted in adding overtime and other charges to the accounts of the Engineer, after they were signed by him. Orders to remove the accused, it is said, were received from Secretary WELLES. Being well versed in the business of the office, however, it was determined to keep them for some time until those engaged in their stead could be broken into the work. Yesterday, however, all the clerks on whom the chief business of the office rested, left without any notice whatever, leaving the Engineer-in-Chief to get along as best he could with his business and accounts.

abstract: -- A young man named WM. G. KETCHAM, son of Mr. E. KETCHAM, proprietor of a livery stable in Love-lane, died at DURLAND's hotel, in Jamaica, on Sunday evening, in consequence of the cold. He had been driving a party to Hempstead, where they took supper. On the return he became stupefied, and the lines were taken by some one of the party. On arriving at the hotel, KETCHAM was taken into the bar-room, and although every effort was made to resuscitate him, he expired in about one hour thereafter. The deceased leaves a wife, but no children.
lead_paragraph: -- A young man named WM. G. KETCHAM, son of Mr. E. abstract: An Interesting trial of skill through the medium of the electric telegraph was initiated last evening between an association of amateurs holding their meetings at No. 189 Bowery, New-York, and known as the "Paulsen Chess Club," and the Chess Club of Philadelphia. On the present occasion the Philadelphians are represented by three of their ablest players, Messrs. WHITEMAN, KEICHELN and THOMAS, and the New-Yorkers by Messrs. BENZINGEE, JOHNSTON and CHEMIER. The preliminaries having been agreed upon and New-York having won the "toss" for first move, their Committee assembled at the office of the People's Telegraph, No. 21 Wall-street, where the Philadelphia players were represented by Mr. MYBON J. HAZELTINE as umpire, at 7 o'clock precisely. The latter gentlemen also met in consultation at the Philadelphia terminus, Mr. S.W. WALKER acting as umpire in behalf of the Paulsen Club. A dispatch having arrived expressing the readiness of the Philadelphians to commence play, "1 P to K 4" was sent forward as the first move for New-York. "1 P to K 4" was instantly returned from Philadelphia, when the game progressed in the following manner. We should premise, by the way, that a special stipulation was introduced into the agreement providing that fifteen minutes should be the extreme limit permitted for the consideration of any one move:

abstract: Four men named JOHN CHAPIN, WM. DIXON, WM. SPENCER, and GEORGE WALWORTH were arrested, late on Sunday night, by the Fifteenth Precinct Police, on the charge of swindling a Mr. JOHN JACOBS, of No. 110 McDougal-street, out of the sum of $170, by fraudulent means well known to gamblers. The offence is alleged to have been committed at No. 683 Broadway, in a house kept by a man named TALLMAN. The officers also seized all the gambling implements which they could find on the premises. The proprietor made his escape through a rear door when he learned that the officers were paying him a visit. The accused were taken before Justice LEDWITH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, by whom they were discharged, the testimony being insufficient to hold them.

abstract: Shortly after 11 o'clock last night,the police of the Second Precinct discovered smoke issuing from the basement of No. 55 Beekman-street. The alarm was at once given, but before the water could be got on the fire it was discovered that the flame and smoke were so great on the Ann-street side of the block, that it was with difficulty the hose could be brought to bear upon it.

abstract: Half an hour's ride by the Fifth-avenue cars from Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn, will bring one to the Washington Pond, where the first Grand Skating Carnival of this season came off yesterday afternoon and evening. This is also the first display of the kind that has been given for two years. Pains and labor were secondary considerations in the primary object of fitting up this beautiful pond with all the
lead_paragraph: Half an hour's ride by the Fifth-avenue cars from Fulton Ferry, Brooklyn, will bring one to the Washington Pond, where the first Grand Skating Carnival of this season came off yesterday afternoon and evening. This is also the first display of the kind that has been given for two years. Pains and labor were secondary considerations in the primary object of fitting up this beautiful pond with all the necessary conveniences tending to make it an attractive and comfortable spot for the lovers of that healthful and enlivening exercise. The area of the pond is eleven acres, and is so arranged on the sides by embankments, etc., that there is no difficulty presented in lighting it up on the darkest nights. The old house which is situated at the entrance, is a relic of Revolutionary fame, it having been used by WASHINGTON as his headquarters during the battles that were fought in that vicinity. It was built in the year 1699, and is consequently one hundred and sixty-four years old. Some of the old window lights, which are easily discernible, are still in the sash of one of the windows.

abstract: The greatest progress which the country is now making in the suppression of the rebellion, is the general, almost unanimous, reenlistment of the veterans of the service, which is now taking place. We may say it is the literal salvation of our armies, and that it is worth more to us than would be an important victory. Viewed in all its aspects, it is the
lead_paragraph: The greatest progress which the country is now making in the suppression of the rebellion, is the general, almost unanimous, reenlistment of the veterans of the service, which is now taking place. We may say it is the literal salvation of our armies, and that it is worth more to us than would be an important victory. Viewed in all its aspects, it is the wisest, most successful and strongest feature which has been developed in the conduct of the war. Not alone in view of the numbers of men which it will continue in the service, but in the cheering moral' effect it is having on the country; in the rapid promotion of enlistments of fresh volunteers; in the renewed and steadfast faith it engenders in the minds of the people, and in the depressing effect it must have on the minds of the struggling rebels, who are watching with intense eagerness every development of the military situation that brings either hope or discouragement.

abstract: The stock of Messrs. BULKLEY & Co., which is a total loss, was valued at $70,000. The firm are insured for $5,000 in each of the following Companies: Humboldt, Standard, Commerce, Market, Importers' and Traders', Firemen's Trust, Hartford, Jefferson, Niagara, Commercial, Firemen's and Brevoort; also, for $2,000 each in the Mechanics', Goodhue and Clinton Insurance Companies; and for $2,500 in the Hope Insurance Company. The building No. 55 Beekman-street was owned by the Wyman estate. The estimated loss thereon is about $20,000. It was fully insured in City Companies. No. 53, occupied by Messrs. LAMSON, GOODNOW & Co., was damaged to the extent of $8,000. The firm are insured for $5,000 each in the Continental, Resolute. Home, and Standard Insurance Companies of this City; for $10,000 in the Washington Insurance Company, of Providence, R.I.; $6,000 in the Jefferson Insurance Company; $5,000 each in the American, Manufacturers', Elliott, North American, Merchants and National Insurance Companies, of Boston; $5,000 in the Norwich Insurance Company, of Norwich, Conn., and $5,000 in the Franklin Insurance Company, of Philadelphia. The building is fully insured in City Companies.
