abstract: The Board of Supervisors having recently leased Palace Garden site for military uses, yesterday directed their Committee on Armories and Drill-rooms to inclose it and roof it in, that it may be used for drill purposes. The officers of the Second regiment sent in a petition representing...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Supervisors having recently leased Palace Garden site for military uses, yesterday directed their Committee on Armories and Drill-rooms to inclose it and roof it in, that it may be used for drill purposes. The officers of the Second regiment sent in a petition representing that this State corps (the original of which enlisted in the Union army at the beginning of the war) are now fully reorganized, and asking for a continuance of the use of their drill-room, corner of Seventh-street and Hall-place, which was recently given over to the Fifty-fifth regiment, upon the supposition that the Second had no home organization. The request was granted by rescinding the resolution in regard to the permission granted to the Fifty-fifth regiment. The Comptroller transmitted additional riot claims, numbered from 2,318 to 2,346, inclusive, which were referred to the Special Committee investigating such claims. The President announced the appointment of the Standing Committees for the year, and the Board adjourned to Tuesday next at 3 o'clock P.M.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon the Sixty-sixth and Fifty-ninth regiments, that arrived from the Army of the Potomac on Sunday evening last, were reviewed in front of the City Hall by Mayor GUNTHER. Shortly before 2 o'clock, the regiments were formed in line, to await the arrival of the Seventy-first regiment New-York State Militia, which had kindly volunteered to act as an escort to our returned veterans. About 4 o'clock, Mayor GUNTHER, accompanied by the Board of Common Council, Gen. MORRIS, father of the Colonel of the Sixty-sixth regiment, Gen. SPICER, SHEPHERD KNAPP, and other well-known officers, appeared on the City Hall steps and saluted the heroes as they passed by. The regiments then deployed in to Broadway, and marched to the Fifth-avenue Hotel, where they were again reviewed by Maj.-Gen. BURNSIDE, the officers and men saluting him as they passed. After this ceremony, the men proceeded to the Park Barracks, where they were dismissed.

abstract: Grant's, Gen., Winter Operations
snippet: Grant's, Gen., Winter Operations
lead_paragraph: Whatever may take place in any other department, the public attention naturally centres, even at this quiet season, upon the great central department, the operations in which must again bisect the Confederacy and eventually end the rebellion. We presume no one expects any grand military operations to be undertaken in that region at present. But there is much to do -- indeed, there is much being done -- which is all-important and highly essential to future operations. Spring opens next month in the latitude of Chattanooga, and the month of March may admit of a movement.

abstract: In the Senate yesterday, but little business was done. The bill providing for the payment of bounties to March 1, was passed. In connection with this subject, Mr. FESSENDEN presented a letter from the secretary of the Treasury, stating that he would be unable to meet the heavy drafts required by this action within so short a time, and recommending increased taxation.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate yesterday, but little business was done. The bill providing for the payment of bounties to March 1, was passed. In connection with this subject, Mr. FESSENDEN presented a letter from the secretary of the Treasury, stating that he would be unable to meet the heavy drafts required by this action within so short a time, and recommending increased taxation. The Enrollment Act was taken up, and Mr. SUMNER's amendment providing that the amount of commutation shall be graduated according to each person's income, was after a long discussion, rejected. After an Executive session, the Senate adjourned.

abstract: Veteran Regiments in the City
snippet: Veteran Regiments in the City
lead_paragraph: -- We were glad to see that the two regiments of veteran volunteers which came to this City yesterday, from the Army of the Potomac, on a brief furlough, obtained a warmer welcome and a more proper recognition than had been accorded to the other veteran regiments which have been arriving during the last few weeks. One of our best City militia regiments volunteered to act as an escort; the Mayor and other of the City authorities stood on the City Hall steps, and smiled as the war-worn heroes passed by, and at the same spot an excellent brass band regaled their ears and touched their hearts with the sweet notes of "Home again." They received frequent welcome plaudits during their march up Broadway, and finally had the honor of a review by Gen. BURNSIDE. All this is certainly an improvement on the conduct of the City in previous similar cases. Only last week we witnessed the march through the City of the heroic fragment of a veteran regiment -- a regiment that had seen the hardest service for close upon three years -- that had fought in more battles than any regiment of troops on the globe, and every man of which had a hundred times confronted the storm of battle and the shafts of death in behalf of the beloved though tattered banner that was borne proudly at the head of their little column -- a regiment that was commanded by as noble a soldier as ever rode a horse, and of whom, it is told, the present Commander of the Army of the Potomac once remarked to one of our most famous Corps Commanders: "W_____, treat him well! for you and I will serve under him one of these days." We say we saw this regiment, headed by this officer, arrive in New-York, march past the City Hall, and through the streets, without receiving a sign of recognition or a cheer of welcome from the Municipal authorities, the military authorities, the militia or the patriotic citizens. It was unkind and chilling, and the returned veterans felt it. Not thus should a free country and a people who love their flag and institutions treat those who have dared everything in their defence, and who popose again to brave the dangers of the field.
headline: {'main': 'OUR VETERAN REGIMENTS IN THE CITY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUR VETERAN REGIMENTS IN THE CITY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Boston Traveller, of yesterday, says that letters have been received in that city from a Northern clergyman, who established himself in Charleston with his family but a short time before the rebellion. He gives touching details of the anguish and suffering of the inhabitants of the...
lead_paragraph: The Boston Traveller, of yesterday, says that letters have been received in that city from a Northern clergyman, who established himself in Charleston with his family but a short time before the rebellion. He gives touching details of the anguish and suffering of the inhabitants of the place, many of whom hope and pray for redemption even at the hands of the Yankees. In his opinion, the time is rapidly approaching when it will be found necessary to give up the city to save the people from absolute starvation. Of course, all that can, leave the place; but many have not the means, neither have they any place of refuge.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, about 1 o'clock, an explosion took place in the carriage factory of W.C. & J. DUNN, corner of Eighty-seventh-street and Third avenue. For some time past, the street opposite the factory has been open for the introduction of a sewer, and it is supposed that during the progress of the work the main gas pipe must have been broken off, and the gas having no outlet except through the sewer leading under the factory, found its way through that channel and lodged under the basement floor. The smell of gas had been noticed for some time, and yesterday the workmen were unable to work in that part of the shop. A large stove was setting in the blacksmith shop, and the gas having reached it, a terrible explosion took place, tearing up the floor, breaking out the windows, lifting the brick walls inside some twelve inches, and scattering everything in the wildest confusion about the shop. Heavy anvils, weighing several hundred pounds, were lifted up several feet and dashed to the floor. Carriage bodies were thrown against the beams and destroyed, and the workmen were hurled against the wall and injured. The wildest confusion existed for some time, and until the nature of the ease was made known, men attempted to jump from the windows. The alarm of fire was given, and hundreds flocked to the scene of the disaster. The fire was soon extinguished, and the sewer stopped up to prevent the gas rushing in. The building was owned by Messrs. ARCHER & GEORGE, and we were unable to ascertain their loss. Messrs. DUNN'S loss was about $500.

Heavy anvils, weighing several hundred pounds, were lifted up several feet and dashed to the floor. Carriage bodies were thrown against the beams and destroyed, and the workmen were hurled against the wall and injured. The wildest confusion existed for some time, and until the nature of the ease was made known, men attempted to jump from the windows. The alarm of fire was given, and hundreds flocked to the scene of the disaster. The fire was soon extinguished, and the sewer stopped up to prevent the gas rushing in. The building was owned by Messrs. ARCHER & GEORGE, and we were unable to ascertain their loss. Messrs. DUNN'S loss was about $500.

abstract: NIBLO's GARDEN. -- A new sensation play -- place Ireland, period 1821 -- was produced here last evening. It is called the "Connie Soogah, or the Jolly Peddler," and is from the pen of Mr. CHARLES GAYLER, a gentleman who has written better things -- and worse. The dramatist who writes for "stars," has to bring his invention down to the common-place necessity of constantly keeping those "stars" before the audience. It is for this and for no purpose of art, that he is employed. Mystery, the great element of all fiction, is therefore denied to him. In this piece -- which is quick in its action, and good of its kind -- the public anxiety is always relieved by the Irish hero. If a secret is being told, he is in waiting -- round the corner or in a closet -- to hear it; if a danger threatens, he is there to avert it. The scoundrel of the piece is allowed a sufficient amount of rope, but we know from the beginning that Paddy is at the other end and will surely haul him up. The interest of the piece is consequently not so much in the thing which we know will be done, but in the way it is done; an interest dependent on quick action, stirring tableaux, and good scenery. These atoms of a rather cheap whole are conscientiously attended to by Mr. WHEATLEY, who, whether he is dealing with mediocrity or merit, never forgets his responsibility as a manager. The tableaux are vivid; the scenery thoroughly admirable. The "Giant's Causeway" scene of the second act is one of the best things ever seen even at this house. As to the statement that "the production of this piece marks a new era in the history of the Irish drama," we can only express our regret that it is not so; and an additional regret that a responsible management should lend its name to such a statement. The "Connie Soogah" is nothing but a "star" piece; very good for those who are fond of seeing Mr. and Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS; very poor for those who are interested in broader mediums of public amusement. In a sentence, the piece is capital for the country, and capital for those who like to see country actors in the metropolis.

abstract: Slavery and the Opposition
snippet: Slavery and the Opposition
lead_paragraph: Gen. GANTT, of Arkansas, formerly of the rebel army, but now a thorough Union man, declared, in his speech at Cincinnati, that the people of Arkansas "turn from Slavery with loathing indescribable," and with great indignation adverted to the fact that "while we who are so much interested pray for deliverance from this curse, there is a sneaking party in the North who would force us to keep the curse with us." It is indeed astonishing that men in the North, who never saw a slave, and who have not a dollar's worth of interest in the institution, are so much more concerned for the fate of Slavery than they in whose social system it had closely interwoven itself, and who had property in it to the extent of hundreds of millions.

abstract: PRESENTATION TO EX-ALDERMAN PETER MITGHELL. Last evening the friends of Ex-Alderman PETER MITCHELL of the Eighth District, met at Lindhelm's Hotel, No. 415 Grand-street, for the purpose of presenting Mr. MITCHELL with a token of their kind regard for him as a citizen and as a friend.
lead_paragraph: PRESENTATION TO EX-ALDERMAN PETER MITGHELL. -- Last evening the friends of Ex-Alderman PETER MITCHELL of the Eighth District, met at Lindhelm's Hotel, No. 415 Grand-street, for the purpose of presenting Mr. MITCHELL with a token of their kind regard for him as a citizen and as a friend. The presentation speech was made by Mr. JOHN GRYERSON in a very neat and appropriate manner, and the Ex-Alderman replied with much feeling. The testimonial was a most beautiful diamond ring, and cost $[???]80. On the inside is the following inscription: "Presented to Alderman MIT[???]ELL by his friends, Jan. 13, 1864." After the presentation the company sat down to a well-spread table, whereat all did full justice. The affair passed off in a most agreeable and happy manner.

abstract: It is a refreshing fact that there is a public officer in the City who has awakened, after sleeping among them for years, to extravagances in all or any of the City Departments. Mr. THOMAS N. CARR, Superintendent of Sanitary Inspection under Mr. DELEVAN, and who was and is retained by Mr. BOOLE, has suddenly been aroused to the fact, after about four years' connection with the Inspector's Department, that there has been gross malfeasance and great extravagance therein. More credit would have been given to his statement had he made it earlier, and more respect to him. Possibly, if not probably, ambitious ideas in connection with anticipated legislative action is what has caused Mr. CARR to unearth that among which he has so long been buried. Still, "State's evidence" is received in courts, and why not be by the public? It is understood that Mr. BOOLE will respond to the charges made; if he can do so successfully, which many doubt, he will relieve a department which has, long ere his control of it, been covered with suspicion, and clear his own skirts of a reproach which, if unrefuted, will cling to him.

abstract: A dispatch to the Philadelphia Inquirer, dated at Chattanooga on Tuesday, says that a severe cavalry fight occurred on Sunday last, at a place called Strawberry Plains, 35 miles northeast of Knoxville, in which the enemy suffered severely.
lead_paragraph: A dispatch to the Philadelphia Inquirer, dated at Chattanooga on Tuesday, says that a severe cavalry fight occurred on Sunday last, at a place called Strawberry Plains, 35 miles northeast of Knoxville, in which the enemy suffered severely. The same dispatch announces that LONGSTREET has been heavily reinforced from the armies of LEE and JOHNSTON, and this affair indicates either that the rebel General intends to advance upon Knoxville, or to annoy our forces by cavalry dashes. The opposing pickets are reported to be fronting each other at Blair's Cross Roads, and LONGSTREET's Headquarters are at Red Bridge. His position is said to be a splendid one. FORREST's cavalry force is said to have been badly handled lately in East and Middle Tennessee, but most of the command managed to escape. JOHNSTON shows a strong front at Tunnel Hill and Dalton.

abstract: The Halifax Citizen says that BRAINE, who captured the Chesapeake swindled numerous citizens in Halifax last Summer out of sums ranging from 25 shillings to $25, by pretending to be a publisher of Montreal, and about to issue a mercantile and statistical work of Canada and the Provinces, for which he solicited subscriptions and advertisements. The work has not yet appeared, and the money doubtless helped to fit out his piratical expedition. BRAINE is still skulking somewhere in the Provinces.

abstract: What is He About
snippet: What is He About
lead_paragraph: Though the news from East Tennessee may not be strictly reliable, yet there is undoubtedly sufficient truth in it to give affairs in that vicinity an important and interesting aspect. We shall not be surprised at a resumption of offensive movements on the part of LONGSTREET's force, so far as may be possible. Three weeks ago, in these columns, we alluded to the great facility with which LONGSTREET could be reinforced from LEE. At that time it was announced, through rebel sources, that all the small commands which had been prowling and hovering around BURNSIDE's advance, on the Virginia and North Carolina border, had effected a junction with LONGSTREET. Once with his rear upon a line of communication with Richmond, LONGSTREET could be comparatively well supplied -- as well as LEE's army is. AVERILL's raid, though destroying immense quantities of stores, which the rebels could ill afford to lose, only interrupted railroad communication for about a week. The President of the road published a card to this effect in the Richmond papers about a week after AVERILL left Salem. There is really no reason, then, why LONGSTREET may not have received men as well as supplies. LEE, counting, as well he might, upon the inactivity of the Army of the Potomac, could safely spare him probably twenty thousand men, giving him, with his former force, an army fully fifty thousand strong.

abstract: In the Senate, Mr. WILSON reported back the bill authorizing another Assistant Secretary of War. Mr. BUCKALEW, of Pennsylvania, offered a resolution that five thousand copiew of Gen. McCLELLAN'S report be printed for the use of the Senate.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, Mr. WILSON reported back the bill authorizing another Assistant Secretary of War. Mr. BUCKALEW, of Pennsylvania, offered a resolution that five thousand copiew of Gen. McCLELLAN'S report be printed for the use of the Senate. Mr. LANE, of Kansas, introduced a bill fixing the price of gold, providing that it shall not be sold at a price higher than the price paid for United States six per cent. bonds, at the regular market in New-York, except for exportation by merchants to pay debts. The resolution for the expulsion of Senator DAVIS, of Kentucky, was then taken up, and the remainder of the session was occupied in speeches by Messrs. WILSON and DAVIS, which are reported at considerable length in our dispatches.

abstract: The Park Barracks are in a most wretched condition; they are filthy in the extreme and utterly unfit for the habitation of any human being. Coals and wood are strewn upon the floor, which looks as though it had not been washed since the erection of the barracks, and the dining tables are equally innocent of soap and water.
lead_paragraph: The Park Barracks are in a most wretched condition; they are filthy in the extreme and utterly unfit for the habitation of any human being. Coals and wood are strewn upon the floor, which looks as though it had not been washed since the erection of the barracks, and the dining tables are equally innocent of soap and water. Many of the windows are broken, and the whole place wears the appearance of an old dilapidated barn, but not by any means smelling as sweet. The bunks, made of rough boards, are dirty beyond description; the walls are soiled and filthy; the place of convenience for the men is horribly disgusting, and altogether the place is a nasty, dirty, noisome hole.

abstract: Reenlistments and Army of Potomac
snippet: Reenlistments and Army of Potomac
lead_paragraph: Among all our armies none will occupy a prouder place when the history of the war shall be written than the Army of the Potomac. Besides a picked rebel army with chosen leaders, it has been forced to contend against the procrastinating incompetency or the rash zeal of its own officers, yet it has remained firm and steadfast amid all disasters, and now it is making a crowning exhibition of heroic patriotism, which the people, whom it represents and serves, can never forget. In reply to the appeals of the Government it is stated that at least three-fourths, and perhaps even a larger proportion of the veterans who have dug under MCCLELLAN, and fought and marched under POPE, BURNSIDE, HOOKER and MEADE, are reenlisting for another three years' term of service, and hardly a day passes that we do not have new proof of the fact in large accessions to the scores of bronzed and hardy soldiers who throng our streets.
headline: {'main': 'The Army of the Potomac and Re-enlistments.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Army of the Potomac and Re-enlistments.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The final examination in the case of the men charged with the murder of the mate of the ship Neptune, was held yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock, and the Commissioner discharged the seven remaining men who had been arrested. It was impossible to get any evidence against these men that would tend to charge them with the crime, and no one else has as yet been arrested or come under suspicion of being concerned in it. The murderers, therefore, whoever they may be, are still at large.
lead_paragraph: The final examination in the case of the men charged with the murder of the mate of the ship Neptune, was held yesterday afternoon at 2 o'clock, and the Commissioner discharged the seven remaining men who had been arrested. It was impossible to get any evidence against these men that would tend to charge them with the crime, and no one else has as yet been arrested or come under suspicion of being concerned in it. The murderers, therefore, whoever they may be, are still at large.

abstract: Bill Prohibiting Chain Bridges
snippet: Bill Prohibiting Chain Bridges
lead_paragraph: -A bill prohibiting the use of chain or suspension bridges by ferry companies, has been introduced into the Assembly, and if it is sufficiently stringent in its provisions we trust that it will speedily become a law. The lives of hundreds, and in some instances of thousands of those doing business in this City, are daily put in jeopardy by exposure to the increasing risks of accident to structures of this description, and no legislation can be too prompt or decisive which shall effectually prevent the possibility of some startling catastrophe by compelling the substitution of floating for these suspension bridges. In some instances we are aware that those who have the control of ferries equipped with these chain-bridges represent that the water in the slips is so shallow that the change would be impracticable, but a dredging machine would certainly remove this obstacle in a very short time.

abstract: Those who are anxious to know when the Army of the Potomac will advance, and when the war is likely to come to a close, may be interested in knowing Gen. MEADE's opinion on these points. He gave it in the course of two little speeches he made in Philadelphia on Tuesday last. In regard to the resumption of active work by the Army of the Potomac, he said: "We are making every effort to improve the present, and, as soon as the weather moderates and the season will allow, active operations will be commenced anew, and in earnest." As to the time when the war ought to close, he expressed himself thus: "The war must be ended by hard fighting, and it becomes every man, woman and child to work for the increase of our armies in the field, and when that is done I trust that next Summer will come to us with peace restored to the land, and happiness, contentment and prosperity pervading the entire country."

abstract: The carpenters' work on the Dunderberg, inside and out is finished that is, comparatively little remains to be done; odd jobs here and there not being taken into account. The engine kelsons are all laid, and massive ones they are too; the coal bunker and bulkhead surrounding the boiler compartment are also in place; and so far as the carpenters are concerned, we presume the vessel might be launched in a week.
lead_paragraph: The carpenters' work on the Dunderberg, inside and out is finished that is, comparatively little remains to be done; odd jobs here and there not being taken into account. The engine kelsons are all laid, and massive ones they are too; the coal bunker and bulkhead surrounding the boiler compartment are also in place; and so far as the carpenters are concerned, we presume the vessel might be launched in a week. The below-water-mark plates are beings fixed on the sides, a layer of the sheathing paper being placed between the plates and timber. The plates themselves are being laid vertically, not horizontally, as usually, and are four and a-half inches thick in the middle, tapering to three and three and a-half inches at the extreme ends.

abstract: Campaign--How a Lie Travels
snippet: Campaign--How a Lie Travels
lead_paragraph: -Not long since a clergyman named HALL, from New-Hampshire, said to be a member of the Christian Commission, visited the Army of the Potomac and had an interview with Gen. MEADE. The Rev. Mr. HALL, like many other people, was curious to know why Gen. MEADE's last campaign failed in its results. So he asked the General to tell him, which he did briefly, saying, among other things, "One of my generals failed me." Mr. HALL sent the particulars of this interview back to New-Hampshire, where, of course, they were printed in some country paper. To Gen. MEADE's statement in reference to the General who failed, the Rev. Mr. HALL added in his own language, "this General was Gen. FRENCH, who was probably too drunk to know or do his duty." But this was so inserted as to make it appear that Gen. MEADE had said it, and now we see the statement traveling over the country quoted as Gen. MEADE's own remarks. Thus, through the morbid curiosity of a citizen, who could accomplish no possible good by the publication of such a story, a lie is put into Gen. MEADE's mouth, and a probable calumny uttered against Gen. FRENCH, and both set upon their travels, with little chance of their being thoroughly contradicted. We send this after them, though feeling the truth of the old adage, that "a lie will travel a thousand miles while truth is putting on her boots."
headline: {'main': 'HOW A LIE TRAVELS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'HOW A LIE TRAVELS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Foreign Criticisms of
snippet: Foreign Criticisms of
lead_paragraph: There have been frequent complaints made against the proceedings of our prize Courts, both here and in Europe. The complaints on this side of the water have been mainly directed to the practical working of the Courts and the officials, and in these we have sometimes been compelled to join. The complaints of our sailors and others as to the custody and disposition of prize properly, and the expenses attending prize proceedings in this port, may have some foundation. But when there come to us from abroad complaints which attack the principles of law laid down by our Courts, misstate the facts of the cases, or attribute to the Judges views which they have never expressed, and then make these misstatements the ground of attacks upon them, the case is quite different. The reputation of our Courts and of their decisions, as correct exponents of prize law, is too valuable to be suffered thus groundlessly to be assailed. An article from the Memorial Diplomatique, (Paris,) extracts from which we published a day or two since, is of the character indicated.
headline: {'main': 'Foreign Criticisms on our Prize Courts', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Foreign Criticisms on our Prize Courts', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In honor of Capt. EDWARD G. LOTT, commander of the Cunard steamship Persia, who is about to complete his three hundredth passage across the ocean, and who, during the period of this arduous service has secured the esteem and respect of the traveling public, by his skill as a seaman, and by his urbane attention to all under his care, a brilliant party of about 100 ladies and gentlemen assembled on Monday evening at dinner at Delmonico's, in the Fifth-avenue. The occasion was one of peculiar interest, and was attended by many of our most prominent citizens.

abstract: on the Mission of the War
snippet: on the Mission of the War
lead_paragraph: Last evening Mr. FREDERICK DOUGLASS addressed a very large and brilliant assemblage in the hall of the Cooper Institute, on the "Mission of the War." The lecture was in behalf of the Woman's Loyal League. Mr. WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT who was announced as intending to preside, was called to the bedside of a dying relative, and Mr. OLIVER JOHNSON, Editor of the Anti-Slavery Standard, filled his place. Mr. DOUGLASS, on being introduced, remarked that men on all sides tell us that Slavery is dead; that it expired as the first shot was fired from Sumter. He was not so confident He looked facts sternly in the face, and saw in the future no miraculous abolition of Slavery. This war is a great national opportunity, which may be improved to a national salvation, or neglected to a national ruin. Vain the might of armies, vain the strength of armaments, if the Government fails to observe those principles of justice and liberty at bottom of the controversy. We are in the salutary school of affliction. If it can teach this great nation to respect those great principles toward a long neglected and cruelly crushed race, we are in a fair way for amendment, but, if this teacher is unheeded, whose lessons are burned into us by blood and fire, and thundered in our ears by the roar of a thousand battles, we shall be a warning to other nations to shun our cowardly example. We had seen in 1848 the sublimest revolution the world had yet experienced. It was regarded as the death of kingcraft. In the twinkling of an eye the powers of despotism rallied, and the hopes of democratic liberty were blasted in the moment of their bloom. Grave liabilities may also yet hang over our present struggle against the slave power of this country. The ladies of the Loyal League were to be thanked for keeping the question before the public. We are not yet out of danger. We were once informed by a hitherto sagacious political prophet, that the war would end in ninety days, yet it still rears its head in its third year, alone among rebellions, as a solitary and ghastly horror, never yet conjured among nations, drawing inspiration from a system, haggard, fiendish, and too indecent even to be mentioned in full. It has strewn our land with two hundred thousand graves, and filled it with mere stumps of men, destroyed property beyond the most exaggerated calculation, and piled up a debt heavier than a mountain of gold to be paid by our children; weakened our friends, encouraged our enemies, -- and for what? For Slavery -- that hell-black enormity that the people of this country have not even yet comprehended. Mr. DOUGLASS, after sketching the origin of the war, observed that this rebellion was enough for the lifetime of any one nation, even should it cover a thousand years, and it should be the voice of every patriot that whether the work cost much or cost little, it should be done thoroughly, [applause,] that it may be the last rebellion ever to curse American soil. The longer the war the better, if need be so, if it succeeds in abolishing the internal system of American Slavery. Say not that this comes from a negro who has no interest in the Union. I feel the deepest sympathy with it. I am an American, [applause,] and with many others participate in the deep privations of the moment. There are vacant places at my hearthstone, once filled by beloved sons, enlisted for the war, whom I live in hopes of seeing return. In this struggle we are writing in the blood of tyrants, the words of eternal justice. The war seems long, but its slow progress is essential to our salvation. The disease, being severe, the remedy must be both powerful and tardy. We were, morally, very low before it commenced, so much so that our great physician. Dr. BUCHANAN, on being called, decided there was no hope for us. We had been literally drugged to death with Pro-Slavery Compromises. There has been nothing so necessary as the slow and steady progress of this war. Why, look how we have grown! (laughing significantly at the enormous audience gathered to hear him, a colored man.) This is not acceptable, evidently, to certain Peace Democrats. The speaker urged the necessity of clearly defining the war as an Abolition war, and not shirking the question, as only in that sense can it be successful. We may admit it to be a war for the Constitution and the Union, but only in the sense that the lesser are included in the greater. Abolition includes both the Constitution and the Union of these States. Slavery was too strong for either. It came to the Constitution and broke it -- to the Union, and sundered it. It must now, itself, be crushed. The Democratic party has had no other master than Slavery for forty years. It has made war and peace precisely according to its dictation. The Florida war even was commenced in the cause of Slavery. A few slaves ran from their civilized and religious masters, men of bibles and prayer-books, and took refuge with men of tomahawks. They found more of the milk of human kindness with Seminoles than with their pious and swindling masters.

abstract: -- The Senate nearly finished its consideration of the amendments to the Enrollment Act, yesterday. An effort by Senator HARRIS, of this State, to increase the commutation to four hundred dollars, failed. The commutation clause, as it stands in the original bill, was retained by the strong vote of 28 yeas to 11 nays. The amendments exempting clergymen and some other classes of non-combatants were adopted. As the bill now stands it is not materially changed. The chief features are the abolishment of the two separate classes, the exemption of clergymen, and the increased penalties and punishments for resistance to the enrollment or conscription, or any attempt at evasion of the same.

abstract: This long-expected ball took place last evening at the Academy of Music, and of the many brilliant ones the Guards have given, was, beyond dispute, the most brilliant. The Academy was chastely and elegantly ornamented for the occasion, with drapings of the Stars and Stripes; the stage handsomely inclosed, making, with the parquette, an ample ballroom. The company was large and select, the beauty in excess of that on any similar occasion, and the dressing rich and elegant. In all that tended to comfort and enjoyment, it was far in advance of the famous Russian Ball. That was a huge crowd, an indescribable confusion; this was crowd enough, truly, yet not to the excess which prevented locomotion or made dancing a farce. Dodworth's Military and Cotillon Band discoursed the music, and most admirably, while hundreds of canaries throughout the building -- a beautiful idea it was -- seemed to emulate the general excitement and enjoyment, and warbled their utmost, as though in rivalry of the more artistic strains.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, a resolution was adopted, directing the Street Commissioner to remove all the incumbrances from the carriage-way on Battery-place, between Broadway and West-street. Merchants on this and the adjoining streets have long used a large portion of Battery-place for mercantile
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, yesterday, a resolution was adopted, directing the Street Commissioner to remove all the incumbrances from the carriage-way on Battery-place, between Broadway and West-street. Merchants on this and the adjoining streets have long used a large portion of Battery-place for mercantile purposes, by temporary storage of bales, casks, &c. Mayor GUNTHER sent in two messages, one in reference to a report of Dr. SAYRE, Resident Physician, of the unhealthy condition of the Park Barracks, and the other accompanying the draft of an ordinance for the temporary improvement of the Broadway pavement, by directing the Croton Board to sprinkle coarse gravel and sand over it, at intervals, to diminish the risk of slipping. Both communications were referred. A resolution was adopted, requesting the Corporation Counsel to draft an ordinance for the better sanitary regulation of tenement houses, as suggested by the Mayor in his communication from the Commissioners of Health. The Standing Committees for the year were announced by the President, and the Board adjourned to Monday at 4 o'clock, P.M.

abstract: Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, a Grand Mass Requiem was held at St. Francis Xavier's Church, in Sixteenth-street, for the repose of the soul of the late Archbishop HUGHES.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, a Grand Mass Requiem was held at St. Francis Xavier's Church, in Sixteenth-street, for the repose of the soul of the late Archbishop HUGHES. Long before the hour appointed the church was densely crowded, mostly by ladies. The altar was draped with black cloth, embellished with the emblems of death. In the centre aisle, upon a raised platform, was a coffin covered with a black velvet pall, in centre of which was a large white cross. At the head and foot of the coffin were placed three wax tapers. The Celebrant was the Rev. JOSEPH LOYZANCE; Deacon, Rev. L. SCHNEIDER; Sub-Deacon, Rev. P. O'REILLY. The following were the priests present in the sanctuary: Very Rev. W. Starrs, administrator of the diocese, Rev. F. McMeiny, Very Rev. F. Sopranis, Rev. Michael Driscoll, Rev. Henry Hudson, Rev. H. DeLuynes, Rev. P. Miguard, Rev. P. Daubresse, Rev. John Cunningham, Rev. John McElroy, Rev. Thomas Flack, Rev. F. Charaux, and Rev. F. Durauquet. Father MOYLANS had charge of the arrangements.

abstract: The Telegraphic Chess match between the New-York Paulson Chess Club and that of Philadelphia, the proceedings in which we have already taken occasion to refer to, was brought to a conclusion last evening. Upon the whole, the game in question may be considered as a fine specimen of chess strategy; and, so far as the Philadelphia players are concerned, we think that it would be difficult to select from the records of match games a better illustration of patient defences and persevering, unwavering attack, than that which is exhibited by them on the present occasion, and which will be apparent on a critical examination of the score, which we give below:

abstract: Yesterday at noon Mr. THACKERAY was buried in the cemetary of Kensal-green. The day was so fine that, notwithstanding the distance from town, a vast concourse of his friends were enabled to surround his grave, and to pay him the last honor. Many hundreds must have been present of almost every rank and class. Only a very few of Mr. THACKERAY's most intimate friends were expressly invited to the funeral.

abstract: Senator Lane s Proposition; Proposition on Price of Gold
snippet: Senator Lane s Proposition; Proposition on Price of Gold
lead_paragraph: Senator LANE, of Kansas, proposes to make it an offence, punishable with fine and imprisonment, to sell gold at any higher price than is paid for the time being in the market for United States Bonds paying six per cent, interest in gold, except in the case of merchants buying gold for purchases abroad. It will be well for Mr. LANE to inform the Senate, before the bill is read a third time, how the law is to be enforced. It will have no moral sanction to aid it, for he will never succeed in persuading anybody of ordinary intelligence that it is morally wrong to pay the market price for one of the precious metals. And the sale of gold is a transaction which can always be carried out with sufficient secrecy to render it very difficult to procure evidence of its having been attended with any illegality. Neither of the parties to it will have any motive for informing against his confederate, except the reward, and this will hardly operate very powerfully upon anybody who is privy to many bargains of this nature. Those who have gold to sell, or seek to buy it, will not be at all likely to come before the world as common informers for the sake of two or three thousand dollars particularly, as, if they did, it would probably be the last sale of this commodity of which they would be allowed to become cognizant, by people who knew them. We shall say nothing of the inexpediency of committing offences which depend for their punishment upon the growth of a spirit of deceit, treachery and espionage among the people, though this has always been, in the eyes of all wise legislators, a consideration of the first importance. It is always highly demoralizing, and therefore highly impolitic, to seek to offer pecuniary inducements to rogues to betray others into the commission of acts which, though prohibited by law, are not condemned by the moral sense of the community; and this is precisely what Mr. LANE's bill, if it ever becomes a law, will do.

abstract: There were three arrivals from Europe yesterday, viz.: the Scotia and City of London at this port, and the Hibernia at Portland, bringing  news a week later than our precious advices. Our files and correspondence present us with an interesting budget.
lead_paragraph: There were three arrivals from Europe yesterday, viz.: the Scotia and City of London at this port, and the Hibernia at Portland, bringing news a week later than our precious advices. Our files and correspondence present us with an interesting budget. The correspondence between JEFF. DAVIS and the Pope has been published, in which the rebel chief asks the mediation of His Holiness in favor of peace. The Pope replies in words of Christian counsel, but does not compromise his neutrality by uttering a political sentiment. The pirate Florida was nearly ready to sail from Brest, and, although the gunboat Kearsage was in that harbor and would do everything to prevent her escape, there was little probability of her succeeding, in view of the application of the twenty-four hours' rule by the French Government. A letter from Cape Town, referring to the recent seizure by Capt. BALDWIN, of the United States steamer Vanderbilt of the rebel bark Saxon, and the destruction of rebel coal on Penguin Island, characterizes these acts as serious infractions of international law, for which England must demand redress. The British Government has instituted a very strict investigation into the conduct of the workmen and officials at Sheerness, who assisted and connived at the escape of the Rappahannock, and all against whom the offence has been proved have been required to resign. The London Times, in referring to the enlistment of men at Cork for the United States steamer Kearsage, points to the conduct of the American Government when England was supposed to be recruiting in the United States during the Crimean war, and says it is not too much to hope that the United States should weigh themselves in the same balance in which they weighed Great Britain. At the usual reception of the Diplomatic corps at the Tuileries on New-Year's Day, the Emperor significantly observed to Mr. DAYTON that he hoped the year 1864 would be one of peace and reconciliation for the United States. The semi-official French journals were exhibiting a decidedly anti-English tone. Schleswig-Holstein affairs still continued to absorb much attention. The Prince of Augustenburg had written a letter to NAPOLEON imploring his countenance and favor, to which the latter had replied, gracefully snubbing the expectant ruler of Holstein. The Duke, under date of Dec. 31, had issued a proclamation, dated Kiel, under the title of the Duke of Schleswig-Holstein, in which he expresses himself as being certain that his claims will be recognized. KOSSUTH's proclamation to the people of Hungary, before given by telegraph, is published in full. It decrees a new General Committee, and hopes that the Hungarians will promptly execute every order emanating from it, in order that the detested yoke of German domination may be shaken off. GARIBALDI has resigned his seat in the Chamber of Deputies.
headline: {'main': 'FROM EUROPE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'FROM EUROPE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Richmond papers as late as the 13th have been received at Fortress Monroe. There is nothing of special interest reported. A dispatch from Charleston states that our forces were busy repairing the damage done to our batteries by the storm. Snow had fallen to the depth of four inches at Orange Court-house.
lead_paragraph: Richmond papers as late as the 13th have been received at Fortress Monroe. There is nothing of special interest reported. A dispatch from Charleston states that our forces were busy repairing the damage done to our batteries by the storm. Snow had fallen to the depth of four inches at Orange Court-house. A dispatch from Gen. LEE announced that the rebels had captured in Hardy County 123 cattle, 125 mules and 200 prisoners -- probably the fruit of EARLY's raid. A dispatch from Wilmington, Jan. 11, announces that "the steamer Hero was run ashore near Georgetown after landing the navy officers." This was probably a blockade-runner. It also states that "one Yankee steamer was blown up and twenty-four prisoners captured," but how, when or where is not explained.

abstract: For the Next Presidency
snippet: For the Next Presidency
lead_paragraph: Any exciting discussion at this time concerning the nomination to be made by the Union party for the next Presidency is to be deprecated. The war demands concentrated attention, and the most harmonious spirit. Yet we hail with satisfaction such spontaneous expressions of preference as are now emanating from State Legislatures, Union Conventions, and other bodies representative of the loyal people. We hail them precisely because they are tokens that there will be no exciting discussion -- that there will be a general recognition that the public interests require the continuance of Mr. LINCOLN at the head of affairs.

abstract: Correspondence with the Pope
snippet: Correspondence with the Pope
lead_paragraph: -- JEFF. DAVIS is an artful dodger. In our foreign files received yesterday we find a correspondence between himself and Pope Pius IX., published elsewhere, which is a fair specimen of the tactics employed by the rebel leader to draw forth expressions of comfort and encouragement from European potentates. Two letters from the Pope to the Archbishops of New-York and New-Orleans, written and received when the latter city was in our possession, are seized upon by JEFF. as the pretext for addressing a letter to the Pope in reply, in which he begs for a nod of recognition. Now, these letters were no more intended for the chief of the rebels than they were for the chief of evil spirits, unless as an exhortation to all evil spirits, JEFF. DAVIS included, to abandon their internal practices, and allow peace and harmony to prevail. But DAVIS says they have been "communicated" to him -- by whom, when or how, he does not say -- but either run through the blockade, or "communicated" to him through the medium of the loyal press, where, we believe, one of the letters was originally published. This is DAVIS' basis for a begging letter to His Holiness; and he gets a reply which will not only flatter his vanity, but, if JEFF. reads it with his eyes open, will certainly convey to him several very appropriate and commendatory hints, viz.: to exert himself to "bring about the end of the fatal civil war," "in order that the American people may obtain peace and concord, and dwell charitably together." These sly digs at the chief rebel's impious doings are worthy of note; and it is to be hoped that in the pleasing contemplation of the flattering appellation of "Illustrious and Honorable President," DAVIS will not overlook the pertinent and sensible advice of His Holiness, to quit his treasonable work, and then, if he can escape the halter, to abscond the country, and take refuge under the shadow of some one of the insignificant rulers whose fingers and toes he is now kissing with so much humility.
headline: {'main': 'JEFF. DAVIS ON THE POPE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'JEFF. DAVIS ON THE POPE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: As a recognition of the patriotic devotion of the reenlisted veterans and disabled soldiers of the Irish Brigade, the officers of that gallant command now in this City have resolved to give a banquet to their ...
lead_paragraph: As a recognition of the patriotic devotion of the reenlisted veterans and disabled soldiers of the Irish Brigade, the officers of that gallant command now in this City have resolved to give a banquet to their war-worn companions in arms, on Saturday next, Jan. 16, at Irving Hall, commencing at 1 o'clock P.M. This banquet, which will be given at the expense of the officers of the brigade, without any outside assistance whatsoever, will be on a grand scale. Every necessary provision is being made to render it a success, under the personal supervision of Gen. MEAGHER, Capts. MCGEE and MORONEY of the Sixty-ninth, NAGLE of the Eighty-eighth, and CARTWRIGHT of the Sixty-third, together with Surgeon O'MEAGHER of the Sixty-ninth and Lieut. O'HANLON of the Sixty-third, and A.D.C., who constitute the Committee of Arrangements. A number of eminent citizens have been invited to attend. Gen. MEAGHER and his officers are determined to show to their heroic countrymen that their resolute fidelity to the Republic in its darkest hours is thoroughly appreciated. We anticipate a most genial and characteristic exhibition of Irish-American hospitality on this occasion.

abstract: It looks well in Albany for the desired increase of the salaries of the Police. The bill has thus early been introduced in the Assembly, and acted on favorably by the Committee. It is so manifestly just, meets with such a general approval from citizens, and so commends itself to the Legislature, that there would seem no doubt of its passage in either House. The bill is entirely untrameled with any of the other issues raised in regard to the Police -- relates solely to the matter of pay, and discards all extraneous matters. Its passage will enable over 2,000 men to meet the increased cost of living, pay them for thirty-seven hours' duty out of the forty-eight, and increase their efficiency.
lead_paragraph: It looks well in Albany for the desired increase of the salaries of the Police. The bill has thus early been introduced in the Assembly, and acted on favorably by the Committee. abstract: By order of Gen. DIX, Marshal MURRAY yesterday caused MALCOLM CAMPBEBL, lawyer, of No. 41 Ann-street, to be arrested. Deputy Marshal SMITH took him into custody, and conveyed him to the Marshal's office, where Mr. MURRAY made a demand of him for $23,000, which it was supposed he had in his possession, belonging to BENJAMIN, who is now in Fort Lafayette. Mr. CAMPBELL denied having such money, and was thereupon sent before Gen. DIX on charge of signing bonds for BENJAMIN on contraband shipments to Nassau. Gen. DIX gave the matter an immediate investigation. Mr. CAMPBELL declined giving any information in regard to the affairs of Mr. BENJAMIN, on the ground that he, BENJAMIN, was his client; he assured Gen. DIX that all his connection with BENJAMIN had been, and was strictly that of counsel. The examination resulted in the discharge of Mr. CAMPBELL.

abstract: The Predicament of Maximi ian
snippet: The Predicament of Maximi ian
lead_paragraph: Will his Serene Highness, MAXIMILIAN, permit us to laugh? Really, we can't help it -- he cuts such a comical figure! He is in a transition state -- but it is not that. A transition state is not necessarily a laughable one. There is a time in the morning when a man has one arm in his coat-sleeve, the other out -- when his toast is midway between the plate and the lip -- when his foot, as he starts for business, is in the air. But nobody laughs at these transition acts. So, too, a callow bird, a blind puppy, a wriggling tadpole, a grub that neither flies nor creeps, though a little curious, don't disturb our gravity. The reason is, not that there is not something whimsical in these anomalous conditions, but that they don't last. All sense of the absurd is taken away by the association of progress, of development, of promise for the future. We expect, as a matter of course, that the other arm, too, will go into its sleeve; that the toast will pass to the mouth; that the foot will come to the ground; that the squab will become a fledgling, the blind pup a watch-dog, the tadpole a bullfrog, the grub a butterfly. But here, for more than a year, this rudimental Emperor has had one arm in his Imperial coat, the other out -- has poised his Mexican bonne bouche half way to his lips -- has raised his one foot towards the halls of the Montezumas, and there held it. His imperial plumes are but pin-feathers still; he don't get his eyes open; he wriggles worse than ever. He is just as much grub and just as much butterfly, just as much Hapsburg and just as much Aztec, just as much Prince and just as much Emperor, as he was fifteen months ago. The last news is that he neither moves, nor alters. Nobody knows what to call him, or what to make of him. We don't know ourselves. All that we know is that it is very preposterous. We must laugh.
headline: {'main': 'The Predicament of Maximilian.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Predicament of Maximilian.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. BOILDIEU'S opera of "La Dame Blanche" a work too little known in this country was given here last night with complete and well-merited success. The composer represents the intermediate period between MOZART and the modern school of writers. His instrumentaion is  will it be pardoned our saying so? an improve-...
lead_paragraph: GERMAN OPERA. -- BOILDIEU's opera of "La Dame Blanche" -- a work too little known in this country was given here last night with complete and well-merited success. The composer represents the intermediate period between MOZART and the modern school of writers. His instrumentaion is -- will it be pardoned our saying so? -- an improvement on the master we have named, whilst his use of the chorus is immeasurably more vigorous than in any other composer of his period. The melodies are a little restrained by a too obvious regard for form; but they are nevertheless pure and beautiful. The concerted pieces are absolutely faultless; studies, in fact, for a generation of writers.

abstract: This elegant establishment known to all lovers of good living, has had, recently the long desired addition of a spacious saloon, capable of dining within it 120 persons. It is fitted up richly, and has all the attractions and conveniences which taste could suggest and liberality secure. The adjoining rooms -- reception and retiring -- are luxuriously fitted up, and, in short, the entire addition is characterized by elegance and comfort. The table service is chaste and beautiful, appetizing on sight. Clubs and dinner committees have now what, at the Maison, they have long needed. The proprietor announces that dinners from his favorite establishment will be served wheresoever desired, weddings and suppers on briefest notice, and creams and confections daily at all hours, sent on order.

abstract: -- Coroner COLLIN held an inquest yesterday upon the body of CATHARINE HENRY, a very old woman, who died from injuries received at the hands of her daughter-in-law, BRIDGET HENRY, residing at 328 East Thirteenth street. It appears that deceased had a quarrel with her daughter, during which she was knocked down and beaten so severely as to cause her death. The jury rendered a verdict in accordance with the facts, and a warrant was issued for the arrest of the assailant.
lead_paragraph: -- Coroner COLLIN held an inquest yesterday upon the body of CATHARINE HENRY, a very old woman, who died from injuries received at the hands of her daughter-in-law, BRIDGET HENRY, residing at 328 East Thirteenth street. abstract: The reenlisted veterans of the New York cavalry, Ninth New-Jersey, and Twenty-third and Twenty-fifth Massachusetts infantry volunteers, arrived in this City yesterday afternoon, on their way to their respective States on furlough, and to recruit their ranks. These regiments embarked at Newport News on the steamers Patapsco, Capt. Mott, and City of Richmond, Capt. KELLY, on Wednesday, P.M.,...
lead_paragraph: The reenlisted veterans of the New York cavalry, Ninth New-Jersey, and Twenty-third and Twenty-fifth Massachusetts infantry volunteers, arrived in this City yesterday afternoon, on their way to their respective States on furlough, and to recruit their ranks. These regiments embarked at Newport News on the steamers Patapsco, Capt. Mott, and City of Richmond, Capt. KELLY, on Wednesday, P.M., and sailed from Fort Monroe on Thursday morning. They all belong to HECKMAN's brigade, and the Patapsco, when she came into port, had Gen. HECKMAN's brigade battle flag flying at her masthead. These troops come to this point under command of Col. G.H. MIX, of the Third New-York cavalry, and are accompanied by a full complement of their regimental and company officers.

abstract: We have taken no part in any attempt to prejudge the questions of individual criminality raised by the recent discoveries of misconduct in the Custom-house. We take it for granted that the whole matter will be thoroughly sifted under direction of the Government, and we are quite willing, as the public will be, to await the result of such an investigation, provided it is conducted by...
lead_paragraph: We have taken no part in any attempt to prejudge the questions of individual criminality raised by the recent discoveries of misconduct in the Custom-house. We take it for granted that the whole matter will be thoroughly sifted under direction of the Government, and we are quite willing, as the public will be, to await the result of such an investigation, provided it is conducted by competent persons, and in a way to serve the cause of public justice, and not the personal ends of individuals. But this confidence will not be secured by what seems to be the drift of affairs at the present moment. It is very ostentatiously announced that active efforts are on foot at Albany and elsewhere to secure the immediate removal of Collector BARNEY, and the immediate appointment of somebody else in his place; Union members of the Legislature, State officers, and other persons supposed to have influence with the Administration, are pressed to join in the effort, and a very active canvass has been set on foot, -- not to secure a fair and full inquiry into official abuses, but to secure a change of office-holders.

abstract: A few eminent citizens last evening gave a private and informal complimentary dinner to Gen. BURNSIDE, at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. Among them were Rev. Dr. FRANCIS VINTON, NEHEMIAH KNIGHT, JOHN E. WILLIAMS, R.H. McCURDY, S.B. CHITTENDEN, LEUTZE, the painter, G.W. BLUNT, ,  The supper itself was elegant and handsomely served, and the speeches that followed, brief, terse and telling, were of a high order of social eloquence.
lead_paragraph: A few eminent citizens last evening gave a private and informal complimentary dinner to Gen. BURNSIDE, at the Fifth-Avenue Hotel. Among them were Rev. Dr. FRANCIS VINTON, NEHEMIAH KNIGHT, JOHN E. WILLIAMS, R.H. McCURDY, S.B. CHITTENDEN, LEUTZE, the painter, G.W. BLUNT, , The supper itself was elegant and handsomely served, and the speeches that followed, brief, terse and telling, were of a high order of social eloquence. Far the most interesting, however, were the few remarks of Gen. BURNSIDE himself; who gave some deeply interesting reminisicences of the perfect and self-sacrificing loyalty of the people of East Tennessee, of the siege of Knoxville, and of his command in Cincinnati. East Tennesseeans, for instance, when the Union armies swept their forms clean of subsistence, would say, "It's hard, General, to be sure; but thank God, the Yankees did it!" And during the siege of Knoxville, most seasonable and large supplies were constantly floated down to the town on the river past the besieger's pickets through the fogs, from a region actutually patrolled by rebel cavalry. The General said of the siege of Knoxville, that after all, there was no great merit in holding it, "because we were ordered to!" After explaining how the detention of LONGSTREET before Knoxville, enabled GRANT to complete his success at Chattanooga. Gen. BURNSIDE paid a noble tribute to the private soldiers, whom he called the real heroes of the war, "fighting where they encounter twenty bullets for one that comes near me, and with no prospect if they fall, better than a nameless grave." Then followed a brief allusion to his policy in arresting VALLANDIGHAM, of striking at the leaders, and a curious story of that Copperhead's arrest. It was threatened that he would be rescued; so he was put in the room immediately above Gen. BURNSIDE's in the hotel, two floors higher, a company of regulars quartered in the hotel, and a Corporal and seven men in the room opposite VALLANDIGHAM's, having express orders to do anything to prevent the prisoner from leaving that room. A serenade to VALLANDIGHAM was proposed, but given up when Gen. BURNSIDE advised the proposers that this regular corporal didn't know anything in the world, except to obey orders, and that there was danger that he might think a rescue was intended, and that VALLANDIGHAM might unhappily meet with some accident. And the General concluded with very graceful and feeling reference to the kind reception he had met at the East, and his hopes of being able to fill up the Ninth Army corps to 50,000 men.

abstract: the Chances of
snippet: the Chances of
lead_paragraph: The political horizon never looked stormier than at this moment in Europe. On the eve of a terrible famine in Hungary, KOSSUTH has sent forth one of his revolutionary proclamations, which never fail to stir the blood of the Hungarian peasantry, so that Austria is already represented to be in a ferment. The Polish Revolution still continues -- an open and bleeding wound in the side of Europe. The Italian aspirations for national unity have not been satisfied, and the historical capital of Italy is still held by foreigners. But most threatening of all, England presents a protest against the occupation of the Duchies by the Federal authorities, and, along with France, appears to guarantee the integrity of Denmark, even at the expense of a great war. The French Emperor still sustains his immense armaments, and is known to look with eager eye for the chances which a German war might bring of acquiring territory on the Rhine. Federal Germany is aroused to an intense pitch, and does not appear likely to yield a point in the Danish question. At the same time, the old revolutionary element still seethes and boils beneath the surface in every country of continental Europe. Nothing could appear more perilous or stormy than the present aspect. It would seem that but a spark were necessary to kindle a universal conflagration.
headline: {'main': 'The Chances of a European War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Chances of a European War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Board of Aldermen yesterday directed the Street Committee to report some plan for the improvement of the pavement on Broadway. The Comptroller sent in his estimates of City expenses for 1864. The budget foots up $8,013,263 86, or $778,313 82 more than the total appropriations of 1863.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen yesterday directed the Street Committee to report some plan for the improvement of the pavement on Broadway. The Comptroller sent in his estimates of City expenses for 1864. The budget foots up $8,013,263 86, or $778,313 82 more than the total appropriations of 1863. He estimates the receipts into the General Fund at $495,200, and a surplus of the Sinking Fund for the payment of interest on the City debt amounts to $750,000, applicable to general purposes, leaving the amount to be raised by tax $6,768,063 86. His estimates do not vary greatly from his predecessor's estimates for 1863. In fact, one item of $895,570, to pay the Union Defence Fund Bonds, issued in 1861, shows the difference, except that last year a half million of the Relief Fund debt was included. Mr. BRENNAN's estimates are low -- some of them too low to meet expenses legitimately incurred, and that must be paid, and the Common Council will be obliged to increase them. The item of $30,000 for Corporation advertising is an instance. The increased number of papers will require the raising of a much larger sum. However, knowing the tendency of the Common Council to inflate the budget, he probably has deemed it best not to start them with big figures. City Inspector BOOLE sent in a reply to the Mayor's message and Superintendent CARR's assertions, concerning the management of his department. The charges and the defence were ordered to be published side by side in the TIMES, and six other papers, and the whole subject was handed over to the Special Committee on Retrenchment and Reform for investigation. The Comptroller was requested to furnish a statement of the receipts from and cost of sustaining (including salaries,) Washington and West Washington, Fulton, Franklin and Jefferson Markets. The Mayor's nominations of Dr. WM. MURPHY, for Health Commissioner, vice Dr. J. MILLER, and THOMAS H. FERRIS, for Inspector of Vessels, vice ANDREW SHEEHAN, were taken up and confirmed. Adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M., on Tuesday.

abstract: In the Senate a bill was favorably reported to prohibit the enlistment of men in this State for other States. A bill was introduced to amend the act relative to the making up of railroad trains; for rebuilding the locks on the Chemung and Oneida Canals; authorizing Dutchess County to borrow $250,000 for bounty purposes.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate a bill was favorably reported to prohibit the enlistment of men in this State for other States. A bill was introduced to amend the act relative to the making up of railroad trains; for rebuilding the locks on the Chemung and Oneida Canals; authorizing Dutchess County to borrow $250,000 for bounty purposes. The Assembly resolutions to amend the Constitution so as to allow soldiers to vote, were unanimously passed. A message was received from GOV. SEYMOUR, with regard to the returning regiments, and the condition of recruits at the several rendezvous. A resolution authorizing the Governor to expend $25,000 for the proper reception of the volunteers, was laid over. The Judiciary Committee were instructed to report upon the expediency of reporting a bill to authorize a State bounty of $300 in lieu of all town and county bounties now being paid. Both houses adjourned to Monday evening.

abstract: NEW-JERSEY VERSUS THE UNITED STATES. -- GOV. PARKER, of New-Jersey, devotes a large part of his message to denunciations of the Emancipation Proclamation issued by the President a year ago, and to arguments intended to show that the offer of an amnesty now made to the rebels will do more hurt than good. GOV. PARKER has a right to his opinion on these subjects as on all others. But we do not see what good object he proposes to accomplish by ventilating them at so much length in his message. He can scarcely expect to induce the President to recall either the proclamation or the offer of amnesty. The former, according to the most reliable information that reaches us, has produced very good results and has contributed very largely to that crippling of the rebel resources which is the best guarantee of the downfall of the rebel Government. And up to the present time we have no reason to suppose that the effect of the proffered amnesty has been otherwise than beneficial. Would not Gov. PARKER have acted more wisely if he had quietly waited to see what the effect of these measures would be before insisting so zealously upon their certain failure?

abstract: Clark vs. Brooks; N. Y. Express Case
snippet: Clark vs. Brooks; N. Y. Express Case
lead_paragraph: At about 10 o'clock last night, a fire broke out in the second story of the five-story marble-front building, No. 146 Duane street, occupied by AUFFMORDT, HESSENBERG Co, importers and dealers in cloths, cassemeres &c., which, before it could be extinguished, involved the whole building and contents in destruction. The first floor and basement of the building were occupied by FAIRCHILD & FANSHAW, importers of British and other foreign silks and dry goods. Owing to the combustible nature of the contents, the fire spread through the building with fearful rapidity, extending from floor to floor with increasing fury, defying all the efforts of the firemen until the entire building had been destroyed. The flames bursting through the roof, illuminated the entire neighberhood, and the burning embers from the fire were floating through the air for blocks around. The firemen, who arrived promptly at the scene, worked with unceasing energy, but could not succeed in saving the devoted building, and they turned their attention to the surrounding stores, which were fortunately preserved from much injury.

abstract: The wind yesterday was from the Northwest. For the past few days large quantities of drift ice, very thick and hard, have been floating about our bays and rivers, doing more or less damage to the shipping and piers. Yesterday, on the flood-tide immense fields of it swept up the East River, doing considerable damage to vessels lying at the ends of piers. The ship Daniel Webster, lying at the upper end of Pier No. 16 East River, had her quarter stove and rudder damaged. Ship Compromise, lying at the lower side of the same pier, was badly chafed, and by careening had her mainyard carried away. The Belle Wood, loaded for Liverpool, at Pier No. 27 East River, was so badly injured that she was compelled to low to Brooklyn to discharge, and her damage is estimated at $10,090. The brig Lucretia arrived Friday from Jamaica, lying at the lower side of Wall-street, was badly chafed and had her foreyard broken by careening. The steamship Sidon, that arrived from Liverpool Friday morning, with 250 steerage passengers, had not discharged her passengers at noon yesterday, in consequence of the difficulty in getting to her from the Ice. The ship Elizabeth Hamilton, lying at Wall-street, parted her moorings, and she was driven against the Daniel Webster, losing rudder and receiving other damage. Upon the flood tide, this afternoon, a very extensive and heavy floating field of ice passed into the East River, which delayed the Staten Island and South Ferry boats, that were in the slips at the time, nearly half an hour, and in its progress up the river materially damaged the ends of many of the piers -- some being nearly demolished. The North River, last night, was one vast field of ice, reaching from shore to shore, and very hard and thick.

abstract: POLYGLOT BUREAU. -- In London, in Paris, and other European capitals, there have long been established offices for the translation of papers from and into all languages. Some of them employ from sixty to eighty translators, and their time is fully occupied. To merchants, professional men and others, they are found convenient; and a cheaper mode than where such bureaus do not exist. In this large commercial City, and with a population where so many are of European birth, such an establishment has been long needed; an office where one can apply and get a letter or any document immediately and accurately translated at a moderate cost. Mr. LEANDER STARR, a gentleman of fine literary acquirements, and an accomplished linguist, has opened such a bureau at No. 71 Nassau-street. In addition to his experience at Kings College, London, and Rupert-Caroline University at Heidelberg, Mr. STARR has served as interpreter and translator to the Navy Department of the French Government at Paris, and, until lately, he has been connected with the foreign press of this City. The work done by each member of the corps of translators is carefully scrutinized before delivery by the accomplished chef himself. To all in need of translations the Polyglot Bureau must prove invaluable.

abstract: Dr. Yeatman's Report
snippet: Dr. Yeatman's Report
lead_paragraph: The great economical discussion in Europe, between large holdings and small holdings, has never been renewed here, as every one is thoroughly convinced that small farms and small freeholders are much the best for this country. The only part of the country which has been worked in large estates is now reaping the benefit of an aristocracy. A people which has no class of intelligent, independent small freeholders, will inevitably be exposed to such convulsions and such ambitious revolutions as the slave-aristocracy of the South has caused on this continent. There is, in such a system of industry, no great intelligent middle class to hold the balance between the extremes of society.
headline: {'main': 'The Lessee System on the Mississippi.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Lessee System on the Mississippi.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At a special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, held yesterday afternoon, the subject of the removal of the Police Commissioners was brought up and discussed at length. A series of resolutions was offered by Capt. CHARLES H. MARSHALL, denounc
lead_paragraph: At a special meeting of the Chamber of Commerce, held yesterday afternoon, the subject of the removal of the Police Commissioners was brought up and discussed at length. A series of resolutions was offered by Capt. CHARLES H. MARSHALL, denouncing the course pursued by Gov. SEYMOUR in removing the old Police Commissioners. In the resolutions, reference was made to the noble conduct of the police during the July riots, and an approval given of the bill recently introduced into the Legislature providing for the permanent organization of the Police Department. Messrs. G.W. Blunt, S.B. Crittenden. Jonathan Sturges, C.S. Roberts, William Orton, Luther B. Wyman and John Austin Stevens, Jr., were appointed a Committee to visit Albany ot urge the necessity of the passage of the bill.

abstract: THE CONDITION OF FORT SUMTER. -- The quantity of patience, powder and public money spent by our fleet in bombarding Fort Sumter during the last few months renders the actual condition of that historic fortress a matter of considerable public interest. A correspondent of the London Times, writing under date of Dec. 1, gives an account of a visit which he had paid the fort a few days previous. He found it a very interesting expedition, though decidedly dangerous in consequence of the constant fall of shells from the Federal fleet, directed in their flight by a powerful calcium light which enabled the assailants to see perfectly everything about the Fort. Until they got into the bombproofs, therefore, the party were exposed to a good deal of danger: but once there, they were perfectly safe. The writer adds:

abstract: Capt. DAYLY, of the steamship Moonlight, arrived Saturday, from Matamoras, reports, Jan. 10, Wilmington bearing west, 125 miles, saw a propeller of about 500 tons, painted lead color, moking a heavy black smoke, and steering to northward and eastward, supposed to be a blockade-runner. Capt. DAYLY also reports about 75 vessels off the bar at Matamoras, but the weather being so bad, no cargo could be lightered off. As high as $10 per bale for Cotton was offered, to have it taken to the vessels, but was not accepted in consequence of the weather. The vessels were chafing each other to a considerable extent.

abstract: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. The Supervisors' Bounty Committee, on Friday, paid bounties to sixty veterans of the Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh regiments. The day previous bounties were paid to one hundred and eleven men. One company of the Sixty-
lead_paragraph: RECRUITING IN BROOKLYN. The Supervisors' Bounty Committee, on Friday, paid bounties to sixty veterans of the Sixty-sixth and Sixty-seventh regiments. The day previous bounties were paid to one hundred and eleven men. One company of the Sixty-sevent Regiment having originally been enlisted in the western part of this State, were sent home shortly after the arrival of the regiment in this City. Supervisor LITTLE started for Rochester, on Thursday, to pay these men their bounties. Supervisors BLOOM and KIRBY will proceed to Baltimore and the Rappahannock to-day, in order to pay bounties to all who are willing to reenlist, and be acredited to the quota of Kings County. The money heretofore raised for paying bounties is now nearly exhausted, and very little of the new loan of $250,000 has as yet been taken. If it is not taken soon, recruiting will come to a dead lock.
headline: {'main': 'BROOKLYN NEWS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'BROOKLYN NEWS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The artists of New-York certainly deserve the thanks of their friends for the pleasant receptions which they are in the habit of giving during that Winter season. The studio in Tenth-street, Dod
lead_paragraph: The artists of New-York certainly deserve the thanks of their friends for the pleasant receptions which they are in the habit of giving during that Winter season. The studio in Tenth-street, Dodworth's Building and the Brooklyn Academy of Music, alternately open their doors for these most enjoyable reunions of the art and beauty-loving. In the two former, the numerous studios which they contain are graciously opened for those who search for the beautiful in little out-of-the-way nooks and shady green (baize) spots. Here one gets a glimpse of the mysteries of art-life. Here -- skulls and rosebuds -- bear-skins and baby hands -- stag-horns and ladies' slippers -- manikins and meerschaums -- laurel wreaths and sledge-hammers -- wax figures and bowie-knives -- turbans and pickle-jars -- steel armor and embroidered handkerchiefs -- divans, easy chairs, ottomans and three-legged stools -- plaster heads, arms, legs, heels, toes and noses -- banjos and harps -- locks of hair and boot-jacks -- old clothes properly torn -- stuffed birds, frying-pans, peacock's tails and gingerbread -- all in wonderful contrariety and strange juxtaposition.
headline: {'main': 'The Fine Arts.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fine Arts.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}
