abstract: Richmond papers of the 15th inst. were received yesterday at Fortress Monroe. They contain telegrams from Charleston as late as Thursday last, when the bombardment was progressing with increased fury, several new Parrotts having been opened upon the city from Fort Gregg. During
lead_paragraph: Richmond papers of the 15th inst. were received yesterday at Fortress Monroe. They contain telegrams from Charleston as late as Thursday last, when the bombardment was progressing with increased fury, several new Parrotts having been opened upon the city from Fort Gregg. During the two days preceding the date of the dispatch, 471 shells had been fired at the place, but with what effect is not mentioned. The telegrams report the number of vessels at Hilton Head to be very large, and say that a fleet has recently gone Southward. MOSBY is reported to have been badly whipped in the recent affair at Harpers Ferry, but notwithstanding his losses, he is said to be still harassing our men.
headline: {'main': 'THE REBELLION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE REBELLION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Great activity prevails at the Naval Depot at Cairo, and it is said that an expedition to go up Red River is being fitted out. Workmen are engaged day and night in preparing the boats required for this purpose, and in about two weeks it is expected that all will be ready. What the object of the expedition is has not transpired; but if Red River should be sufficiently high to admit the passage of these vessels up very far, important transactions will undoubtedly take place.

abstract: Female Education for the Better Classes
snippet: Female Education for the Better Classes
lead_paragraph: We have alluded recently to the middle class examinations for women in England as a step in the right direction with regard to the elevation of the female working classes. It is still more clearly a national progress in respect to the advancement of women in the middle and upper classes. The great want, both in England and America, for these ranks of life, is a more thorough and practical education. Every father of a family here who is hot a man of wealth, knows that his daughters, unless they marry, have but two professions open to them after his death leaves them on the world -- that is, teaching and keeping a boarding-house. Now, not to speak of the disagremens of the latter business, comparatively few women are fitted for either of those employments, whether by nature or training. Then the fact that but two lines of occupation are substantially open, crowds them with competitors, so that the salaries and profits are reduced to a very low rate.

abstract: London Times on Corruption of Confederate Government
snippet: London Times on Corruption of Confederate Government
lead_paragraph: NOT A PLEASANT PROSPECT. -- We hear a great deal of the corruptions that have become rife in every department of our Government. We have no doubt there is quite enough truth in what is said upon this subject to warrant very severe denunciations and very marked solicitude for the permanent welfare of the country. But if misery loves company, we are not wholly without sources of consolation. Affairs in the rebel Confederacy seem to be a good deal worse even than the most graphic of our home critics have represented them here. A correspondent of the London Times, who is favored with a residence at Richmond, thus discourses on this prolific theme:

abstract: It has been stated that the American Telegraph Company have had all their cables across the North River destroyed. Such is not the case. They have seven cables, five of which were carried away. The other two have worked regularly. The wires connecting with the five disabled cables are yet operating from Jersey City, but it is expected a portion of the broken cables will be repaired to-day.

abstract: The anniversary of the birthday of BENJAMIN FEANKLIN will be commemorated by the New-York Typographical Society at 7 1/2 o'clock on Monday evening next, (the 18th inst.,) at the Library-rooms, No. 3 Chambers-street. The oldest member of the Society, Mr. CHAS. MCDEVITT, will give a short account of the history of the Society, and will be followed by Messrs. DE VINNE and ALVORD, on interesting subjects connected with the printer's art. Mr. AUGUSTUS MAVERICK will give some sketches of representative men in the editorial profession in this City, and of other distinguished persons. The proceedings will be interspersed with music and appropriate exercises.

abstract: Our Canadian friends are having another season of the celebrated case of the Commercial Bank of Canada vs. The Great Western Railway. It was before the Canadian Court of Appeals at Toronto on Tuesday and Wednesday last. It possesses no little interest, and we give a brief history thereof: The Bank claims of the Railroad Company the sum of $1,500,000, advanced to C.J. BRYDGZS, Managing Director G.W.R., and THOS. REYNOLDS, Finance Director G.W.R., on account of the Detroit and Milwaukee Railroad. It seems that after the Great Western Company undertook the completion of the Detroit and Milwaukee road, the large sum of money claimed in the suit was advanced by the Commercial Bank to Messrs. BRYDGES and REYNOLDS, both being officers of each Company. The Bank allege that the money was advanced to the Great Western, and on the failure of the Detroit and Milwaukee, demanded the return of their loan from that Company. The latter, however, asserted that the advances were made to the Detroit and Milwaukee, and not to the Great Western Company, and denied all the responsibility. The Bank commenced a suit, fixing the sum claimed at $1,500,000, and the case was first tried at the Kingston (C.W.) Assizes, in May, 1862, and resulted in a verdict for the Bank. In August, 1862, the Great Western obtained from the Court of Queen's Bench a rule nisi, calling upon the plaintiffs to show why a non-suit should not be entered, on account of the misdirection of the Judge, and the reception of improper evidence. The case was argued before the Court of Queen's Bench and in December a decision was given again in favor of the Bank. The Great Western took an appeal, which came before the Court of Appeals at Toronto on Tuesday and Wednesday as stated. On the bench were President M'LEAN, of the Court of Appeals; Chief Justice DRAPER, of the Queen's Bench; Chief Justice RICHARDS, of the Common Pleas; Chancellor VANKOUGHNET, Vice-Chancellor ESTON, and Hon. Justices WILSON and MORRISON, being the chief judicial dignitaries of the province. The case was argued for two days, and the Court reserved its judgment. It is probable that the final decision will not be given until the March term of the Court. -- Rochester Democrat, Jan. 8.

lead_paragraph: In accordance with previous arrangements on the part of the officers and ex-officers of the Irish Brigade, the non-commissioned officers and privates, numbering about 250 men, were sumptuously entertained yesterday afternoon at Irving Hall by a grand banquet given in honor to them by the commissioned officers of the brigade exclusively, they having refused to be the recipient of any large amount of money gratefully and freely tendered by outside and interested parties, considering it a far more preferable mode of showing the high regard and esteem entertained by them for the brave, hardy and patriotic sons of the Emerald Isle, who had so nobly and faithfully fought and patiently suffered by their side in behalf of the only country where their rights of citizenship had been respected.

abstract: Foreign Criticisms upon, continued; Memorial Diplomatique on our Prize Courts continued
snippet: Foreign Criticisms upon, continued; Memorial Diplomatique on our Prize Courts continued
lead_paragraph: We have shown in a previous article that the attack of the Memorial Diplomatique upon the Prize Court of this District, in reference to the case of the Stephen Hart, was entirely unjustifiable. An examination of the opinion of the Court in the case of the Springbok, which has been furnished us, leads us to a similar conclusion as to this case. We find in that part of the article which relates to it, as we found in what related to the Stephen Hart misstatements of the facts of the case, and misstatements of the law as laid down in it, and if the former are not so gross as those in reference to the Stephen Hart, the latter are even graver.

abstract: Police Commissioners--Necessity of Legislation
snippet: Police Commissioners--Necessity of Legislation
lead_paragraph: We trust the Legislature will give early attention to the subject of our Police. Gov. SEYMOUR's extraordinary action in removing the entire Commission and appointing new men in their places, regardless of what are believed to be the explicit and peremptory requirements of the law, is certain to involve us in great difficulty, and to impair most seriously the efficiency of the force. Public sentiment would not allow the present Commissioners, even if they were disposed, to quietly yield to action believed to be utterly illegal, and known to be highly detrimental to the peace and good order of the City. The validity of Gov. SEYMOUR's action will be tested in all the Courts of law, and meantime the Police force will be demoralized, the City saddled with heavy expenses, men kept out of their pay, and a conflict of authority created, injurious to every interest of the community.
headline: {'main': 'Our City Police at Albany.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our City Police at Albany.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: American Watch Company vs. Th. Block & Bros. -- This was an action brought by the plaintiff, a corporation engaged in manufacturing the American watch, at Waltham, near Boston, Mass., against the defendants, watch manufacturers in Switzerland, having an agency in this City. The celebrity attained by the American watch by reason of its superiority over all foreign watches in lowness of price and perfectness of time-keeping, has created a public demand which even the large resources of the factory have been unable promptly to supply. Hence an illicit manufacture has sprung up during the past year in England and on the continent, and large quantities of spurious watches, very inferior to the American watch, have been made there and imported into this country, bearing the forged name of the American Watch Company, and also infringing their various trade marks. The general appearance of the watches which have pirated the plaintiff's trade mark, is well calculated to deceive the public and even dealers not familiar with the genuine article.

abstract: Cobden-Delane Controversy--Newspaper Impersonality
snippet: Cobden-Delane Controversy--Newspaper Impersonality
lead_paragraph: One of our exchanges mentions a "report" that "since the editor of the London Times, Mr. DELANE, allowed himself to be smoked out from his snug seclusion of impersonality, and castigated by Mr. COBDEN, that unhappy gentleman is treated with marked coldness by his acquaintances and whilom friends in ministerial circles." This is only one of the many absurdities to which this famous controversy has given rise. The idea that any revelation of the editorship of the Times has taken place in consequence of the correspondence between Mr. COBDEN and Mr. DELANE is simply ridiculous. We presume there has not been, for the last ten years, the slightest doubt in the mind of any reasonably well informed politician in England, that Mr. DELANE was the editor of the Times. He certainly has never taken the slightest pains to conceal it. Every member of Parliament knew it, and was very glad to meet him in that capacity. It was just as well known in all the clubs, and in all other places of resort for men at all interested in public affairs, as was the fact that PALMERSTON was Premier, and COBDEN the head of the Reform party. When he visited this country Mr. DELANE was received everywhere, publicly and privately, as the editor of the Times, and never thought of denying, evading or concealing the fact.

abstract: Principles and Practice of
snippet: Principles and Practice of
lead_paragraph: We published a letter yesterday on "The Principles of Taxation," recommending the Government to lay the burden as far as possible on "primary manufactures," or, in other words, on those manufactured articles, such as pig-iron, which furnish the raw material for other manufactures, because these taxes are easier of collection, but are less harassing and vexatious to the community at large. Now that Congress is turning its attention to the necessity, which every one sees, of raising more money by taxes and less by loans, we hope this advice will have due weight. Nothing can be plainer than that the proportion, which at present exists between these two modes of raising revenue, cannot be preserved any longer. We must pay more of our current expenses, out of our means, and less of them by borrowing, if we mean to preserve our credit. If we go on raising loans at the same rate as during the last two years, during two years more, we shall certainly bring on a crisis such as nobody would like to contemplate, and no dexterity in the management of our finances would be of the slightest use in warding it off. Every scheme that does not involve a large amount of taxation, is simply either a postponement of payment, or the conversion of one evidence of indebtedness into another evidence of indebtedness. The debt is not reduced by it in the least, or the payment of either interest or principal made one particle easier. And although it seems most probable that the war will be over within the present year, we have no right to calculate on this, either in arranging our financial or our military affairs. As long as the war is actually going on, all calculations as to the time when it will end, or the way in which it will end, are too vague and too uncertain to furnish any sound basis for a plan of finance. The only plan consistent with safety or honor, is to tax and raise men as if the struggle was to last for two or three years longer, and as if the termination of actual hostilities was sure not to bring with it complete pacification. Nearly all our mistakes and misfortunes, hitherto, have been due to our unfortunate faith in the shortness of the contest. The waste, both of blood and treasure, which has been caused by our confident expectation that the rebellion would be over in three or six months, cannot, of course, be accurately known; but we know enough to know that it has been enormous. It is high time to abandon these delusions, and to acknowledge frankly and fairly the magnitude of our task, and prepare for it. We have to conquer half a continent, and, when conquered, we shall be obliged, according to all present appearances, to reorganize its social system from the base to the apex. This is a tremendous work, but it is a glorious one, and will call for the display of as much wisdom as valor. We have shown the valor -- but the demand for wisdom will, of course, last long after that for valor has ceased.

abstract: -We give this morning a tale of horrors that has not been equaled for many a day, in the facts of the burning to death of between two and three thousand people in a church at Santiago, the Capital of Chili, South America. The vivid pictures given by our correspondents on the spot, are certainly heart-rending. The horrors of war -- its carnage and its cruelties are bad enough; but a scene such as this, is infinitely more shocking than the fiercest contests of brave men. The victims were of all grades of society, embracing among them the elite of the gay capital of Chili. We have a list of over 2,000 of these victims, sent us by our special correspondents, which we have no room to publish, but those interested can see the list for a few days at the counting-room of the TIMES.

abstract: the Proposal to Report Fully
snippet: the Proposal to Report Fully
lead_paragraph: -We see it stated that the United States Senate is inquiring into the propriety of employing an official reporter to furnish reports of the debates for the press in New-York and elsewhere. They complain that the reports now published are meagre and unsatisfactory. While Senators are prosecuting this inquiry we may give them a hint or two that will be of service. The reason why our Congressional reports are so brief is that the public do not want them any longer. We have tried the experiment. Three years ago the TIMES, in connection with two of its neighbors, had special reports of both Houses of Congress made and transmitted by telegraph expressly for their columns. They were much more full than those furnished for the Associated Press. The increased expense thus incurred by the New-York papers that entered into it was not far from a thousand dollars a week; yet nobody seemed to care for the increased fullness of the reports. Indeed, the disposition on the part of the public was rather the other way; the reports were too long to be generally read, and it was on this account that they were discontinued.

abstract: The General Term of the Court of Common Pleas, after some four and a half years' delay, has just decided the vexed question as to the import of the section in the Metropolitan Police Act which forbids the "publicly keeping" of intoxicating liquors on Sundays and election days. The judgment of the court below is affirmed, and it is settled "the keeping of liquors in so public a manner as to invite the public to purchase, or keeping a store or bar-room containing them open and easily accessible to the public," is a violation of the law.

abstract: A Baltimore dispatch says that word has been received from Gen. KELLY, announing the return of Major COLE, of the Maryland cavalry, from a scout to Leesburgh. The Major saw nothing of the rebels, and he does not credit the report that STUART is threatening Point of Rocks. Not an armed rebel was seen within forty miles of Leesburgh.
lead_paragraph: A Baltimore dispatch says that word has been received from Gen. KELLY, announing the return of Major COLE, of the Maryland cavalry, from a scout to Leesburgh. The Major saw nothing of the rebels, and he does not credit the report that STUART is threatening Point of Rocks. Not an armed rebel was seen within forty miles of Leesburgh.

abstract: We have received full files of Richmond papers from Dec. 28, 1863, to the 15th inst., there having been no communication by flag of truce during that time. The contents of the papers are very
lead_paragraph: We have received full files of Richmond papers from Dec. 28, 1863, to the 15th inst., there having been no communication by flag of truce during that time. The contents of the papers are very interesting, though there is no important news, The Winter is passing rapidly away, and the temper of the rebel journals shows that the condition of affairs is not improving. The severe weather is terribly felt by the ill-clad armies. The numbers of the rebel armies, despite the efforts of the rebel Congress at conscription, do not augment; the question of supplies is assuming a more formidable attitude than ever; the Conscription Bill will leave the States without crops, the planters going into the armies and the slaves being hired out to Corporations and manufacturers. The conscription of all the old soldiers now in the armies, whose term shortly expires, is urged in a memorial to the Rebel Congress by Gens. HARDEE, CHEATHAM, BRECKINRIDGE, and others. LONGSTREET'S position in East Tennessee is said to be satisfactory, though it is admitted that his troops are without supplies of many kinds, particularly shoes. It is reported that he will stay in East Tennessee this winter. JEFF DAVIS had issued an order conveying the joint resolution of thanks of the Rebel Congress to Gen. LEE. An account of the rebel raid into Hardy County is given, which shows it to have been an insignificant affair in its results. Gen. PICKETT, commanding the district on the North Carolina frontier, has hung a colored soldier of the Fifth Ohio Regiment, in retaliation for a guerrilla hung by Gen. WILD; also another colored man belonging to Massachusetts, for burning houses. The railroad companies of the Confederacy have become so reduced in rolling stock, that extraordinary efforts are now being made to repair and increase the efficiency of the roads, but a Richmond paper remarks that the conscription will disable the railroads, and says, in addition, "all Virginia railroads are nearly worn out, and so are the men working them." The reenlistment of our veterans is a source of gloom to the rebel press, which chronicles the fact with evident alarm. Flour is quoted at $150 per barrel. The cast of the whole horoscope, as seen through rebel eyes, is decidedly blue, and the prospect grows darker and darker.

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. -- WAGNERS celebrated opera of the Tannhauser was brought out at the Academy of Music, last evening, with complete success. The performance was generally of a very creditable sort, but owing to the length of the opera, it did not terminate until an hour much too late for us to do justice to its merits. We shall, therefore, defer our remarks to another occasion, simply placing on record the favorable reception of the opera, and the general merit of the performance. Tannhauser will be repeated on Wednesday.

abstract: on State Regeneration Before Restoration
snippet: on State Regeneration Before Restoration
lead_paragraph: So far as the bill prepared by Mr. ASHLEY Of Ohio, Chairman of the House Committee on Territories, provides for carrying into effect the President'a plan for loyal Governments in the insurgent States, its proposed enactments carry a look of thoroughness in details as well as of soundness in principle. It is no doubt an anomaly to recognize a small fraction of the freemen -- or any fraction whatever less than a majority -- as the governing constituency for an entire State; but it is one which is forced upon the Government by events and circumstances themselves so anomalous as to commend this measure as the nearest, among all debatable ones, to the spirit and intents of the Constitution. There is a wide and obvious, although commonly unnoticed distinction, between communities that subsist as States, in the sense commonly accepted among mankind, and such as have come into the condition and character of our United States, Any civilized people occupying and possessing an ascertained domain under an organized Government is, in the former sense, a State, -- as says Brabantio of Venice, in the play;
headline: {'main': 'NATIONAL POLITICS.; State Regeneration Precedent to State Restoration.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'NATIONAL POLITICS.; State Regeneration Precedent to State Restoration.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Via St. Johns, N.F., we have two days' later news from Europe, brought by the steamship Columbia, from Galway, Jan. 5. It is positively stated that the Austrian Archduke MAXIMILIAN will visit Paris and depart thence before the end of March, for Mexico, taking with him large reinforcements for the French army. The Schleswig-Holstein difficulty was daily becoming more aggravated, although there was no danger of a collision between the Federal and Danish troops, the latter having completely retired from Holstein territory. The French Legislature on the 4th inst. presented an address to the Emperor, pacific in its tone regarding Russia and Poland, hopeful of beneficial results from French intervention in Mexico and China, and commendatory of the scheme for a Peace Congress. The London Daily News asserts that the recent extraordinary mission of Marshal FOREY to Washington resulted in an understanding that the United States Government should not interfere in the new Mexican Monarchy, and in return it was believed that France would refrain from intervention in our affairs. The pirate Florida had completed her repairs at Brest, and was anchored near the U.S. gunboat Kearsage, expecting to leave the port in February. The French Government adheres to its determination of enforcing the twenty-four hours' rule. The indictment against HENAN and KING had been removed for trial to the Court of Queen's Bench. It is announced that four new steamers, 2,500 tons each, are to be placed on the line between New-York and London. The sale of chances in the lottery for the steamship Great Britain was progressing rapidly.

abstract: Those who have read THACKERAY  cannot have forgotten his descriptions of that class of large-nosed gentlemen to whom young men who have been living too fast, and have sudden and urgent calls for ready money, are too apt to apply for aid. As our readers
lead_paragraph: -- Those who have read THACKERAY cannot have forgotten his descriptions of that class of large-nosed gentlemen to whom young men who have been living too fast, and have sudden and urgent calls for ready money, are too apt to apply for aid. As our readers will recollect, these gentry never can raise quite the amount which the spendthrift requires in cash, but they are apt to have a little nice wine, or a picture, or a horse, or some knickknack which they can throw in to make up the amount, and which is so cheap that they would not let it go except to oblige a friend, &c.

abstract: Prof. Twining's Letter on
snippet: Prof. Twining's Letter on
lead_paragraph: We publish in another part of this morning's paper, an able and interesting communication from Prof. TWINING, of Yale College, on the plan by which Mr. ASHLEY in Congress propoeses to restore the Union. Its main purpose is to insist upon the necessity, in order to secure the welfare and stability of the Union, of regenerating the governments and political institutions of the rebel States before restoring them to their old place in the National Union. The writer commends President LINCOLNS plan as eminently wise and just; while he objects to the seventh section of Mr. ASHLEYS bill, that it may place the State Governments again in rebel hands. That section, after providing fully for the formation of a free Constitution, and stipulating against any assumption of the Confederate debt and other abuses, enacts that when a majority of the legal voters of the State shall adopt that Constitution, it shall be received and proclaimed by the President to be the constituted government of said State. Prof. TWINING, in the article referred to, objects that by such a provision the rebels may again get possession of their State Governments.
headline: {'main': 'Restoration of the Union.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Restoration of the Union.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the Senate various bills and resolutions of minor importance were presented, -- to establish a system of vaccination in the District; to establish a Bureau of Emancipation; to abolish the color qualification for mail-carriers; for the construction of a ship-canal around Niagara Falls. The resolutions of thanks to Gens. HOOKER, MEADE, HOWARD, BURNSIDE and BANKS were passed. The resolution prescribing the oath to be taken by Senators was made the special order for to-day. The resolution for the expulsion of Mr. DAVIS was referred to the Judiciary Committee. Mr. POMEROY introduced a bill to incorporate the North American Land and Emigration Company, the object of which is to encourage emigration and agriculture. The Enrollment Act was taken up, and, after various verbal amendments, was passed -- ayes, 30; noes, 10. Adjourned.

abstract: Winslow, Richard H. Will of
snippet: Winslow, Richard H. Will of
lead_paragraph: The object of the trial is to test the validity of the will of the late RICHARD H. WINSLOW, long a member of the well-known banking house of WINSLOW. LANIER & Co., in New-York, but shortly before his death a resident of Westport, Connecticut. Mr. WINSLOW marred, in 1829, a Mrs. ROBERTSON, of New-York, by whom he had three daughters. In 1852, he went to Paris, leaving his wife and children in this country, and when in Paris lived what is usually termed a "gay" life, residing there with one of the fair inhabitants of that place and passing his time in a doubtless pleasant but not very moral manner. Mrs. WINSLOW brought a suit against him in the State of New-York for divorce, on the ground of adultery, and obtained a decree in April, 1863 ???o defence being interposed by him. This appeared in evidence on the trial, the record of the divorce with all the evidence of the offence being produced and given in proof to the jury.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from, our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day. the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: -- Our letter from Japan gives a clear account of the situation of affairs up to the first of November last. The order for the expulsion of foreigners had been modified to a request to have them remove to Nagasaki and Hakodadi, places at the extremes of the Empire. This request was made at a private audience granted the American and Dutch Ministers at the Capital, Yeddo, and these functionaries at once replied that they should not comply with the request. When the other foreign representatives heard of the demand, they expressed a like decision, and when sent for to come to Yeddo, knowing what the authorities wanted, they declined to go. In the meantime, other efforts are making to drive foreigners from the country. Such restrictions are being placed on the production of, and traffic in tea and silk; that the native merchants are relinquishing the business and removing to Yeddo. The Government says if foreigners do not remove, civil war will certainly ensue, and some of the Princes seem to be seceding and confiscating at will. One of them had seized three Government steamers, while passing through his waters, as indemnity for the loss of those by the U.S. frigate Wyoming, last Summer, on the ground that the Government, not he, should be the loser. The settlement of matters in that benighted country does not look like one of the speedy events of the future.

The Government says if foreigners do not remove, civil war will certainly ensue, and some of the Princes seem to be seceding and confiscating at will. One of them had seized three Government steamers, while passing through his waters, as indemnity for the loss of those by the U.S. frigate Wyoming, last Summer, on the ground that the Government, not he, should be the loser. abstract: The steamship Morning Star, from New-Orleans Jan.12, arrived at this port last evening. On the day of her departure a very important proclamation was issued by Gen. BANKS, calling for an election of officers for a State Government, to be held on the 22d of February, under the provisions of the Amnesty Proclamation.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Morning Star, from New-Orleans Jan.12, arrived at this port last evening. On the day of her departure a very important proclamation was issued by Gen. BANKS, calling for an election of officers for a State Government, to be held on the 22d of February, under the provisions of the Amnesty Proclamation. On the evening of the 9th, a very enthusiastic and numerously attended meeting was held at the St. Charles Theatre, for the purpose of taking steps to organize a State Government. The weather at New-Orleans for a week had been unprecedentedly cold. No army movements are reported.

abstract: O'Neil vs. Glynn; False Imprisonment by Policeman
snippet: O'Neil vs. Glynn; False Imprisonment by Policeman
lead_paragraph: John O' Neil vs. Christian F. Glinn. -- Action to recover damages against the defendant, who is a member of the Metropolitan Police, for the illegal arrest and imprisonment of the plaintiff on the 9th day of August last. The plaintiff called upon defendant to take care of a man who was, of a Sunday evening, lying intoxicated upon the sidewalk near the plaintiff's house, in East Twenty-eighth-street, which defendant refused to do; whereupon the plaintiff made complaint at the Station-house in Thirty-fifth-street; but being treated with more indignity, if possible, by those in charge at the Station-house than by the Policeman, he told them he knew the way to Headquarters, and then went home; and as he chanced to be on the street shortly after, and near his own house, without a warrant, without a charge and without even an explanation, he was arrested by the defendant and taken to the Station-house and locked up till the next morning, when he was taken to Jefferson Market and discharged by the Magistrate without even an open charge having been made against him by the defendant or any one else. Justice ALKER charged the jury that if they found from the evidence that the intoxicated man was lying on the sidewalk, that it was the plaintiff's right, it was his duty, especially on a Sunday evening, to notify the Police of the fact, that he might be taken care of, and calling on the defendant, who was on duty near by, if he refused to attend to the intoxicated man, it was the plaintiff's duty to report him; and if on plaintiff's return from the Station-house he aid or said nothing in the presence of the officer, which was or tended to a breach of the peace, then the defendant had no right to make the arrest, and the jury should find a verdict for the plaintiff; and in, finding for the plaintiff they should accord such damages as would hereafter learn policemen to do their duty.

abstract: Supplies of the, Failure of; Government, New Attempt to Reform at Albany
snippet: Supplies of the, Failure of; Government, New Attempt to Reform at Albany
lead_paragraph: We are about to witness another attempt at Albany to mend the City Government, by transferring the election of the Aldermen to the City at large, and the management of the public works, including the street-cleaning, to a commission to be composed, as the Croton Board is, or as the Police Commission is to be. How this scheme will work, if carried out, we have too much regard for our reputation to venture to predict, after having witnessed the failure of so many attempts to make New-York a well-ordered, well-managed place of abode. But appearances are certainly in favor of that portion of the new plan which gives all the citizens the privilege of voting for every Alderman. This will, in the first place, secure candidates who are generally known either for good or evil, and who have some claim to prominence or distinction. The great difficulty with which municipal voters have to contend under the present system is, that men present themselves without hesitation for the suffrages of a Ward, who would not have the hardihood to ask for the votes of the whole City, and who are generally so obscure that nobody except the regular politicians knows anything either of their character or of their antecedents. When the Aldermanic ticket has, however, to be put into everybody's hands, people will not be satisfied with merely Ward busybodies or celebrities, but will insist on having candidates -- and will have those who are prominent New-Yorkers -- well known to all the inhabitants, just as the Mayor has to be, either for honesty, and capacity and public spirit, or for the reverse. We venture to predict that under this regime the Board of Aldermen at least, would undergo a great transformation -- that the pot-house oracles would disappear from it, and men of more intelligence, better character and social position take their places; though we admit that all this might happen, and the "honorable Board" still remain a very extraordinary and by no means creditable assemblage. By enlarging the area from which any man or body of men is elected, we always secure greater talent and higher character, and we believe the rule applies even to Aldermen. The provision of the new law which makes the Councilmen represent Assembly Districts, is, of course, a desirable change for the same reason, though in a less degree.
headline: {'main': 'Reform of the City Government.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Reform of the City Government.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Police, ever active in good and generous works, have held a meeting, at which Inspector CARPENTER was Chairman and J. S. MCWATTERS, Secretary, with a view of aiding in the success of the Great Fair to be held in this City, in behalf of the Sanitary Commission. They transacted some preliminary business, and adjourned to meet next Saturday evening. It is understood that all institutions, all societies, all churches, all trades, all professions, all branches not mercantile business, all organizations, literary, charitable, political, and otherwise, will enter into a generous rivalry, in aiding in this Great Fair. It will undoubtedly be the greatest that the world has ever witnessed; it is the intention to make it so from the humblest occupation to the highest. The only difficulty is the securing of a proper location. The Academy of Music will prove altogether too small -- and who ever heard of its being called too small before? -- and yet where else can the Fair be held? Palace Garden will not furnish 100m enough. What is to be done to meet the necessities of the oocasion? Why, trust to the Committee who will do the beat they can, and whose intelligence and energies are lent to the perfecting of this great event.

abstract: rough and tumble Fight
snippet: rough and tumble Fight
lead_paragraph: -A domestic insurrection on a very small scale seems to have broken out in Richmond. The irrepressible FOOTE, formerly of Mississippi, now of Tennessee, who was always in a row of some sort while at Washington, and who does not seem to have changed his habits one whit in this respect by going to Richmond, had a rough and tumble fight on the 6th with Judge HANLEY, of Arkansas, Chairman of a committee engaged in the investigation of frauds. It seems that FOOTE laughed at some of the evidence elicited. Now, laughing may be of different kinds, and may mean very different things; and nothing is more likely to be misconstrued. Judge HANLEY did not know exactly what to think of this particular laugh of FOOTE, -- but he took the liberty of remarking to him that he needn't laugh. FOOTE did not seem obliged to him for the permission, but contented himself by defining his laugh as an "honest laugh at least." Judge HANLEY did not quite understand what he meant by that, but he ventured to say that he "doubted it." Thus arose a casus belli -- using the word in a military and not in an anatomical sense. FOOTE "arose and struck" Judge HANLEY -- to use the graphic phrase of the Examiner. "Both clenched and blows were given and received by both parties." Violent claims were mutually laid to the contending shirt-bosoms: tables were overturned: the recorded evidence was scattered, and one of the Commissaries present was knocked into a corner "like a man of rags" -- says the historian, "which he is not." The bystanders observed strict neutrality by seizing the coat-tails of the combatants with rigid impartiality. Both were torn off, and in this bobtailed condition the contest closed. It seems not at all unlikely that the Confederacy itself will ere long present the same appearance and come to a similar end.
headline: {'main': 'WHAT CAME OF A REBEL LAUGH.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'WHAT CAME OF A REBEL LAUGH.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There is no rule of evidence better settled than that what a man says against himself, his plans and his prospects, is more worthy of belief than what he says in his own favor.
lead_paragraph: There is no rule of evidence better settled than that what a man says against himself, his plans and his prospects, is more worthy of belief than what he says in his own favor. Now and then, it is true, a man may be met who takes too unfavorable a view of his own condition and prospects, but he is a rare bird. And when we find different stories told by men engaged in the same enterprise, we naturally give credit to that one which is most unfavorable.

abstract: JERRY KEHOE, an old man, indicted for manslaughter, in killing DENNIS MAHONEY, plead guilty to manslaughter in the fourth degree, and was remanded for sentence. This case was that of a stabbing affray growing out of political differences as to the merits of Mr. MORGAN JONES as a candidate for Alderman. The parties met in a bar-room at No. 57 Oak-street on Dec. 9 last, and got into an altercation as to what had been done on the previous election day, when the prisoner drew a knife and stabbed the deceased, inflicting a wound from the effects of which he died. After disposing of this case, the Court adjourned.

abstract: Hammer vs. Barnes; Hammer Ale Case
snippet: Hammer vs. Barnes; Hammer Ale Case
lead_paragraph: Adolph Hammer vs. Charles Barnes, impleaded with Marsh and others. This case, which was recently decided by Justice MULLEN, on the demurrer, in favor of the plaintiff, was called for trial yesterday on the question of the measure of damages due Hammer from the defendants. The plaintiff is the celebrated Harlem brewer, and the action is brought to recover damages for the improper disclosure of certain valuable secrets in the art of brewing. The defendants are brewers in Albany, and they purchased from the plaintiff the secret, known in this country to Hammer alone of brewing ale that would keep in hot weather without souring, and using in the manufacture 25 per cent of ma[???]t and hops. For this secret, to discover and perfect which Mr. Hammer had spent a great deal of time and money, defendants paid a large sum, and gave bonus not to impact it to any other parties than those to whom it was absolutely necessary to give it in order to carry on their business. Plaintiff alleges that the defendants broke their agreement with him, and imparted the knowledge of the process to other parties, whereby plaintiff has been damaged to the amount of $35,000. He obtained an injunction against the defendants, restricting them from imparting the secret to any others, and the question of what amount of damages he is entitled to now comes up. The case has excited considerable interest, owing to the heavy amount involved and the decision of the interesting question that a secret which cannot be patented can yet be of such value to the owner that he can recover damages from parties to whom he has imparted it for a valuable consideration upon pledge of secrecy.

abstract: "Your medicinal preparation (Brown's Bronchial Troches) is certainly valuable to soldiers in the field, and I feel satisfied, if generally adopted at the hospitals, many sleepless nights of the weary soldier would be averted. Our regiment are now testing their qualities, and I believe are all satisfied with their good effects in alleviating those distressing affections of the throat arising from cold and exposure. They are now daily prescribed in our hospital and at the surgeon's morning call." Sold everywhere at 25 cents per box.

abstract: Emigration from the South
snippet: Emigration from the South
lead_paragraph: Among the troubles which seem just now to be perplexing the Southern rebels, that of keeping their able-bodied citizens from running away seems to be conspicuous. Gov. SMITH, the newly inaugurated Governor of Virginia, thinks it a matter of "concern" to see their citizens seeking to evade military duty, by leaving the country for foreign parts, and he suggests the propriety of refusing passports and of making very stringent laws on the subject. The Confederate authorities will, doubtless, take good care not to go too far legislating on this delicate subject. They may themselves hare occasion to go abroad before long, and may have conscientious scruples about violating the laws of the land even to accomplish the highly important result of saving their own necks. Some action on the subject, however, is fast becoming imperatively necessary.

abstract: Railroad Accidents
snippet: Railroad Accidents
lead_paragraph: The American railroad system, in regard to speed and safety, has been brought so near perfection, that for a long time the traveling public have enjoyed immunity from those fearful accidents which, eight and ten years ago, so frequently sent thrills of anguish and horror through the land. But recently, railroad matters seem to have got out of joint, and we have chronicled at least half a dozen serious accidents on leading lines of travel within the past ten days, most of them attended with serious loss of life. The weather may have had something to do with this -- frost, and snow and ice are sometimes barriers which reasonably account for delays and accidents -- and it may be mere chance which precipitates half a dozen of these calamities into the space of a week. But we fear the vigilance of some of our railroad managers has suffered relaxation, and that the enormous press of business and travel, and the consequent flow of money, has induced criminal indifference to the comfort, safety and accommodation of the public. And we may take this occasion to say that the management of several of the most important roads leading out of this City, particularly the management of the local accommodation trains, is attended with so much irregularity and apparent carelessness, that people dependent upon them travel back and forth with fear and trembling, feeling that their lives are risked at almost every trip. If the public sense should be appalled by some sudden and fearful calamity, these railroad managers would and should be held far from guiltless. There is great room for improvement in the management of most of the roads leading out of New-York. Let those in charge see that the improvement is made as a measure of justice to the public, and not wait for it to be prompted by some frightful disaster.

abstract: IRON-CLADS ABOUT TO GO INTO COMMISSION.  The ERICSSON iron-clads Tecumseh and Mannahatta, now finishing at the yards of Messrs. SECOR  Co., Jersey City, are about going into commission.
lead_paragraph: IRON-CLADS ABOUT TO GO INTO COMMISSION. The ERICSSON iron-clads Tecumseh and Mannahatta, now finishing at the yards of Messrs. SECOR Co., Jersey City, are about going into commission. The Tecumseh, which is nearly completed, is 235 feet in length, 40 feet in width, and 13 feet depth of hold. Her model is similar to the Weehawken, but she is of larger dimensions, having a, measurement of 1,434 tons. The forward part of the interior of the vessel is to be used as a store-room where supplies will be delivered from the upper deck by a windlas. The Commander's cabin and Captain's apartments immediately adjoining the store-room, will be elegantly furnished. In the wardroom there are seven state-rooms, all well lighted, which are to be occupied by the First Lieutenant, Chief Engineer, Ensigns, and Masters. The port gangway and turret blower engine rooms are separated by a partition of iron, and are admirably adapted for the purpose for which they are intended. The turret-room contains four engines, two for the turret, and one for each blower. Connected with them are the requisite store-rooms and the officer's round-house. The berth deck, between the turret engine room and coal bunkers, is a large and commodious apartment intended for the crew. Attached to it, on the port side, are the apothecary's room, paymaster's office, hammock and bread rooms and galley. On the starboard side of the vessel the magazine and crews' round-house are located. Adjoining them is the main entrance to the engine room, attached to which are bunkers with a space for 160 tons of coal each. The Mannahatta is similar in every respect to the Tecumseh. The 15-inch turret guns have been placed in position, and it is expected both vessels will be ready for sea as early as March next.

abstract: This question is asked, in public and private, a hundred times a day, and but few of the answers are ever based upon any sound reasoning or reliable facts. It is in small, almost insignificant occurrences and expressions that the true condition of the rebellion, and that of the people of the South, is most truly indicated. A Richmond paper of a recent date announces with extreme gratification the arrival of one hundred live fat hogs in the neighboring city of Petersburgh, styles it a "very pleasant kind of invasion," much more agreeable than to be "invaded by a hundred lean, slab-sided Yankee prisoners," coming to eat pork instead of producing it. Another article recommends a plan by which every portion of the cattle and hogs slaughtered for the use of individuals and the army may be made available, and significantly adds that in "many portions of the States the supply of these animals is exhausted." Thus, day after day, these little irrefutable indications of the condition of the rebellion manifest themselves in a plain, unprejudiced manner, and are worthy, therefore, of general credence. Let those who study the progress of the war carefully note these certain developments, and they can obtain an idea of how soon the war will end, which will be far more reliable than if based on almost any other reasoning or hypothesis. The people of the South are so despotically ruled, that their demands for peace will be stifled so long as there are bayonets at the command of the rulers. But as the progress of our armies narrows still more closely the country on which they depend for food, actual starvation, now threatened, will become an inevitable fact, unless submission to the rightful Government is promptly accorded. So long as the lines of the armies of the rebellion covered the States of Kentucky, Tennessee, Arkansas and Texas, the weapon of starvation was one on which we could place no dependence. But the condition of affairs now justifies the public in placing some dependence on the indubitable evidences of a speedy dissolution which appear from time to time in the rebel journals, and which they cannot repress if they would.

abstract: An exempt fireman gives the following graphic account of the death of GEORGE W. BURRIDGE, of Engine Co. No. 42, at the late fire in Duane-street, and thrillingly details the heroic conduct of Mr. WM. CORGAN, assistant foreman of the same company. The company were stationed to the rear of the building, on Reade-street. The engine was put to work, and the hose got on a twelve-inch wall, which ran parallel with the building on fire, and which wall was fifty feet in height from the area or yard below. Mr. BURRIDGE had the pipe, by which he directed a stream into one of the upper windows of the building on fire. After some time it became apparent that the rear wall would fall. Orders came for No. 42 to back down. Poor BURRIDGE at this moment, while in the act of shifting the pipe to a brother member, came in contact with the stream, which, being very powerfull, knocked him off the wall into the abyss below. The rear wall of the building on fire was then crumbling and apparently going to fall. The members commenced to run toward Reade-street. At this time the Assistant Foreman of No. 42, Mr. WILLIAM CORGAN, got upon the wall, immediately tied the drag-rope around himself, gave the end to some of the members of the Company and others on the wall, lowered himself into the abyss below, disengaged himself from the rope, tied it around poor BURRIDGE, placed the body in a perpendicular position with the back against the wall, and cried out to them above to hoist up, which they did, and got the body safely over the wall. Mr. CORGAN was now placed in a terrible position, the rear wall, five or six stories in height, about to fall on him, and no means of escape. On looking around him he saw a high wall toward the eastern side, surmounted by an iron railing. To get over this wall was his only chance for life. He succeeded in reaching the top, and was just getting over the rails when the walls fell, and, as supposed by all present, the brave CORGAN was killed. They were about to commence extracting him from the ruins, when of a sudden he made his appearance among his brother firemen. Among the many heroic deeds performed by our firemen, there are few that parallel this one of CORGAN's.

abstract: Non-payment of Bounties to
snippet: Non-payment of Bounties to
lead_paragraph: 0-- There is a very loud and just complaint on the part of our reenlisted veterans, who have come to their homes in this City on a brief furlough, at the shameful manner in which they are treated respecting the non-payment of their bountymoney. The difficulty, we are informed, is altogether attributable to the neglect of the regimental and company officers, who nearly always fail to bring with them from the army the evidence of the reenlistment of their men. Without these enrollment papers, duly signed by the Commissary of Musters at Washington, the County Supervisors' Committee can in no instance pay the bounty. This certificate of reenlistment forms the only voucher by which the Committee can regulate its action, and the only proof upon which the volunteer can be credited to the quota of the county. Yet we are told that it is next to impossible to make the regimental officers and the authorities at Washington understand this simple matter, by which a world of annoyance and hardship would be spared the noble fellows who have served the country faithfully through one long term of service, and are cheerfully offering themselves for another.

abstract: the Restoration of
snippet: the Restoration of
lead_paragraph: The wheels have started. The work of bringing back the "Confederate" States has begun. Maj.-Gen. BANKS, under the authority of the President, has issued a proclamation to the loyal citizens of Louisiana, providing for an election of Governor and other State officers on the 22d of February next, and the installment of such officers on the 4th of March; also, for an election of delegates, on the first Monday of April, to a Convention for the revision of the Constitution. He has taken this step on the assurance that more than one-tenth of the population desire the speedy reinauguration of civil rule on the basis of the Amnesty Proclamation of the President, and that the movement will be carried through in absolute good faith to the National Government.
headline: {'main': 'The Restoration of Louisiana.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Restoration of Louisiana.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our correspondent at Havana, under date of Sunday last, says "the rebel steamer Isabel, under the Spanish flag, arrived here yesterday from Mobile in four days, with a cargo of cotton. According to the Mobile papers of the 5th an attack of the Federal troops against that place was at that time shortly feared. There was also a report...
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent at Havana, under date of Sunday last, says "the rebel steamer Isabel, under the Spanish flag, arrived here yesterday from Mobile in four days, with a cargo of cotton. According to the Mobile papers of the 5th an attack of the Federal troops against that place was at that time shortly feared. There was also a report current in Mobile that the rebel steamer Gray Jacket, which left that port with 600 or more bales of cotton, had been captured by the Government cruisers. Hopes were, however, entertained that she had escaped on account of her extreme quickness."

abstract: War Expenses, Mr. Wood's Bill to Reimburse
snippet: War Expenses, Mr. Wood's Bill to Reimburse
lead_paragraph: -- Ex-Mayor WOOD's bill for reimbursing New-York City the expenses she has incurred in raising troops to aid in suppressing the rebellion, deserves favorable consideration. The principle which it embodies is essentially just, and if the time for bringing it forward is premature, the fault must be laid at the door of those who took the lead in the matter. The claim of Pennsylvania was the first one brought forward, -- naturally enough, as Pennsylvania is seldom behind hand in pressing claims of any kind upon the National Legislature. We concur with those members who thought it would be quite as seemly and proper for all the States to postpone their demands until the war was over. We are engaged just now in a common struggle, -- one in which all the States have a common interest and no question of separate and subordinate concern should be permitted for a moment to interfere with the devotion of the national energies to the prosecution of the war. The suggestion that a general bill should be passed, providing for the auditing and settlement of all such claims, and for their payment when the war is over, is a good one, and is far preferable to the enactment of laws for each individual case. All the States would then stand upon the same footing, and each would be sure to receive what was justly its due, without delaying or encroaching upon the claims of its sister States. But if Congress does not see fit to pass such a general law, we trust that the claims of New-York will not be postponed to those of any other city or State.

abstract: GERMAN OPERA. Mr. RICHARD WAGNER'S opera of the "Tannhauser" was played last night, for the second time, at the Academy of Music. The director was Mr. CARL BERGMANN, who some years since brought out the work at the Stadt Theatre, where it was a complete failure.
lead_paragraph: GERMAN OPERA. Mr. RICHARD WAGNER'S opera of the "Tannhauser" was played last night, for the second time, at the Academy of Music. The director was Mr. CARL BERGMANN, who some years since brought out the work at the Stadt Theatre, where it was a complete failure. Since then, the general public has become familiar with the overture, and through that brilliant pot pourri, with the principal themes of the opera. The advantage of this acquaintance was noticeable last night in frequent and genial bursts of applause. Indeed, we have seldom seen an audience that was more attentive, respectful, and quick to appreciate. We are heartily glad that it was so, not from any particular love of WAGNER, but because we should be sorry to see a New-York audience guilty of the rudeness and obstinate blindness that characterized the Parisian audience when this opera was first produced in the gay metropolis of la belle France. The least we can do for a man of study and long effort, is to give him a patient hearing.

abstract: Banks, Forcible Collection of Taxes from
snippet: Banks, Forcible Collection of Taxes from
lead_paragraph: The readers of the TIMES remember that, early last year certain City Banks succeeded in a suit against the county, by which so much of their capital as was invested in United States stocks, issued since Feb. 25, 1862, was exempted from taxation by virtue of a clause in an act passed on that date... of a clause in an act passed on that date. The costs of the litigation the Supervisors are yet paying, as the different Banks obtain judicial orders commanding payment of their bills. The success of these Banks imposed the burden of their taxes upon the county, and as the valuations of property for the year had been fixed and the taxes levied, the uncollectable amounts charged to these Banks could not be raised on the tax of that year -- 1862. The Atlantic and National Banks, and the Bank of Commerce, refused to pay taxes on any portion of the capital invested in United States securities, and twelve other banks refused to pay the tax assessed upon the portion of their capital stock which was invested in Government securities, issued since Feb. 25, 1862. The following table shows the names of all the Banks that declined to pay, and the losses which their action occasioned:

abstract: Rutherford, Special Agent on Naval Race
snippet: Rutherford, Special Agent on Naval Race
lead_paragraph: Considerable interest was created in naval circles yesterday, by the announcement of the fact that a Mr. RUTHERFORD had arrived from Washington, empowered by the Navy Department to negotiate for a race between the United States steamer Eutah, and the steamer King Kiang, the latter built in this City for the China trade. A letter of Mr. DICKERSON, published in the New-York morning journal of yesterday, stating that "the engine of the Kin Kiang was made from Mr. DICKERSON's drawings, in respect to which said engine differs from ordinary ones," attracted the attention of the Navy Department. Mr. RUTHERFORD's instructions were to make of the owners of the vessel, the Messrs. OLIPHANT, the following inquiries:

abstract: Clark's Patent Steam and Fire Regulator Company vs. Wm. Noyes. -- This was a suit to restrain defendant from infringing reissued letters patent, granted to complainants for "a new and useful improvement for regulating the pressure of steam in steam-boilers." A preliminary injunction was heretofore granted in this case, and it now came up for a final hearing. The Court said a decree must be entered in this case for the complainants. The objection that they have no existence as a Corporation is not well founded. They became a corporation under the laws of New-York, and have never been dissolved. Whether they have done or omitted to do anything by reason of which they might be liable to be dissolved, in proceedings taken against them for that purpose, it is immaterial here to inquire. I have no doubt the patent is a good and valid one. The invention is useful and meritorious. It has been sustained after a full and laborious trial at law, and with the verdict rendered on that trial I was and still am, after mature deliberation, satisfied. Let a decree be entered making the injunction perpetual.

abstract: Desertion in the Rebel Armies
snippet: Desertion in the Rebel Armies
lead_paragraph: They have a curious use of military lan guage down in Dixie. What we call deser tion, they now call absenteeism and strag gling. It would seem that the evil has taken such proportions, and become so formidable, that it will no longer do to apply a harsh name to it. Concerning its exact magnitude, authorities differ. The Mobile Register declares that there are "two hundred thousand stragglers." The Atlanta Intelligencer, probably with more correctness, makes one hundred thousand the number of those "now absent from their commands." Taking even the smaller figure, it is a most significant token of the demoralized condition of the rebel armies. It really is of as much account as many great victories on our side, for it would take many such victories to reduce the rebel strength in any such measure.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. SHERMAN submitted the report of the Commissioner of Agriculture, adverse to the proposed tax of 20 per cent, on leaf tobacco. The Senate then resumed the consideration of the rule requiring an additional oath to be administered to Senators. Mr. JOHNSON, of Maryland, addressed the Senate in opposition to the rule, because he thought it was not required by the Constitution. Mr. HOWARD favored the rule. Mr. FOOT only discussed the expediency of it. He thought the oath was already required by the law of 1862. Without concluding the subject, the Senate adjourned to Monday next.

abstract: Diplomatic Correspondence, the
snippet: Diplomatic Correspondence, the
lead_paragraph: We copy from the volume of diplomatic correspondence, just sent in to Congress, sundry dispatches of interest concerning our relations with Great Britain. The whole is too voluminous for publication, and we are well aware of the impossibility of giving a clear and complete view of the case by such extracts as we are able at present to publish. But the papers contained in this sheet will at least indicate the nature of the questions at issue between the two Governments, and the temper and spirit in which they have been discussed.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday and received a communication from the Mayor in re lation to a complaint from merchants near West Washington Market, that the Central Park and North and East River Railroad Company had di rected their employes to sweep dirt from the tracks into the street, causing obstruction and in convenience to persons doing business down town. The Mayor suggests that the railroad ...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday and received a communication from the Mayor in re lation to a complaint from merchants near West Washington Market, that the Central Park and North and East River Railroad Company had di rected their employes to sweep dirt from the tracks into the street, causing obstruction and in convenience to persons doing business down town. The Mayor suggests that the railroad companies be compelled by ordinance to cart away the dirt accumulating on their tracks. The Mayor also communicated that Major-Gen. DIX has taken possession of the Park Barracks as a "military necessity" for the reception of returned soldiers;' that Gen. DIX had given him assurance that the barracks would be cleaned, and that the General renewed a request made some months ago, for permission to the United States to erect barracks on the Battery. A resolution by Mr. BRANDON, to direct the Street Commissioner to remove, the Park Barracks, for the reason that "they have become a nuisance," was referred. Another message was received from the Mayor, proposing that the Legislature be memorialized for an act creating a $5,000,000 fund, to be raised on an easy time loan, to lay Belgian payment wherever it is not now laid on streets below Fourteenth-street. The Board changed their hour of meeting to 1 o'clock P. M. Ad[???] and to Monday.

abstract: Gigantic Schemes--Soap Bubbles--of
snippet: Gigantic Schemes--Soap Bubbles--of
lead_paragraph: It appears that it is beginning to dawn upon the economists of the Confederacy that the extraordinary proposition made by JEF- FERSON DAVIS in his last Message, that the $500,000,000 of excess in the currency, and the $200,000,000 required for the war expenses of the coming half year--seven hundred mil lion dollars in all--should be raised at once by a tax, is tantamount to the confiscation of all the real estate in his jurisdiction. The scheme when it first made its appearance excited unmixed astonishment here as well as in Europe, as its emanation from a personage ordinarily so shrewd and so skillful in covering his weak points as JEFFERSON DAVIS, proved better than anything else could the desperation of his position. What is, however, still more astonishing is, that the rebel Congress has actually taken it up, and embodied it in a bill; and another bill which is also before them, and certain to pass, provides for the drafting of every white male in the Confederacy of the military age. So that those of the unfortunate white men of the South, who happen to be at present inside the rebel lines, will, in a few weeks, be liable to be called on for seven hundred millions of dollars, and will, at the same lime, be forced into the ranks of the army. Of course, the money cannot and will not be paid. No such sum could be raised on a similar area of the South in a time of profound peace, and with industry undisturbed; it is, therefore, hardly necessary to say that the notion that it can be raised now, after three years of bloody war, and at the moment when every man capable of firing a musket, (whether he is able to march or not,) is on the point of being dragged from his home, is simply ridiculous.

abstract: --The London Correspondent of the Irish Times writes: "There are some whispers that the private life of the Emperor of the French is not at the pres- ent time the happiest. It may be that the insurance of the Emperor's life in the London offices for a large sum is the foundation of the rumor; but another bit of gossip also tends strength to the report.
lead_paragraph: -- The London correspondent of the Irish Times writes: "There are some whispers that the private life of the Emperor of the French is not at the present time the happiest. It may be that the insurance of the Emperor's life in the London offices for a large sum is the foundation of the rumor; but another bit of gossip also sends strength to the report. It may not be altogether forgotten that before the Emperors marriage he had held for many years intimate relations with a Mrs. HOWARD, by whom he had two children. When the Emperor married, the lady was handsomely provided for and sent to England, where before long she was married. The marriage did not turn out a happy one, and Mrs. HOWARD returned to Paris. There is no doubt that this lady had the character of being very clever, und of advising Louis NAPOLEON at the desperate crisis in his fate in such a manner as, when acted on, led ultimately to his elevation to the French throne. Nor long since it was announced that the Emperor was in the habit of leaving Complegne late at night by special train, and appearing in Paris; it now appears that Mrs. HOWARD is the attraction, and that alter a lapse of years she hag resumed her sway over Louis NAPOLEON's mine, and is once more his counselor-in-chief. Hence, perhaps, the whispers of the hour lake their rise.

abstract: Jose Fraschieris vs. David M. Henriques and Thomas F. Ferris -- The plaintiff in this action, tried for the second time, alleges that in September, 1857, at Havana; Cuba, he consigned to the defendant; David M. Henriques, a large quantity of cigars, [???] bark Lyra. That said cigars were not landed in New-York until the 1st of October. 1857; that said Henriques was, on the 1st day of September, 1857, insolvent and unable to pay his debts, which fact Henriques fraudulently concealed from the plaintiff, and represented himself to be in prosperous circumstances, in order to obtain credit from the plaintiff for said segars; that after Henriques became in solvent, he executed a transfer of his property to defendant Ferris. Plaintiff notified both these defendants that he claimed the property before they bad removed it from the Custom-house, which notice they disregarded; he therefore brought the suit for $40,000. Defendants deny that plaintiff consigned any segars to them, but allege that they purchased the segars of plaintiff that he drew bills on them for the amount, and obtained the money for these bills in Havana, and defendant Henriques denies that he was insolvent or made any fraudulent representations. These bills, draws by plaintiff, were accepted by defendant Henriques, and be claimed that be had a lien on them to save himself from loss. On the first trial before Judge BRADY, the complaint was dismissed for want of proof, but on appeal to the General Term a new trial was ordered.

abstract: The desperate legislation of the rebel Congress, though not yet fully perfected is bringing out defiant threats of resistance from different por- tions of the Confederacy. The North Carolina papers in particular are very bitter, while from Georgia also come warnings to the tyrants at Richmond. The Raleigh Standard openly defies ...
lead_paragraph: The desperate legislation of the rebel Congress, though not yet fully perfected is bringing out defiant threats of resistance from different por- tions of the Confederacy. The North Carolina papers in particular are very bitter, while from Georgia also come warnings to the tyrants at Richmond. The Raleigh Standard openly defies the execution of the measures proposed, and says if they prevail, "the people of North Carolina will take their own affairs into their own hands, and will proceed, in Convention assembled, to vindicate their liberties and privileges."

abstract: Damages for Illegal Captures
snippet: Damages for Illegal Captures
lead_paragraph: -- We had occasion some time since to call attention to the position of the law as to claims for dam- ages by the owners of vessels wrongfully captured as prizes. The Circuit Court in this City, in the case of the Empress, had held that it was not within the province of our Prize Courts to decree costs and damages to the claimants, even when they decreed the restitution of the property to them.

abstract: -- The family of Archbishop WHATELEY have undertaken the preparation of a Memoir of his Life. It will, in a measure, be autobiographical -- consisting mainly of his own memoranda, correspondence, &c. A volume of miscellaneous Memoirs from his Commonplace Book is also announced, and a selection from his unpublished sermons. Dr. WHATELEY'S published writings make him one of the most voluminous authors of the day, and his mental activity appears to have remained unabated to the last.

abstract: Diplomatic Cor. on our Relations with
snippet: Diplomatic Cor. on our Relations with
lead_paragraph: As we read the important diplomatic correspondence of which we have before spoken, we shall all breathe freer, in seeing how near at one moment this country was to a war with Great Britain. During the fitting out of the iron-clads, our people were roused up to the highest pitch of excitement, and even the remotest western communities, as well as the commercial sea-border, felt that an open war could hardly be worse for us than this secret piratical warfare waged from British ports. Mr. SEWARD, in his remarkably bold and spirited dispatch of July 11, only spoke the universal popular judgment, when he said the Confederate pirates, under the British flag, should be treated as if they were public enemies, and that all damages inflicted by them must be indemnified by the British Government. The very distinct threat accompanying this expression was justified by the feelings and reason of the whole nation; that is that the pirates should be considered as British cruisers and pursued into British ports by the naval forces of the United States. Nothing was possibly left to us, consistently with our national dignity, but this summary proceeding, which would have been tantamount to a declaration of war with Great Britain. With the six fast and powerful iron-clads afloat on the ocean, receiving supplies and coal from English colonial ports, our commerce would have been almost ruined, our ports open to attack, and the blockade often interrupted. A general naval war with England could scarcely have been worse, while the opportunity for reprisals and plunder on every sea would have been incalculably greater.

abstract: Question of Permanancy of
snippet: Question of Permanancy of
lead_paragraph: The question of permanent confiscation which is now engaging the attention of the House, is one of very great moment. It will be remembered that the original measure concerning confiscation, which passed Congress eighteen months ago, made a general sweep of the property of rebels, both real and personal, and for all time. The President returned the bill with objections against that clause making confiscation of real estate extend beyond the lifetime of the traitor, because of its doubtful constitutionality. The clause was modified, so as to confine the confiscation to the life interest; and in that shape became a law. A strong effort is now being made to restore the clause to its original shape, so as to make the confiscation permanent. The matter has become one of immediate practical importance. A large amount of real estate, belonging to rebels, is now in the hands of the Government, and in justice to the National Treasury, as well as to the neglected property itself, some disposition must be made of it. But if anything more than a life interest is to be transferred, new legislation is necessary before the sale.
headline: {'main': 'Permanent Confiscation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Permanent Confiscation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Explanation of Votes
snippet: Explanation of Votes
lead_paragraph: -Hon. Mr. GRISWOLD, the Democratic Member of Congress from the Renssalaer district of this State, voted recently against laying on the table the resolutions of Mr. ROGERS, of New-Jersey, for negotiations with the rebel authorities. In the House a day or two afterwards, he explained that he did so under a misapprehension; that he was utterly opposed to sending Commissioners to Richmond, and saying that in his judgment "any offer at the present time on the part of the Federal Government, to negotiate or compromise with rebels defiantly in arms against that Government, would be unpatriotic, unwise, and only pernicious in its tendency." This shows pretty clearly that Mr. GRISWOLD does not intend to be drawn, by party relations, or any other influences, into hostility to the Government in its prosecution of the war.

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Aldermen, yesterday, a resolution by Mr. OTTIWELL was adopted, for the appointment of a Committee to confer and act with Mayor GUNTHER and Mr. SANDFORD in extending a suitable reception to the returned veteran soldiers of this City, who have renlisted and are now here on furlough. A communication was received from the Comptroller, stating that since his estimates for the City appropriations for 1864 were made, a resolution had been passed by the Common Council, and approved by the Mayor, increasing the wages of all Corporation laborers from $1 75 to $2 per day, and that this action necessitated an addition to several of the items to his budget to meet the increased expense. It was referred to the Finance Committee. City Inspector BOOLE's Annual Report for 1863 was received and ordered to be printed. It may be found entire in the official proceedings. The report contains earnest recommendations for the reforms heretofore suggested by Mr. BOOLE to the Common Council. The Mayor transmitted a long communication from THOMAS N. CARR, being his rejoinder to Mr. BOOLE's reply to the charges made a short time ago against the management of the City Inspector's Department, and It was referred to the Special Committee on Be trenchment and Reform. Mr CABR says that BOOLE and the reputed "Alqermanic Ring" have combined to "break down the Mayor," and pro poses JAMKS R. WHITING, Judge BOSWORTH and WM. CURTIS NOYES as a Committee to make honest investigation of his charges, or that the "Astors, Stewarts and men of that class unanimously petition the Legislature for power to examine, through a Committee of their own selection, and to recommend all needed amendments to the charter. The Board adjourned to Friday, at 2 o'clock P. M.

Never were a people, apparently, so completely taken by surprise; never did the excellent plans either of mice or of men gang so completely aglee.
