abstract: GERMAN OPERA. -- The second performance of "La Dame Blanche," last evening was, in all respects so thoroughly delightful, that we find ourselves unable to add a single word in the way of criticism. We may, however, ask a question. Do people know that this is one of the most celebrated and remarkable of semi-modern operas? The German public is acquainted with the fact, but all other publics (except, of course, the French,) seem to be strangely ignorant of it. BOLDIEU IS one of the positive geniuses of his period. He is as absolute in this work as MOZART is in "Don Giovanni." No comparison is intended in this remark, and, in fact, no comparison is possible. But BOILDIEU is a man who will live, and ought to be known to a musical community as well as MOZART is known.

abstract: CONCERT AT THE FIVE POINTS HOUSE OF INDUSTRY,--An informal concert was given in the chapel of this useful institution last Friday, for the children of the House and their parent. The room was still decorated with its Christmas greens and flags. Mr. HALLIDAY, the Superintendent, acted as chairman, and several members of his family constituted a quartette choir which, with a piano accompaniment, led the performance. The music included instrumental ...
lead_paragraph: CONCERT AT THE FIVE POINTS HOUSE OF INDUSTRY,--An informal concert was given in the chapel of this useful institution last Friday, for the children of the House and their parent. The room was still decorated with its Christmas greens and flags. Mr. HALLIDAY, the Superintendent, acted as chairman, and several members of his family constituted a quartette choir which, with a piano accompaniment, led the performance. The music included instrumental solos, comic songs, chorus songs, &c., which were rendered with much spirit and success. But the most interesting part of the performance was that of the children. Two of the little girls sang several duets with remarkable truth and case. The whole of them joined with most editing and vigorous enthusiasm in the choruses, and always save their laughter and applause with ready from at the right points. The little folks were under excellent di[???] their childish chat and movements instantly ceasing at the signal of the Superientendent. Perhaps the most thoroughly appreciated of all the exercises was the final one, the distribution of a great basset of New Year's cake, by the Kindness of a good friend of the institution. The musical exercises were varied with a curious callisthenic performance during which the twinkling fingers and waving arms of the children, keeping time above their heads, produced singular effect. Such an exhibition of good manners and musical feeling and attainments by the children of this locality, is a powerful testimony to the great value and good management of the House of industry, as conducted by Mr. HALLIDAY. Among the friends present was Capt. FLETORES of the fifteenth Massachusetts Volunteers, one of four brothers, all soldiers, of whom one was wounded at Ball's Bluff, one killed at Antietam and one killed at Gettysburgh; while the Captain himself was shot through both cheeks at the latter place and left for dead on the field.

abstract: Pembina dates to Jan. 4 have been received at St. Paul, Minn. Gov. DALLAS had not only given the Indians provisions and transportation to get them to leave, but actually supplied them with 300 pounds of powder and a proportionable amount of balls. This is more British neutrality that should be remembered. Forty-seven Sioux men and their families came in and surrendered themselves to Maj. HATCH, rather than risk the Winter on the plains. They are from Little Six's and Little Crow's bands, and one of them claims to be a brother of Little Crow. The Chippewas showed their friendship by killing six Sioux before they left the settlements.

abstract: The news from Chattanooga is encouraging. Trains are now running regularly between that place and Nashville. The arrival of supplies is large, and full rations are again issued to the troops. A large number of recruits are constantly arriving, sufficient to balance the number of Veterans going home. The desertions from the rebel army are very numerous, 150 deserting at one time on Monday last. The rebel army at Dalton is reported to be 30,000 strong, and so reduced in supplies that they are killing their best mules for supplies of meat. Gen. GRANT arrived at Chattanooga yesterday morning.

abstract: Chesapeake Case; The Delay at Halifax
snippet: Chesapeake Case; The Delay at Halifax
lead_paragraph: -We had hoped before this that the case of the steamer Chesapeake, before the Admiralty Court at Halifax, might have come to some conclusion. The case was adjourned till last Wednesday, but was then from some of the multifarious causes of the law's delay, postponed still further. There can, however, be no doubt as to what will be the ultimate result of the case. The intimation given by the Judge some time ago, that under the facts before him he should treat the case as one of piracy, was a very strong one, and it is also quite plain that the Court will not lend any countenance to that feeling which led some of the citizens of Halifax to sympathize with, and even to aid, the villains who had run away with the vessel. He referred to them as men who had "violated the proclamation of neutrality," who had "grossly and wilfully, and stealthily" violated the rights of neutral territory, and violently resisted officers seeking to execute process, and were then fugitives from justice. No Court would speak thus, if it were not determined to pass upon the case in accordance with the rules and acquirements of justice, and without reference to any false public feeling in favor of the men -- and certainly it should be so. Where, of all[???] places, should such an outrageous act of violence be frowned upon, if not in an Admiralty Court, the Court which administers the law of the sea, and has especial guardianship of the rights and immunities of peaceful navigators?

abstract: Expedients--Dictator, Protectorate, >amp;c.
snippet: Expedients--Dictator, Protectorate, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The rebel leaders are like rats in a trap. On every side they see the iron bars of their cage daily closing in upon them. Their strength is becoming exhausted, their materials are wearing out, their hopes are growing fainter, and they rage up and down their narrow limits, with such desperate exertions to strengthen themselves against their coming fate, with such diverse and wild plans for escaping from the toils which are around them, and with such rage and inexpressible hatred in their hearts against those whose strength and skill, undreamed of by them, have brought them to such straits, that the sight is not a pleasant one to look at. One's ideas of the nobility of man, one's hopes for the triumph of the gentler virtues on the earth -- of the reign of righteousness and peace and love among men, seem at first to be wholly outraged by such an exhibition. But when we think of the future and of all the hopes for it, which are brightening with every ineffectual struggle of theirs, when we think of what it is which has brought them to such straits and of the peace and liberty for this nation and for all mankind which are to be secured or at least hastened by their destruction, we cannot but rejoice to see how every day the pressure comes heavier upon them and the day of retribution draws nearer.

abstract: Caught in Boston
snippet: Caught in Boston
lead_paragraph: -- The Bostonians have caught a rare legal curiosity -- a barrator -- and they seem as tickled over their prize as a child with a new toy, and as delighted as AGASSIZ would be if the discovery of a new species of insect were announced. The lawyers have got the "barrator" in Court, and impaling him, as a wicked boy would a fly, upon the sharp point of their quips and quirks, they hold him up to the admiring gaze of a thronged Court-room, while the newspapers devote column after column to the proceedings, noting every twist and turn of the case as accurately as a surgeon jots down the, motions of a victim undergoing the operation of vivisection.

snippet: De Baretellen, C. V., the Man of the North and the South; Reade, Charles. Very Hard Cash; Round the Block; Hopkinson, Mrs. C. A. Hints for the Nursery; Kirk's, J. F., History of Charles the Bold; Angel Voices; New Edition
lead_paragraph: work like GIBBON's Decline and Fall, or MACAULAY's England's if not the product of absolute genius, requires for its elaboration a combination of qualities almost as rarely met with as genius itself. How few the world possesses of books of this class a little consideration will show. They may almost be enumerated sin a breath; but a place hardly second in public estimation and actual usefulness is always open to men of average intelligence who, with taste, leisure and research, publish the results of their investigation of any special period of its annals. To this class, by far the larger proportion of the standard histories that fill our shelves belong -- as Lord MAHON's England, TYTLER's History of Scotland, ALISON's EUROPE, MERIVALE's Roman Emperors, and others; books that the world could not well afford to lose, but which have certainly been produced without the exercise of those higher qualities of mind that go to make up the ideal historian. So voluminous have become the original authorities for every period of recent history since the growth for the modern rage for printing State papers, correspondence, and all the documentary material on which the narration of facts is founded -- so wide a range has ethnology and archology given to the studies of classic times, that the entire history of a country or State becomes too serious a task to be performed by one man, and the Monograph, devoted to the illustration of a particular reign or period, will undoubtedly be the prevailing form for future writers of history.

abstract: A number of regiments which have reenlisted have been arriving in Nashville from the front during the last two or three weeks, on their way home to enjoy the thirty days' furlough accorded properly to reenlisted soldiers. abstract: Reply to "Perfectionists" at Norfolk, Va.
snippet: Reply to "Perfectionists" at Norfolk, Va.
lead_paragraph: -- Maj.-Gen. MCPHERSON, in command at Vicksburgh, will soon get as unenviable a reputation as Gen. BUTLER once enjoyed, if be does not display a little more gallantry in his treatment of the ladies. The following is the substance of an order which he recently issued: "The following named persons -- Miss Kate Barnett, Miss Ella Barnett, Miss Laura Latham, M ss Ellen Martin and Mrs. Moore, having acted disrespectfully towards the President and Government of the United States, and having [???]ted the officers, soldiers, and loyal citizens of the United States who had assembled at the. Episcopal Church in Vicksburgh on Christmas Day for divine service, by abruptly leaving said church at the point in the service where the officiating minister plays for the welfare of the President of the United States, and all others in authority, are hereby banished and will leave the Federal lines within forty-eight hours, under penalty of imprisonment. Hereafter all persons, male or female who by word, deed or implication, do insult or show disrespect to the president Government, or flag of the United States, of to any officer or soldier of the United States, upon mailers of a national character, shall be fined, banished, or imprisoned, according to the grossness of the offence."

abstract: The Metropolitan Fair in aid of the Sanitary Commission, which is to be held in this City, is eliciting the interest and exciting the pride of our merchants. It was mentioned the other day in the TIMES that all the different Trades, all the Professions, all the Societies, political, social, benevolent or otherwise, all the different public offices, and the ever generous Metropolitan Police, had determined to lend their liberality and their efforts to its consummate success. Our merchants are now moving; committees of the different branches of their business have been appointed, and they are taking steps to nobly respond to the call. They have already been largely called upon. Chicago, Cincinnati, Boston, Brookiyn, have all, we believe, made calls upon them, and not in vain. Let each and all remember that their own City will soon appeal to them; of their Plenty they will give -- give beyond precedent, it is hoped and expected. While responding to the calls from abroad, let an eye be kept on the call which will soon be made from home. This Fair must be the greatest the world has ever known; it must be, both in its array of goods and its results a wonder, and unparalleled. These are strong expressions; the liberality and the patriotism of New-York will show that they are not misused.

abstract: Object System of Teaching in Industrial Schools, (C. L. B.)
snippet: Object System of Teaching in Industrial Schools, (C. L. B.)
lead_paragraph: The great difficulty in all teaching is the liability of falling into routine -- both teachers and scholars going on in a mechanical manner, without any invention on one side or much activity of the mental faculties on the other. There are peculiar obstacles also in the teaching of young children, from the fact that children's minds work so much through their senses, while our common systems are so much addressed to their memory and abstract powers. Then, the English language is a dreadful undertaking in itself, for a child, there being so little analogp and so many exceptions and irregularities in its construction. Learning the letters has no connection with the sound of them; spelling has scarcely any relation with reading, and the sound of one word is very little guide to another, spelt exactly alike. When the child's mind reaches such a study as geography the whole subject of a map is a mystery to it; the relation of the points of compass on a diagram and the points in the streets about him being en exceedingly difficult subject to grasp at first. "Definitions," of course, are the last conquest of even a mature mind, and as they are usually taught in primary schools, they are a perfect absurdity. So the first idea of a standard of weights and measures, and the meaning of numeration, is very hard to convey in the beginning to the child.

abstract: There are at present two bills before the State Legislature incorporating companies to run street railroads one of them down Lexington-avenue and through Gramercy Park, and the other across the City near the City Hall. This description, of course, gives no idea of their tortuous wanderings.
lead_paragraph: There are at present two bills before the State Legislature incorporating companies to run street railroads one of them down Lexington-avenue and through Gramercy Park, and the other across the City near the City Hall. This description, of course, gives no idea of their tortuous wanderings. We shall not attempt to enumerate all the streets through which they are to run, as we doubt if a list of the streets through which they are not to run would not occupy a very much smaller portion of our space. We mention them, however, not for the purpose of either objecting to or approving of their course, but of calling attention to the fact that in neither of the bills is there the smallest provision for the comfort of the public or protection of their rights. The sole condition attached to the grant of these valuable franchises is that the fares shall not be over five cents. There is not one word about the number of cars to be run, the number of seats they are to contain, the number of passengers who may be crammed into them, or, in fact, a single restriction or proviso as against the companies. The only provisos in the charters are directed against the Mayor and Common Council, with the view of giving the companies the complete and uninterrupted monopoly of the tracks. The pending attempt to assert the doctrine that the rails may be used by the public has probably suggested some of these precautions. At all events, as the matter stands, these companies bid fair to get complete possession of most of the streets on the east side of the town, driving off all other public conveyances, and rendering the use of private carriages increasingly difficult and dangerous, and upon condition that they shall carry people in any posture they please, for five cents a head.

abstract: -- The Rev. A.P. STANLEY has resigned his Professorship at Oxford and has taken leave of the University on the acceptance of his promotion as Dean of Westminster, in a sermon entitled "Great Opportunities," which is said to be among the most striking pulpit discourses of modern times. The text is taken from Luke xix: 41, 42, and the subject is the lesson conveyed in the words, "Neglected Opportunities," first to individuals and then to collective bodies, as the University he was then addressing.

abstract: A meeting of the old members, relatives and friends of the Forty-fifth regiment. New-York Volunteers, was held last Thursday evening, 21st inst., at No. 83 Allen-street, for the purpose of making preparations to receive this Veteran regiment, which is now on its way home from the Army of the Cumberland, to enjoy the furlough of thirty days. The entire regiment has reï¿½nlisted for three years. The meeting was well attended, and it was resolved to give the regiment, on arriving here, a reception worthy of these gallant men for their many brave actions during the war, and for their most patriotic offer to serve three more years for the suppression of the rebellion. This regiment was organized in this City in August, 1861, and consists almost entirely of Germans, many of them previous to their organization having served with the Fifth regiment New-York National Guard during their first three months' campaign at the beginning of the war. It was raised under the auspices of the Union Defence Committee, and especially under the pecuniary patronage of one of our most patriotic citizens -- Mr. ELIAS HOWE. It has seen very hard service; and from the original number of about one thousand men, it is now redhead to about 450. It participated in the campaign in Western Virginia, under Gens. FREMONT and POPE; afterward under Maj.-Gen. SIGEL in his Summer campaign of 1862, (battles of Cedar Mountain and Bull Run.) and was then transferred to the main corns of the Army of the Potomac. Afterward, it took active part in the battles of Chancellorsville and Gettysburgh. After the return of the Potomac army to the soil of Virginia, it was transferred with the Eleventh corps to the Cumberland army, and earned new laurels in the capture of Lookout Mountain under Gen. HOOKER.

abstract: Duty of Aiding
snippet: Duty of Aiding
lead_paragraph: Patriotism in the City of New-York, or in any of our home communities, is a comparatively cheap and easy virtue. We go about our business as usual, eat our dinners, entertain our friends, enjoy amusements, and make money very much as we always have done. It is true, we subscribe to the Sanitary Commission, or invest in Governments, or make an occasional eloquent speech on our "glorious Union;" but on the whole, so far as our comfort and ease are concerned, the great American civil war might as well be in China.

abstract: Anglo-Maorian War
snippet: Anglo-Maorian War
lead_paragraph: Judging from the comments of the British press on our American campaigns, one would suppose that, in war, a General had only to find out his enemy, and fight him; but it appears from the way in which the British themselves have been carrying on war in New-Zealand that this off-hand mode of conducting military operations is not at all times desirable. For months Gen. CAMERON has been encamped, with a strong force, almost within sight of the Maorian position at Mere-mere, yet he has not, until now, once ventured to assail it. On the contrary, instead of making a grand effort to crush the main body of the enemy, and to end the conflict by a single blow, he has been converting his troops into guerrilla bands and training them to combat the natives with their own weapons. This style of strategy may prove more effective against the Maorics than a more imposing system; but, though great things ate expected from it, recent occurrences rather seem to indicate that the anticipation has not hitherto been realized. The events of the Fall would, in fact, be hardly deserving of notice, did they not tend to illustrate the efficacy of the bushwhacking system alluded to. The organization of what are termed "flying columns," whose duty it is to scour the country in detached bodies, and to cut off marauding parties of Maorics, has certainly not deterred the natives from "planting ambuscades" and surprising the troops. On the 2d of September, for instance, an outlying picket from the Queen's Redoubt -- Gen. CAMRRON's Headquarters -- consisting of sixty of the Royal Irish, under Lieut. DAWSON, were suddenly attacked in the rear by a party of Maorics, and though the soldiers charged, repulsed, and pursued them to a considerable distance, still, on returning to their original position, they were assailed by another party, and had not Capt. LE POER FRENCH, of the Fortieth, come to their assistance, they might have been compelled to retreat. On the 7th of the same month, a yet more striking illustration of the boldness of the natives, and of the supineness of the "flying columns," occurred near Cameron-town. An escort, conveying provisions and military stores to the camp in canoes, was fired on by a large body of Maorics near the above-named place; three Europeans and two aboriginal loyalists were killed, and both the canoes and their cargoes fell into the hands of the victors. This, however, is not the Worst. The firing attracted the attention of the commander of a neighboring redoubt, who dispatched fifty men in the rescue. On approaching the Maorian ambuscade, they charged, but were met by so sharp a fire that they had to give ground, leaving the Captain and three privates dead, and a number wounded. Nor is it improbable that the whole detachment would have been slaughtered, had it not been for the gallantry of a Sergeant, named MCKENNA, who rallied the men, and, at their head, forced his way through the thick of their assailants with the loss of only one of his band.
headline: {'main': 'The Anglo-Maorian War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Anglo-Maorian War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At St. Peter's Church, on Friday, a solemn High Mass Requiem was held for the repose of the soul of the late Archbishop HUCHES. On this occasion the Celebrant was Rev. WM. QUINN, Pastor of the Church; Deacon. Rev. M.A. MADDEN, Madison, New-Jersey; Sub-Deacon, Rev. Mr. COWRON, Staten Island; Master of the Ceremonies, Rev. Mr. MAGUIRE. The whole of the altar and sanctuary were hung with black cloth festooned with white, In the middle aisle was a coffin covered with a black pall. on which was a large white cross. Surrounding the coffin were twelve wax candles. Within the sanctuary were seated Rev. Dr. Cummings, Rev. Dr. Neligan, Rev. P. Conway, Ireland; Rev. M. Cunan, Rev. P. Farrell, Rev. Wm. Clouny, Rev. A. Donnelly, Very Rev. P. Moran, Newark, N.J., and Rev. Jas. Moran. Among those present in the body of the church were Mr. MICHAEL HUGHES and Mrs. RODERIQUE, brother and sister of the late. Archbishop. The choir, under the direction of Mr. PECHER, the organist, sang some most delightful music; the most noticeable were the Dies Iroe and Lacrymosa choruses of MOZART. The offetory Libera nic Domini, composed by Mr. PECHEE, was also excellently rendered. The principal singers in the choir are Mrs. Easton and Mme. Chome, sopranos; Miss Gebbelle and Miss Hutchings, alto; Mr. Hubnertenor, and Mr. Urches, basso.

abstract: Is the backbone of the rebellion broken? To judge by some speeches in Congress, and some articles in the newspapers, the backbone of the rebellion has been broken a hundred times, and was speedily to be broken a hundred times more. In overcoming any difficulty, great or small, the first duty is to confront it squarely. The ostrich is no model ...
lead_paragraph: Is the backbone of the rebellion broken? To judge by some speeches in Congress, and some articles in the newspapers, the backbone of the rebellion has been broken a hundred times, and was speedily to be broken a hundred times more. In overcoming any difficulty, great or small, the first duty is to confront it squarely. The ostrich is no model for a rational man. Do we want more soldiers? Is there a necessity for a draft? Is it true, or is it not, that the nearer we approach the end, the more pressing becomes our need of a large army? And is it true, or not, that the more efficient we make our army, the more time, money, blood, and life, we shall save.

abstract: -- The Portlanders have got up another sea-fight in a fog. The Argus of Tuesday morning says that on the forenoon of the preceding day, about 10 o'clock, two steamers were seen off Spurwink, Cape Elizabeth, between Bluff and Stratton Islands, and both fired several times, apparently at each other. Some dozen shots were exchanged in all, when one steamer apparently made for the other. This is the account given by a gentleman who was at Spurwink and with cased the filing, though the fog and smoke prevented him from seeing the movements of the steamers directly.

abstract: Reunion after Civil Wars
snippet: Reunion after Civil Wars
lead_paragraph: There are many who still doubt the possibility of a restoration to union and quiet, even after the rebellion is subdued. A "subjugated" people; they say, can never be relied on. A glance at our revolutionary history may be the best thing to reassure us, though, in fact, all history abounds with instances of great disaffection turning to order, and the spirit of rebellion forever vanishing, underthe reign of just law.

abstract: London Times on Federal Affairs
snippet: London Times on Federal Affairs
lead_paragraph: In an article printed Jan. 5, the London Times sets forth, in its best style of Pro-Slavery grumbling, the alleged facts which convince it that the war is apparently interminable, and that the situation of affairs at the close of 1863 proves that no progress at all is made toward its conclusion. "It is evident," remarks the seer, "that the Fedeeral possession of Eastern Tennessee, even if it can be maintained, will not bring the war nearer to a conclusion." The Richmond papers are of a different opinion, as is Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS. These think East Tennessee the key to the whole military position, because they know it admits the holder into any one of their remaining States, unless they can keep the door shut by sheer superiority of force. "The blockade of the Southern coast," snarls this rheumatic Giant Grim of the press, "does not deprive the people of an ample supply of imported articles." Here, again, the Richmond prices current tell a very different story. 'Tis distance lends enchantment to the view. Those who live inside of the celebrated Southern Confederacy are of opinion that imported articles are most awkwardly scarce. Mr. DAVIS, for instance, in his last message, intimates that Wilmington is the only port left open at all, and that that is in danger of being closed. "Goods to the value of a million dollars arrive in Wilmington every four-and-twenty hours," avers the dissatisfied London giant. Of a million rebel dollars possibly. These are worth, delivered in New-York, from six to eight cents a pound avoirdupois to work over. But surely the Times is moderate. Why does it not repeat the last rebel report on this side that steamers were running into Wilmington twenty-three in one night? Why strain at a gnat? But most awful of all is the final groan of the Times over the expense at which "abolition" is prosecuted. These are its words:

abstract: 'The news from Chattanooga is encouraging. Trains are now running regularly between that place and Nashville. The arrival of supplies is large, and full rations are again issued to the troops. A large number of recruits are constantly arriving, sufficient to balance the number of veterans going home. The desertions from the rebel army are very numerous, 150 deserting at one time on Monday last. The rebel army at Dalton is reported to be 30,000 strong, and so reduced in supplies that they are killing their best mules for supplies of meat. Gen. GRANT arrived at Chattanooga yesterday morning.

abstract: The HARRISON English Opera Company is meeting with the most encouraging success. Its continuance is placed beyond peradventure by a steady prosperity that leaves nothing bet a larger house to be desired. The performance at Niblo's Saloon on Thursday evening was attended by a really brilliant audience, sufficient in every way to indicate that the "Bohemian Girl" is yet an attractive opera with the musical public. On the following night, at the Park Theatre, when WALLACE's "Maritana" was given, the house was densely crowded, and hundreds were unable to gain admission. In the latter work an exceedingly interesting debut was made by Miss MYERS in the part of Lazarillo.
lead_paragraph: The HARRISON English Opera Company is meeting with the most encouraging success. abstract: Levy en masse, Jeff. Davis Proposed; Condition of the
snippet: Levy en masse, Jeff. Davis Proposed; Condition of the
lead_paragraph: Toward the conclusion of every war there are indications which announce the ability of a nation to carry on hostilities with the force of positive demonstration; and no concealment of facts, or falsification of events in official documents, can hide the condition of a country thus circumstanced. Everything from the South indicates a speedy termination of the rebellion. The population is exhausted by a war that has not accomplished a single object for which it was commenced. Everywhere its armies have been driven back by the steady advance of the Federal forces. They have lost the Mississippi, and the States of Missouri, Arkansas, Kentucky, Tennessee, and a large portion of Virginia and Louisiana. Their armies are everywhere on the defensive. The people are suffering for the necessaries of life; their ports are blockaded, their currency worthless, and the population insufficient even for the purposes of a defensive war. Above all, the spirits of the soldiers are no longer hopeful. The people are beginning to grumble. Not long since Gen. MAGRUDER advised his men to hang every one who hinted that "this was a poor man's war for the rich man's benefit." The message of JEFFERSON DAVIS to his rebel Congress, and the reports of his Cabinet officers, admit by their despondency of tone, and the desperate measures they advise, the hopelessness of their situation.

abstract: The steamship Etna, from Liverpool on the 8th and Queenstown on the 7th of January, arrived at this port yesterday. Her news is two days later than that telegraphed from St. Johns, N.F., brought by the Columbia. The journals contain nothing striking concerning American affairs, with the exception of the London Times, which, in a characteristic article, endeavors to show that the Federal successes have been no successes at all, and consequently the war is apparently as little near the ending as ever. The Birmingham Post says that Mr. BRIGHT was directly instrumental in getting from Washington a mitigation of the sentence of the pirate RUBERY, who was convicted at San Francisco. The Schleswig-Holstein question continued to be exciting:, and there were increased apprehensions of an outbreak. On the afternoon of the day the steamer left Queenstown, however, the telegrams from Germany were less unfavorable, and a report had gained currency not only that proposals for conference had been agreed to by France and England, but there is reason to believe they will be accepted by the German Powers. The King of Denmark, who has been visiting the divisions of his troops, had issued an address to his army, and had ordered 14,000 men of the re-reserve to be called out. The text of the address of the Corps Legislatif of France in reply to the speech from the throne was read on the 4th. The unpopularity of the Mexican expedition is attested by the report of the Supplementary Credits Committee, which unanimously expresses the hope that an end should be put to the matter as soon as the honor and interest of the country will permit; News has reached England in rather a round about was that

abstract: The Armament of the
snippet: The Armament of the
lead_paragraph: The "statement" which we published a few days ago in reply to our query as to the armament of the monitors, leaves that query still equally pointed and pertinent, while at the same time it contains some assertions not at all reconcilable with the received opinions as to the superiority of rifled ordnance over the smooth-bore gun for distant firing. We would premise, however, that it neither was nor is our intention to dogmatise as to the absolute value of the 15-inch smoothbore as compared with the 8-inch rifle. Each has beyond a doubt qualities that render it more effective for special work than the other. Nor do we claim that either type of gun should be used in the armament of the monitors to the exclusion of the other. In fact, what we have complained of, and still complain of, is that the bureau of ordnance and construction is doing this very thing, as in the case of several of the new monitors confining their armament to the 15-inch smooth-bore, in face of the demonstrated superiority of the heavy rifle for the kind of work which the iron-clads are intended to perform in Charleston harbor.

abstract: Through the vigilance of Surveyor ANDREWS, Marshal MURRAY, and the Inspectors of Customs, the shipments of merchandise to "contraband ports," to be there reladen and run through the blockade, has virtually ceased. These officers have been untiring in their efforts to have this illicit trade broken up, and the guilty parties punished. Upon all vessels now loading for Southern ports, for Nassau and other ports of similar character, the cargo is rigidly examined by the inspectors, and the chances of goods contraband of war escaping their vigilance are few, and far between.

abstract: THE BROOKLYN FIRE DEPARTMENT. -- The total number of men drafted into the military service from the Fire Department of the Western District, and whose commutation was paid by the city, was forty. At a meeting of the Board of Officers recently held, the Committee on the subject made their report to the above effect. The Chief Engineer stated that two or three bills had been introduced into the State Legislature in regard to the Fire Department. Last year a bill had been passed, by which the entire yearly expenditure of both departments was limited to the sum of $50,000. He did not think the sum sufficient -- $100,000, he contended, would not be too much for the purpose. In the discussion which ensued, it was stated that the salaries of the different officers, which amounted to about $16,000 a year, was included in the appropriations. The amount is nearly equally divided between the Eastern and the Western Districts, although the latter department contains five times as many men as the former. Three new companies had been organized during the year, and it would take at least $12,000 from the funds to purchase lots and build houses thereon. In view of this fact a resolution was adopted requesting the Fire Commissioners to organize no more new companies without consulting the Board of Officers. A resolution was also adopted providing for the appointment of a committee of three to proceed to Albany, and consult with our Representatives in regard to the bills now before them. The Foremen of Engines Nos. 5 and 14, Hose No. 2, and Hook and Ladder No. 5, were appointed such Committee.

abstract: MASS MEETING OF WORKING JEWELERS. -- A mass meeting of the working jewelers of New-York was held at 2 P.M., yesterday, at No. 113 1/2 Bowery, for the purpose of forming a protective union. The meeting was organized by electing Mr. L.N. NATHAN Chairman, Mr. HONSTETTER BIRELING Secretary, and Mr. STRIBBEL Treasurer. After a pretty full discussion, all present enrolled their names; a brief adjournment to draft resolutions was had, and a series was adopted, providing for the election of delegates from each shop, with powers to act for the common benefit, and to prepare a proper constitution and bylaws. The meeting then adjourned.
lead_paragraph: MASS MEETING OF WORKING JEWELERS. -- A mass meeting of the working jewelers of New-York was held at 2 P.M., yesterday, at No. 113 1/2 Bowery, for the purpose of forming a protective union. After a pretty full discussion, all present enrolled their names; a brief adjournment to draft resolutions was had, and a series was adopted, providing for the election of delegates from each shop, with powers to act for the common benefit, and to prepare a proper constitution and bylaws. The meeting then adjourned.

abstract: We hope the Legislature will not, in the multitude of matters that demand its attention, overlook the subject of reform in the management of our State Prisons. It may not be feasible to adopt at once such a comprehensive system of reformation as the actual condition of these institutions requires, but in very many respects minor changes can be made that will be of very great importance. The whole subject of prison discipline and management needs a thorough revision. We are by no means certain that the steps taken by Government for the punishment of crime do not really increase itthere seems to be such an utter disregard of the elements and conditions that enter into this most complicated social problem. But it is not likely that we shall very soon have Legislatures made up of social philosphers or, what would be still better, of men competent and disposed to understand and apply the truths set forth by such philosophers, to the practical conduct of public affairs.

abstract: In the Senate Mr. SUMNER introduced a bill, supplementary to the act of 1862, requiring all persons admitted to practice at the bars of the United States Courts, to take the oath of allegiance. Mr. WILSON offered a resolution requiring the Committee on the Conduct of the War to inquire into the character and efficiency of the heavy ordnance now provided for the armament of fortifications. On motion of Mr. HALK, his resolution asking for an investigation of affairs in the Navy Department, was referred to a Select Committee of three -- Messrs.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is pub-  lished THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents.
lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Speech at Annapolis
snippet: Speech at Annapolis
lead_paragraph: -- We publish in another part of this morning's TIMES a speech recently made by the Postmaster General before the Maryland Legislature. It is an able and elaborate exposition and vindication of President LINCOLN's policy in the prosecution of the war against the rebellion, and especially of his recent Message and Proclamation. Unlike his former speech in Maryland, it avoids topics that have become matters of controversy among Union men, and cannot fail to command the assent and admiration of the public at large.

abstract: Via Halifax, we have received three days' later news from Europe, brought by the steamship Canada, which left Liverpool on the 8th instant, and Queenstown on the 10th. From Great Britain, we have intelligence of the birth of a son to the Prince of Wales, and of the favorable condition of the mother and infant. Judgment was to have been delivered in the case of the Alexandra on the 11th instant. The project of disposing of the steamship Great Eastern by lottery at Frankfort was not likely to be carried out the Frankfort Senate having refused to authorize the drawing. Dr. TURTON, Bishop of Ely, died on the 7th inst. From France we hear of the discovery in Paris of a conspiracy on the part of four Italians, whose object is not told. The conspirators were arrested, and at their residence were found a quantity of gunpowder, polgnards revolvers, air-guns, and sight hand-grenades of the ORSINI pattern. The Schleswig-Holstain question continues to wear a threatening aspect, and both sides were active in military preparations. It is reported that the Federal force in and upon the borders of Holstain numbered 60,000, and would soon reach 100,000. It was stated that Prince Angustenburg intended to declare Kiel a free port. The British [???] had addressed a f[???]th note to the federal Diat, urging a conference, and, upon the ples of protecting British interest, was about to dispatch a [???] of war [???] to the [???] waters. The Times regards the commencement of the campaign in [???] almost certain within a short time. The new ship [???] Wa[???] of Boston, was lost on [???] first voyage to liverpool, by during [???] on the [???] coast.

abstract: Rebel Designs in
snippet: Rebel Designs in
lead_paragraph: The news from Tennessee seems to indicate that a desperate attempt is about to be made by the rebels, during the coming month, to take advantage of the supposed reduction of our forces, by the furloughs granted to the veteran regiments reenlisting, and to regain some of their lost ground in Tennessee. There seems to be little question that advantage has been taken of the full in the operations in Virginia and at Chattanooga to reinforce LONGSTREET heavily for another attack on Knoxville, and MORGAN is to cooperate in the movement by a raid on the communications of the latter place, both with Chattanooga and with the West, by way of Cumberland Gap. Knoxville lost, it is hardly necessary to say that our position at Chattanooga would become in the highest degree precarious, to say nothing of the waste of the brilliant and cheaply-bought triumphs by which Gen. BURNSIDE acquired possession of the place last Summer.
headline: {'main': 'Rebel Designs in East Tennessee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Rebel Designs in East Tennessee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Additional dispatches from Chattaneoga confirm the reports of large desertions from the rebel armies. It is said that the proposition to conscript the rebel soldiers new in the army is causing them to desert in heavy numbers. Forty-six came in on the 21st, in one squad. One division of rebels has gone to reinforce Mobile. At Louisville, rumors prevail of an intended rebel raid into East Kentucky.

abstract: Broadway near Murray-street, Friday afternoon last, was the scene of a some what unusual occurrence, even for a city like New-York, abounding, as it does, in novelties and extraordinary events. At about 4 o'clock P.M., promenaders who happened to be passing in the vicinity of Murray-street, were thrown into an unwonted excitement by hearing the report of a pistol; by seeing the frantic efforts of the man who fired the shot to escape from the person fired at, who, covered with blood, cocked revolver in hand, rushed across the carriage-way through the crowd, knocking every one in his way aside very unceremoniously, evidently determined to summarily punish his would-be murderer. His career was suddenly arrested, however, by Lieut. WHITTAKER, of Gen. KILPATRICK's staff, who seized the infuriated man, wrenched the pistol from his hand, and handed him over to considerate bystanders for medical treatment.
lead_paragraph: Broadway near Murray-street, Friday afternoon last, was the scene of a some what unusual occurrence, even for a city like New-York, abounding, as it does, in novelties and extraordinary events. At about 4 o'clock P.M., promenaders who happened to be passing in the vicinity of Murray-street, were thrown into an unwonted excitement by hearing the report of a pistol; by seeing the frantic efforts of the man who fired the shot to escape from the person fired at, who, covered with blood, cocked revolver in hand, rushed across the carriage-way through the crowd, knocking every one in his way aside very unceremoniously, evidently determined to summarily punish his would-be murderer. His career was suddenly arrested, however, by Lieut. WHITTAKER, of Gen. KILPATRICK's staff, who seized the infuriated man, wrenched the pistol from his hand, and handed him over to considerate bystanders for medical treatment.

abstract: Rebel Enlistments in England; Earl Russell's Letter
snippet: Rebel Enlistments in England; Earl Russell's Letter
lead_paragraph: One of the strongest points against England, in the case of the Alabama, has been the fact that she was not only built by English workmen and with English money, but that she was manned with an English crew, recruited in England by rebel agents, for the very purpose of preying upon our commerce. This point has been repeatedly pressed by Mr. ADAMS throughout his correspondence with Earl RUSSELL, and that it was manifestly felt and found a difficult one to get over, is plain from the fact that it is not alluded to in Earl RUSSELL's letter of Dec. 19, 1862, in which the English side of the case is argued very fully. He meets the question of the furnishing the ship herself by the argument, such as it is, that there is no difference between a ship and a cannon, and that both the United States and the rebels have bought arms in England; and he argues very strenuously that the sarling of the vessel was "in spite of earnest endeavors made to enforce the law." But he does not allude to the point which Mr. ADAMS had made, that her "crew, her equipment and her arms were sent out to her by the same British subjects who built and dispatched her."

abstract: MOVEMENT TO RAISE WAGES OF MATES OF VESSELS. -- A meeting of ships' mates was called, last evening, at No. 227, South-street, to consider the question of raising their wages. But few persons were present, but some intelligent first officers made statements to our reporter, which have interest as showing that the general movement for larger wages is spreading among the seamen. It appears that first mates now receive the same pay as during eight or ten years past -- i. e., on packets, from $40 to $45 a month, while the seamen very often get larger wages by getting $60 or $70 advance on their wages of $30 a month, and leaving the ship at the end of their run. Mates also find their current rate of pay insufficient for the decent support of a family, almost all articles of common consumption having risen from 30 to 50 per cent., and some much more.

abstract: Yesterday morning the Court-martial, ordered by Gen. Dix, to try the officers belonging to Gen. SPINOLA's brigade who had enlisted men contrary to the rules and articles of war, met at the old police headquarters, corner of Elm and Broome-streets, for the purpose of trying JOSEPH A. KERRIGAN, Examining Surgeon, charged with passing men while in a state of intoxication and perfectly unconscious. To the charge the defendant pleaded not guilty. The Court consists of Capt. J. P. Lock-man, One Hundred and Nineteenth New-York; Capt. D. L. Sullivan, Sixty-ninth New-York; Capt. C. H. Vandervee, One Hundred and Forty-fifth New-York; Capt. J. J. Heam, One Hundred and Sixty-fourth New-York; Lieut. James Forrest, Seventy-third New-York; Lieut. K. Mooney, One Hundred and Fiftieth New-York; Lieut. C. Hunter, Twelfth New-York Battery, and Capt. Wright Rives, A. D. C., Judge Advocate. The counsel for the accused was Mr. MCKEON. who stated that Mr. KERRIGAN had received no commission from the War Department, having received his appointment from Col. SACKETT, and was, therefore, not amenable to the rules and articles of war. After deliberation, the Court decided that, having his name, as Examining Surgeon, to enlistment papers, he was liable to be tried by Court martial.

abstract: About a week ago, an account was given in these columns of a certain Rockaway Captain, commanding a sloop, who had induced a number of South-street merchants to loads his vessel with articles contraband of war for the purpose of running the blockade into Eastern Virginia, instead of which he ran into Rockaway, and there disposed of the goods on his own account. At least, so ran the rumor. But it now appears that Surveyor Andrews had an eye upon this sloop, and detailed some special officers to watch her, who, as the vessel slipped her moorings one dark night, and set sail without a permit from Marshal Murray, gave chase, and after a tedious search, found her at Northwest Inlet, Far Rockaway, where she lay, half filled with water and sand, and completely ice-bound. Upon inquiry, the officers found that the vessel had just touched at Near Rockaway, where she had discharged her cargo; and the Captain had disposed of the most salable portion of the cargo and pocketed the proceeds. The remainder is now in the possession of the Sheriff of Queens County, but how or why he should attach it has not been made plain. The sloop was named Amanda, commanded by JAMES FINDLAY, and was cleared for Cherrystone, Va. She was loaded with tea, indigo, pins, blacking, envelopes, writing paper, whisky, printed music, and a number of cotton cards. It was also stated she was carrying out a hoop-skirt as a present to Mrs. JEFFERSON DAVIS. Beside the cargo, a quantity of baggage was on board the sloop belonging to parties anxious to run the blockade, who were to get on board at some point off Long Island. They were not called for, and the baggage is held with the cargo.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen [???] yesterday. A message was [???] from [???]toing the resolution appointing about 200 Commissioners of Deeds to fill vacancies, because the limit of 300 of these officers in the City has been exceeded by 128. He recommends that application be made for a law legalizing all the acts of the Commissioners of Deeds serving, since, the number of them has exceeded 300. The Mayor prefaces his objections by saying that the resolution "is returned for the reconsideration of your Honorable Body. I have been advised by the Counsel to the Corporation, that there were doubts whether the appointment of these officers was a legislative act on the part of the Common Council, but that the magnitude of the interests involved in the regularity of proceedings before them, and the uniform course hitherto taken, made it expedient that I should take action in reference thereto."The law says the Common Council shall appoint, and the charter says all proceedings of the Common Council shall be by act, ordinance or resolution, and the Mayor is given the veto power over all their acts. By making objections to the resolution, the Mayor's communication is a veto on it, although he says he returns it for "reconsideration."The veto probably will be overruled. The Comptroller reported a balance of $2,771,553 20 in the City Treasury on last Saturday. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P. M. on Thursday.

abstract: His Steward and Chambermaid Desert Him
snippet: His Steward and Chambermaid Desert Him
lead_paragraph: An important rumor comes to us from Norfolk, Va. JEFF DAVIS' steward and chambermaid are reported to have arrived at that place direct from Richmond. About a year ago, when the rebel military authorities were impressing all the horses they could find in Virginia, Mr. DAVIS' coachman made his advent in Washington, perhaps because he found his occupation gone ; and the supposition is certainly reasonable that his ebony cola borers have followed his example for the same sufficient reason. The scarcity of provisions at Richmond has unquestionably reduced the larder of the head rebel to an exceedingly lean condition. What need, therefore, of a steward? And as it is authentically rumored that Richmond is even now in process of abandonment, what does JEFF DAVIS want of a chambermaid? Or, perhaps, with the proverbial sagacity of her class, this slave woman has forecast the fearful storm which is so soon to turn her former master out of his house and home, and has deserted his falling fortunes in time to achieve her own salvation.

abstract: Report of Battle of Antietam
snippet: Report of Battle of Antietam
lead_paragraph: -At last we have that section of Gen. McCLELLAN's report which gives the history of the battle of Antietam. It attempts an explanation of the failure to follow up LEE after the disastrous defeat which was there administered to him; but, with a whole year devoted to the task, Gen. McCLELLAN has failed to construct a defenses which the public will pronounce impregnable. He states that "the troops were greatly overcome by the fatigue and exhaustion attendant upon the battle of Sept. 17, together with the severe marches they had previously executed. Did any army ever fight a great battle, extending through one day, without becoming fatigued and exhausted? Yet there are numerous instances on record of partial victories having been triumphantly completed after two and even after several days' fighting. Then is there any reason to believe that LEE's beaten and dispirited troops were any less fatigued and exhausted than our own victorious men ? That excuse would more than have justified ROSECRANS in abandoning the field and the victory to BRAGG after the first day's bloody repulse at Murfreesboro. It is stated, too, that on the right, HOOKER's corps and one division of SUMMER's, had been driven back with heavy loss, and in disorder, and the troops there were consequently not deemed in a proper condition to renew the attack. The heaviest fighting, however, would naturally have taken place on the left, as the first movement would have been to cut LEE off from the Potomac; and Gen. McCLELLAN virtually acknowledges that this wing of the army was in good condition, when he states that only the new troops attached to it had their morale impaired by a repulse late in the day on Sept. 17.

abstract: Fifty-eighth Regiment; Reception and History
snippet: Fifty-eighth Regiment; Reception and History
lead_paragraph: The German population of the City, and especially the former officers and soldiers of this brave and favorite regiment, together with the many warm, personal friends of Acting Brig.-Gen. W. KRZYZANOWSKI, by whom it was raised, have made great efforts to give this regiment, which, having reenlisted as a veteran regiment, comes home on a thirty day's furlough, a grand reception and most cordial welcome. Out of a full regiment which left here in October, 1861. but a small band of 200, under the command of Lieut.-Col. A. OTTO, returns, the regiment having participated in nearly every battle in the Army of the Potomac, and fought last under GRANT in Tennessee, losing heavily at Chancellors-Ville, Gettysburgh and Lookout Mountain. The regiment is accompanied by Acting Brig.-Gen. W. KREYZANOWSKI, under whose able command it received (or its bravery, steadiness under fire and good discipline, the name of the "Glorious Fifty-eighth," by which it is known among its comrades, and is the first of his brigade, the whole of which having reenlisted as a veteran brigade, will shortly arrive here. The regiment is expected this morning, and will be received by the Fifth regiment, N. Y. N. G., Col. BURGER, Capt. OTTO's Company of Carbine Rangers, Col. HEINE, of the One Hundred and Third regiment, N. Y. S. V., and his officers, together with other detachments of volunteers in the City. The regiment will be received at the foot of Cortlandt-street, and escorted to the City Hall, where it will be reviewed by Mayor GUNTEER, thence up Broadway to Fourteenth-street, thence to and down the Bowery to Atlantic Garden, where a collation will be provided. Hon. J. T. BRADY will there receive the flag presented to the regiment when it left for the war, and which, torn and pierced by an hundred bullets, is to be handed over to the City authorities. An address in German will also be delivered by Dr. R. DULON.

abstract: Messrs. LEEDS & Co. offer for sale on Wednesday evening, some pictures of rare merit. They have been on exhibition for some days past at the old Dsseldorf Gallery, No. 548 Broadway, and the spacious room having been lit up after seven to attract those who are fond of art, it has been thronged until a late hour. Generally we are tempted by the pictures of modern artists, and we have in the collection which hangs on the south wall excellent specimens of DE LOOSE and KOEKOK but what are more worthy of remark are the older masters, some of whom are most creditably represented in the sixty-eight pictures which we are told form the gallery of a connoisseur. Thus the "Poisson," the "Agostino-car-acci," a remarkably fine specimen; the "Jouvenets," the "Berghem," and "Puerto de Cordova," stand prominently forth. The "Sebastian Gomez," and "St. Catharine," with the "Rosa de Tivoli" by its side, attracts an all who enter the room. Even for the lounger the visit is not thrown away. For many of these pictures, doubtless, there will be a sharp competition among collectors on the night of sale.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented from the New-York authorities, asking an amendment of the riot law. Bills were noticed calling for the appointment of Commissioners to determine the boundary line between New-York and Westchester Counties; asking the incorporation of the King's Bridge, High Bridge and Forty-second-street Railroad Company; authorizing dummy-engines on the Brooklyn Central and Jamaica Railroad. The concurrent resolutions proposing the amendment of the Constitution, so as to provide for the appointment of five Commissioners of Appeals, were passed.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented from the New-York authorities, asking an amendment of the riot law. Bills were noticed calling for the appointment of Commissioners to determine the boundary line between New-York and Westchester Counties; asking the incorporation of the King's Bridge, High Bridge and Forty-second-street Railroad Company; authorizing dummy-engines on the Brooklyn Central and Jamaica Railroad. The concurrent resolutions proposing the amendment of the Constitution, so as to provide for the appointment of five Commissioners of Appeals, were passed.

abstract: The Richmond Inquirer of Jan. 19 says:  Mr. HIDELL, Secretary to the Vice-President, received a dispatch yesterday, from Augusta, announcing the sudden and serious illness of Mr. STEPHENS. He was attacked on Sunday morning. This attack, with the well-known state of his health during the Winter, creates serious apprehensions in regard to him.
lead_paragraph: FORTRESS MONROE, Tuesday, Jan. 26.

abstract: About 70 invited guest went down the harbor yesterday on the trial trip of the new sidewheel steamer Warrior, 1,507 tons, built by Capt. WM.P. WILLIAMS and others. The ship left the foot of Jay-street about 10 1/2 o'clock, and returned about 8 P.M., having made over 50 miles at over 10 knots an hour, with from 18 to 23 pounds of steam, and 16 to 20 revolutions a minute. These rates, with new machinery indicate that she will be a very speedy ship when running at full power.

abstract: One of the most distressing accidents, resulting in the destruction of life and property, occurred at No. 65 Maiden-lane yesterday afternoon at 5 o'clock. The persons in the vicinity at the time were startled by an explosion in the second story of the building, which threw the doors and windows into the street, and set fire to the wood-work. In a few moments another explosion followed, and still another. Several parties were stunned by the violence of the concussion, and were felled to the earth. As soon as they could recover, they ran to the second floor of the building and found the body of one of the clerks, PAUL HOFFMAN, with life extinct and his clothes literally torn off his person. The smoke was very dense, and nothing could be seen beyond the body, which had been thrown out to the landing. Groans were heard, however, proceeding from the interior of the room, and Patrolman HAYS, of the Second Precinct, made his way in and succeeded in getting out Mr. CHARLES BLOCK, another unfortunate, who was found to be very much injured. He was taken to the New-York Hospital. It is thought he will recover, but he will be maimed for life. The body of HOFFMAN was removed to the Second Precinct Station-house by Capt. MILES, who was promptly at the fire, with sections of men from the Third, Twenty-seventh and First Precincts. The Police rendered very efficient service at the fire.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, an ordinance making a new appropriation for the Relief Fund, was presented and laid over. A resolution was presented directing the Comptroller to advertise and sell at auction the franchises of the ferries running from the foot of Hoboken, Houston, Christopher and Eighty-sixth streets. The resolution was referred, as was also a resolution to require the Belt Railroad Company to substitute grooved for the Trails now used by them. In the course of a discussion upon the propriety of ordering the building of any more steam fire-engines, Mr. JONES said $86,000 were expended for new steamers last year, and that work, of various kinds, for the Fire Department is ordered that will cost $300,000 -- or thrice as much as it is customary to appropriate annually for new apparatus and repairs, Mr. OTTIWELL quoted from the report of the Chief Engineer to the Common Council last year, that no more steamers are required than are now in use. The Board adjourned to 2 o'clock P.M. on Friday.

abstract: The United States steam transport Fulton, Capt. WOTTON, from Port Royal, S.C., 23d, and Stono Inlet. 24th inst., at 1 A.M., with passengers to United States Quartermaster, arrived here yesterday morning, having made the trip in 52 hours. She brings no news of importance. The improvements on the various forts and batteries were progressing. The troops are all in good health.

abstract: Early yesterday morning, the Fifty-eighth and Sixty-eighth Regiments, the former 350, the latter 200 strong, from Gen. GRANT's army, arrived in the City. Their coming had been anticipated, and preparations had been made by the Fifth New-York Volunteers and a Committee of Arrangements, to receive them. About 10 o'clock, the veterans, after a slight rest, marched from the Erie Railroad depot to Atlantic Garden, on the Bowery, where the Fifth was in waiting to receive them. After some preliminary movements, incident to all receptions, the escort, accompanied by the reenlisted heroes, proceeded to the City Hall Park. At this point the Fifth "grounded arms," and the veterans filed by there, forming in line in front of the City Hall. Here they were received by the Mayor, Members of the City Council, and several distinguished guests. Col. KRZYZANOWSKI (now in command of a brigade) and staff, Lieut.-Col. OTTO, in immediate command of the Fifty-eighth, and Lieut.-Col. STEINHAUSEN, of the Sixty-eighth, waited on the Major, who in a few remarks congratulated them on their safe return. In reply to the Mayor, Col. KRZYZANOWSKI acknowledged the honor of the reception and hoped that the future career of himself and his men might be such as to meet the approval of the City authorities and the whole country. After a short complimentary speech by Dr. BRUENINGHAUSEN, the regiments returned to Atlantic Garden, where a substantial collation was in waiting for them. The premises not being sufficiently large to accommodate all the guests, the Sixty-eight were entertained at the Bowery Garden. At both of these public resorts a fine band of music was in attendance, and the best of cheer was had. Of the many receptions of returned volunteers, the honors done yesterday to the Fifty-eighth and Sixty-eighth regiments exceed them all, not possibly in splendor of "turn-out," but in genuine hearty welcome.

abstract: LATE OF ENGINE COMPANY No. 39. -- At a meeting of the Board of Engineers and Firemen of the New-York Fire Department, held last evening at Firemen's Hall, action was taken relative to the death of WILLIAM FANNING, of Engine Company No. 39, who on Sunday last, was run over by Engine No. 15, and instantly killed. Suitable resolutions, conveying an expression of respect and esteem for the deceased, were offered by the Foreman of Engine Company No. 15, and unanimously adopted. To-day at 1 o'clock P.M. the members of the Department will assemble at the corner of Seventh-avenue and Thirty-first-street, to join the funeral procession. Chief Engineer D[???]CKER and his assistants will act as Marshals. Mr. FANNING was also a member of Hawkins' Zoua[???]es, and the members of the regiment are requested to meet at No. 128 West Thirty-first street, the house of Engine Company No. 39, this day at 1 o'clock, to attend the funeral of their late comrade.

abstract: Gen. BUTLER reports from his department the details of an expedition sent to the Peninsula. Three armed transports and a force under Gen. GRAHAM, went to Brandon Farms, a few miles below Fort Powhatan, and captured 20 prisoners, brought away 99 negroes, destroyed quantities of pork, oats and corn, and seized a sloop and schooner with 240 boxes of tobacco destined to run the blockade, returning without having lost a man.

abstract: Military Movements in the Spring
snippet: Military Movements in the Spring
lead_paragraph: It has from time to time been our lot to perform the not always pleasing, but none the less necessary, duty of giving a check to what has seemed to us ill-grounded public anticipations of military success. We are pushed to the conviction that a lesson of this kind is not entirely unneeded at this moment; and the point of the argument bears not so much on any special military task before us, as on the general aspect of the war as a whole. It should be sufficient consolation to every lover of his country that we can at last see our way to ultimate victory; that with adequate effort on our part the rebellion is doomed to destruction; and that even those foreign on-lookers who have been most sceptical as to the possibility of the conquest of the South, are at length compelled to confess that the military problem is on the fair way of solution. This high thought, we say, should be of itself a sufficient inspiration, without the need of any of the artificial stimulants derived from popular illusions and unfounded hopes. It should, in fact, rather have the effect of causing us to look coolly and dispassionately at the problem and all the elements that enter into the problem, to the end that realizing fully all that remains to be done, we may the more resolutely bend our energies to its accomplishment.

abstract: Private Letters Found Among Papers
snippet: Private Letters Found Among Papers
lead_paragraph: We have received five or six columns of private letters, said to have been found among the papers of Mr. STUART GWYNNE, recently implicated in some improper transactions in the Treasury Department. They are letters from gentlemen who were endeavoring to secure the introduction of sundry alleged improvements into the navy, and also to secure for themselves certain positions in the Government service. As no charges have been brought against these gentlemen, and as their letters have not the slightest public interest, we see no good end to be accomplished by their publication. The fact that they are private letters, written with the freedom and confidence usually supposed to belong to such correspondence, gives them, we are aware, a certain kind of interest in the eyes of the public. But their publication, in the absence of any strong public interest to be served thereby, seems to us exceedingly unjust to the parties concerned, and a breach of propriety scarcely justified by the circumstances of the case.
headline: {'main': 'INTERCEPTED CORRESPONDENCE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'INTERCEPTED CORRESPONDENCE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Elsewhere we print a letter commenting severely, but justly, upon the lack of courtesy and patriotism as evinced by the municipal authorities and the public, demonstrated more recently in the treatment of the One Hundred and Second Regiment New-York Volunteers, just returned from their gallant work at Lookout Mountain. The observations of our correspondent are true, and should make our people blush for shame. All the honor extended to these heroes is simply a review by the Mayor when they will march up town. We certainly hope this state of affairs will undergo a change for the better, and that very speedily. We cannot honor these men too much. We should give them our money, and praises, and patronage, and raise our hats to them on every occasion.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. BAYARD announced his willingness to take the oath in obedience to the resolution passed by the Senate on Monday. But he added, in a speech of explanation, that his mature convictions of his duty under the circumstances would induce him shortly to resign his seat in the Senate and retire to private life. The Senate then took up the resolution to expel Mr. DAVIS. A letter from Mr. DAVIS was read to the effect that in offering his resolutions, he had no design to incite the army to mutiny, or the people to sedition; but simply to induce the people to consent to a constitutional arbitrament of their difficulties.  Mr. HOWARD offered an amendment, changing the word "expelled" to "censured," and spoke at length upon the subject. Without concluding the subject, the Senate adjourned.
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. BAYARD announced his willingness to take the oath in obedience to the resolution passed by the Senate on Monday. abstract: Piracy; Diplomatic Correspondence on Confederate Cruisers
snippet: Piracy; Diplomatic Correspondence on Confederate Cruisers
lead_paragraph: The volume of last year's diplomatic correspondence, just published, makes it plain that the English Government has changed not simply its action, but its principle, in respect to the stoppage of Confederate cruisers built and equipped in its ports. In a dispatch of Earl RUSSELL to Mr. ADAMS, in January, he declared, with a very high tone, "the Government of this country respect the law. They do not seize upon property to the loss and damage of its owners, without proof that they are legally entitled to do so." He insisted that strict and perfect legal proof of the ownership and destination of the vessels was necessary to justify any detention of them. It was because, in the very nature of the case, this absolute legal proof could not be given seasonably, if at all, that the Alabama, the Florida and the other pirates escaped. In the latter part of the year this assumption was modified. Earl RUSSELL indicates his readiness to proceed on reasonable presumptions, without strictly conclusive evidence, and to look to Parliament for indemnity if damage should thereby be done the innocent. In the early part of the year he put the onus of proving the illegality of the destination upon our Government; in the latter part of the year he put the onus of proving the legality of the destination on the vessel itself. Thus writing in September concerning the iron-clads he says: "Instructions have been issued for preventing the departure of the iron-clad vessels in question from Liverpool until satisfactory evidence can be given as to their destination, or, at all events, until the inquiries which are now being prosecuted with a view to obtain such evidence shall have been brought to a conclusion." Had this rule been recognized at the outset, not a single rebel cruiser would have ever left a British port.

abstract: The Cincinnati Commercial learns from two gentlemen who have escaped from Alabama to avoid the conscription, that there is a very decided reaction in Alabama against the rebel leaders, which is immediately attributable to the wholesale impressment of persons and the seizure of property. As evidence of this, the fact is stated that resolutions indorsing secession, introduced into the Alabama Legislature, met with decided and unexpected opposition. They passed the Senate, but when they came into the House they were arrested by a formidable, outspoken and bitter opposition. The anti-secession feeling is most general, and better developed in the northern than in the southern part of the State.

abstract: At the monthly auction sale of Scranton coal, yesterday, prices were generally lower, the average decline having been about twenty cents per ton, as compared with the December sale. The total amount disposed of was 24,200 tons. The general average price was $7 12 per ton. The splendid weather of the past week or ten days has had the effect of deminishing the consumption and weakening the confidence of the speculative operators. Many families are buying coal by the single ton at the time, taking their chances in the market, as was recommended in this paper mouths ago, and find this course decidedly advantageous to them, as they are enabled to make each successive purchase at lower rates.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, a petition was presented, asking for a State bounty of three hundred dollars under the last call for troops. Bills were introduced for dummy engines on the Brooklyn Central Railroad; extending the provisions of the general manufacturing law to the construction and use of elevators; legalizing the Brooklyn Volunteer bonds, and controlling the running of railroads in Brooklyn. Bills were passed relative to the inspection of gas-meters, and incorporating the Roosevelt Hospital.

abstract: The neighborhood of Grand-street and the Bowery was thrown into a terrible state of excitement at 1 o'clock yesterday afternoon, by the commission or a shocking murder, of which WILLIAM H. WILLIAMS, the well-known Ann-street bill-poster, was the victim. The perpetrator of the homicide was ROBERT C. HAINES, an Englishman, 44 years of age, and a painter by occupation, whose inciting motive seems to have been jealousy. The tragedy occurred on the sidewalk, in front of WILLIAMS' residence, No. 282 Grand-street, where HAINES met his victim as he was coming out from his house.

abstract: The War in
snippet: The War in
lead_paragraph: The present news from Germany has certainly an alarming appearance. A Federal army of 60,000 men on the borders of Holstein, the Federal Committee reporting adversely to the Treaties of London of 1852, the Danish Government fortifying itself in Schleswig, and an English fleet reported to be fitting out for the Baltic, all these seem natural preliminaries to war. The German people are evidently intensely aroused, and determined to support the House of Augustenburg. England seems to be gradually forced into the position of upholding Denmark. There is obviously a limit beyond which the Danes cannot yield to German pressure, and still preserve their place as a European Power. The little stream of the Eider is probably now the only separating line between two angry and opposing armies, whose collision may awake all Europe to arms. Any accident might now kindle the universal conflagration so long predicted. Yet before concluding on the certainty of a great war in Europe, we must look more carefully into the inter-play of forces beneath these imposing external movements. It should be remembered, as we have so often repeated, that this movement in behalf of the Duchies is essentially an instinctive and general uprising of the great German people for the sake of national unity. It is this that creates so profound an excitement throughout Germany. But, as a necessity, the dynastic influences of Germany -- the Princes and Kings -- are opposed to German unity. Whatever unites the people, fetters them.

abstract: the Pending Suit and the Press
snippet: the Pending Suit and the Press
lead_paragraph: The Express complains of injustice on the part of its cotemporaries in regard to their treatment of the suit pending between its present proprietors and one of their late partners. As it includes the TIMES in this complaint, it is proper for us to say that we have done nothing in the matter, beyond publishing a fair report of the testimony taken in open court, as part of our regular legal record. We have made no comment whatever on any part or aspect of the case, and have neither expressed nor formed any opinion as to the merits of the controversy. How we could have done less than we have done, in justice to the public, we do not perceive. While the Express has not always taken pains to deserve kind or considerate treatment at the hands of its cotemporaries, we should certainly be very unwilling to merit the censure which it bestows upon us. We have never meddled many way with the privet relations or business affairs of that or any other journal. We make this explanation in justice to the Express as well as ourselves.
