abstract: The Executive Committees of the Great Metropolitan Fair for the United States Sanitary Commission are actively engaged in perfecting their arrangements. The ladies meet every day at the Receiving Depot, No. 2 Great Jones-street, corner of Broadway, and a certain number of the gentlemens' committee will always be found at No. 842 Broadway, to give information, or receive contributions. This Fair is intended to be not a mere Fancy Fair, for the sale of useless articles at exorbitant prices, but rather a grand exhibition of the industrial, agricultural, commercial and artistic products of the whole country, or, indeed, of the whole world, if the world will only be kind enough to contribute to a charity the grandest in its proportion, the noblest in its objects, the most universal in the distribution of its benefits that has ever presented itself to the benevolent. On the 28th of March, at the grounds known as the "Palace Garden," on Fourteenth-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, this Fair will open. There now remains two months for preparation, and the committees are hard at work -- the ladies in particular devoting a great deal of time with unwearing energy, in the determination to make this an exhibition which, in magnificent proportions and beneficial results to the funds of the Sanitary Committee, shall far excel the fairs held in the other cities of the Union for the same object. To assist them in this aim, it is the duty of everyone to contribute, and not only will it be doing an act of charity, but the plan of the Fair offers reciprocal benefits to every merchant and manufacturer who wishes to bring his goods before the public. Everybody is invited to contribute -- merchants, manufacturers, mechanics, artisans, artists, farmers, publishers, managers and artists of theatres, musicians, music dealers, all trades and callings. There is nothing so small that the Committee will not receive it with thanks; there is nothing so large that room cannot be found for it.

abstract: Proposed Expulsion of
snippet: Proposed Expulsion of
lead_paragraph: -- Without wishing to be at all intrusive, we venture to express the opinion that the Senate of the United States is wasting a good deal of valuable time and zeal in discussing the proposal to expel Mr. GARRETT DAVIS, of Kentucky, for words used in certain resolutions offered by him a few days since. The proposition seems to us to smack a good deal more of personal or party passion than of zeal for the public good. The power of expulsion doubtless belongs to the Senate, as to every other deliberative body; but it should never be used except under the most stringent necessity. If any Senator were known to be disloyal in sentiment, and treasonable in conduct, the public safety would demand his expulsion, even if proof of his crime were not clear enough to warrant his punishment. But to expel a Senator, and disfranchise his State, for words spoken in debate, would be an extraordinary stretch of power, only to be justified by the most extraordinary circumstances.

abstract: The One Hundred and Second New-York Volunteers, that arrived here on Sunday from Chattanooga, was reviewed in front of the City Hall yesterday afternoon by the Mayor and Common Council. After the review, the regiment marched up Broadway to Twenty-third-street; thence to Washington Parade-ground, where it was dismissed. No escort of any kind was furnished to this returned regiment of reenlisted veterans, save the band of the Seventh Regiment. It has been a subject of much regret by the friends of the regiment that no New-York regiments welcomed the men on their arrival in this City. A number of ladies, however, are now employed in raising funds in order to entertain the veterans of the One Hundred and Second at a dinner. The regiment, which now only numbers 200 men, is under command of Capt. STEGMAN.

abstract: Reelection and Reconstruction Question
snippet: Reelection and Reconstruction Question
lead_paragraph: Unquestionably one of the strongest causes of the popular manifestations for the reelection of President LINCOLN, is the fact that he most directly represents an acceptable policy in regard to reconstruction. Every man in the country knows President LINCOLN's method, and the spirit with which it will be carried out. He has disclosed both with a distinctiveness which there is no possibility of mistaking. The good faith and consistency which have marked all his words and actions are taken as a perfect guaranty of his future course.

abstract: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. CONNESS introduced a bill for the better organization of Indian Affairs in California. Mr. LANE, of Indiana, introduced a bill to facilitate the transmission of money from soldiers to their friends and families. Mr. HALE, from the Naval Committee, reported a bill, providing that hereafter all appointments in the volunteer naval service shall be submitted to the Senate for confirmation, the same as the regular appointments. The Senate proceeded to consider the bill to promote enlistments, which was discussed until the close of the morning hour. The resolution for the expulsion of Mr. DAVIS was then taken up. Messrs. HALE, FESSENDEN, and LANE, of Indiana, opposed the resolution, because they believed it a blow at free speech, and because they did not believe the Senator from Kentucky was in fact disloyal. No conclusion was reached when the Senate adjourned.

abstract: and the Monroe Doctrine
snippet: and the Monroe Doctrine
lead_paragraph: The Monroe doctrine is a good word to conjure by; but the spectre which some of the Copperhead presses are attempting to raise in its name, apropos of the position taken by the Administration in regard to the French in Mexico, can have little power to frighten even the most timorous. It will not, we conceive, be found that the honored maxim of American statesmanship has suffered any detriment from aught that our diplomatic correspondence discloses. The attitude or the Government toward the French invasion has been, from the first, that of "observation" -- the only attitude that could, under the absorbing conditions imposed upon us by the war, be wisely assumed. But while there has been nothing like blustering or menace indulged in, neither has there gone forth any uncertain sound on the point of our real sentiments as to the Emperor's doings. There is a quiet significance in that passage of one of Mr. SEWARD's dispatches, in which he states that "the permanent establishment of a foreign and monarchical government in Mexico will be found neither easy nor desirable;" and when the whole spirit of his utterances is taken in connection with the action of the Government, the wisdom and prudence of the course pursued must be manifest to every fair-minded man.

abstract: According to the Baltimore American, spies and rebel mail carriers pass through our military lines with alarming frequency and impunity The oath of allegiance is taken and violated without compunction, and passes beyond our pickets are given to every one desiring them who subscribes to the oath. Our military authorities almost seem to connive at these proceedings, so frequent have they become.

abstract: Movements of the Rebel Army
snippet: Movements of the Rebel Army
lead_paragraph: A dispatch wearing all the appearance of authenticity reaches us with the important intelligence of the rebel Gen. JOHNSTON's withdrawal from the front which he has lately held at Dalton. The news, up to the hour of writing, lacks official confirmation; but it comes in a circumstantial and veracious form. This is the most important military event that has happened since the battles in front of Chattanooga, though it is still a text that does not add it of a perfectly satisfactory interpretation.

abstract: Redemption, How to be Effected
snippet: Redemption, How to be Effected
lead_paragraph: If Senator WILSON'S bill, securing homesteads to persons in the military service, to be carved out of confiscated lands or lands sold for taxes in the South, should pass, it will, in conjunction. with the sales of land which are being made every day to other persons, go a long way toward solving the problem of Southern pacification. There is little question, that do what we will by way of conciliation, a large portion of the purely Southern population will remain hostile to the Government after the war is ended. They will have, no doubt, abandoned all thought of a second resort to armed resistance, but the frenzy which first hurried them into revolt will not have entirety subsided. They will remain breeders of strife and contention; a constant source of trouble and disaffection; obstructors of the law; fomenters of treason and sedition; a standing menace to our domestic tranquility, and a standing invitation to foreign meddlers. They will not be very formidable in numbers, perhaps, but they will be the most influential portion of the Confederacy, the best educated and the most completely versed in the art of intrigue, They will keep alive, by every means in their power, the memories of the war, both amongst those who suffered from it, and those who fought in it, and they will find active and faithful missionaries in the thousands of old soldiers who will be scattered all over the country, and to whom come what will, the reminiscences of their campaigns will always be sweet.

abstract: The liquor merchants are much excited at the prospect of another tax being levied by Congress upon their stocks of liquors. They say they have already paid one excise tax on the liquors which have gone into their private stores, and they cannot see with what justice they can be called upon to pay another.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all, official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day. the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports: items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: STEPHEN T. CLARK vs. JAMES BROOKS AND ERASTUS BROOKS.-- The motion in this case came up for argument yesterday morning. Mr. SMITH read an affidavit of JAMES BROOKS, in which he says that the prosperity of the Express has steadily increased since the establishment of the paper; that there is no gratuitous advertising in the paper, and that no advertising has been inserted to fill up the paper, and he denies that any article published in the paper has been of a disloyal character, and he denies that there has been any loss on account of the political course of the paper.

abstract: The war news from Tennessee is rapidly increasing in interest. The dispatches received last evening announce that JOHNSTON's (late BRAGG's) army is rapidly falling back south of Dalton, and had already reached Kingston, which is the point where the Dalton Railroad intersects the railroad leading from Rome to Atlanta and Augusta. Kingston is forty miles south of Dalton. Col. BURKE, of the Tenth Ohio Regiment, went out with a flag of truce forty-five miles, but could find no enemy. The advanced pickets of the enemy were reported to be at Kingston. Several unimportant cavalry demonstrations have been made to cover this retreat. The recent raid of RODDY's forces upon Athens, Ala., has already resulted disastrously. Gen. THOMAS telegraphs that the rebels crossed the Tennessee, two brigades strong, at two different places, but were engaged by our forces and defeated, losing fifteen killed, and wounding and capturing quite a number. Our loss was only ten wounded; Gen. THOMAS also telegraphs that Col. BOONE, with a force of mounted infantry, attacked the camp of the rebel Home Guards, under Col. CULBERTON, routed them, and destroyed their camp and property, without loss to our side. Parties who left Knoxville on Saturday last report that LONG-STREET's cavalry were skirmishing with ours above Knoxville. Confidence was felt in our ability to hold Knoxville. Gov. JOHNSTON had issued an order at Nashville for holding an election for county officers in such counties as were under loyal control. A stringent oath will be administered to all electors offering to vote.

abstract: Congress and its Jurisdiction
snippet: Congress and its Jurisdiction
lead_paragraph: The ground has slipped away so gradually from beneath the bogus Confederacy, that very few appreciate how much truth there is in the assertion recently made by the Raleigh (North Carolina) Standard, that the rebel Congress is "controlled by members from Kentucky, Tennessee, Missouri, Arkansas, Louisiana and other places, who impose odious and oppressive laws, which can no more be enforced on the people of the States which they profess to represent, than upon the people of New-York or New-England."

abstract: The steamship City of New-York, from Liverpool on the 13th, via Queenstown on the 14th inst., with four days' later European news, arrived at this port last evening. The advices are of an interesting character. The Schleswig-Holstein question exhibited no material change, but it is announced that Denmark has made her last concession, and should any German regiment advance beyond the Northern boundary of the Federal territory, King CHRISTIAN is resolved to enter on war with all energy. Prussia and Austria still exhibit the vacillation which has marked their conduct on the matter throughout. A large number of Italians have been arrested in Paris on suspicion of being connected with the recently discovered plot to assassinate the Emperor. MAZZINI, against whom a charge of complicity in the affair was made, writes to the papers a most explicit denial of the accusation. In the Court of Exchequer on the 11th inst., the Chief Baron and Baron BRAMWELL gave judgment in the Alexandra case, discharging the rule obtained by the Crown in favor of a new trial. There will consequently be no new trial; and the ship will be released. The effect of the above decision is that the Foreign Enlistment Act, with all its antecedents and consequences, will be discoursed over again in the Court of Exchequer Chambers, and probably in the House of Lords. A Canton dispatch of Nov. 13, says the American steamer Scotland, Capt. RUSSELL, had been seized by the customs authorities for taking in guns and other contraband cargo in the Cum-sing-moon Bay, in Canton River. Particulars of the destruction of the clipper ships Amanda and Winged Racer, by the pirate Alabama, are also received. The Liverpool Post says that the greatest topic of the East India press by the last mail is the Alabama, her late manceuvres and her probable future tactics occupying much space. The American flag, however, is fast disappearing from the Indian seas, ships taking shelter under that of Peru, Prussia and Portugal. Risks in American bottoms are point-blank refused by the Eastern Insurance Offices, and only one ship is reported loading under the American flag; meanwhile the cause of all the consternation is quietly cruising in the Straits of Sunda, patiently waiting for coming prizes.

abstract: Securing Homesteads
snippet: Securing Homesteads
lead_paragraph: The lands now selling in South Caronna under the provisions of the act for the collection of direct taxes in insurrectionary districts, our correspondent informs us, are going off at prices which will at least assure reimbursement to the Treasury of the money expended in the prosecution of the sale. In these days of prodigal expenditure of the national finances, this, in itself, is a gratifying financial fact. But connected with it is another tact of a still more gratifying character, that has in it a sharp bearing upon the question of what will be done with the negro. All the accounts sent to us. concur in saying that the late emancipated slaves of the chivalry the Sea Islands are the largest p[???] chasers of the confiscated lands. Tho who are most intimately acquainted wi the negroe's characteristics will not be surprised at this development of his ambition become a landed proprietor. To possess a his unquestionable domain the little hut an its small garden-plot, which formed his particular share of the plantation "quarters, was Cudjo's sole joy in the days of his se[???]itude, and for this dole of domesticity h[???]elt that attachment which the househo[???] [???]abby shows for her wonted chimney-corne[???] Now that the authorities upon whom the du[???]as devolved of parceling out the lands an[???]rranging the terms of sale have been a[???]ains, with wise forethought, to let the freed[???]en know that they could purchase, "for themselves and their heirs forever," the fee sim[???]le of these homesteads, guaranteed to them upon the faith of the President of the United States, in whose authority they have learned place implicit trust, the avidity which they [???]ve shown, in purchasing the soil, among [???]ose who know them, excites no wonder, people in the world care less to move their [???]miciles. They fix their household gods, be[???]ey never so humble, as far as posble beyond the reach of the iconoclasts. who, under guise of bettering their prospects, would rudely dash them in pieces. In proof of this, witness their response to the order of Major General HUNTER, who last Spring accorded them full privilege to leave the Department, offering them transportation whithersoever they would go. Scarcely a dozen of the 15,000 blacks whom the order reached availed themselves of its provisions, and those who did, without exception returned home again, satisfied that a change of residence would in no sense be advantageous. In view of these facts, how ridiculous is the old argument, which even now is sometimes advanced by ignorant or designing people, that when free the negroes would swarm to the North and offer their labor in competition with that of the whites! Take it all in all, the result of the sale of these South Carolina lands is of the most encouraging nature, affording, as it does, the first practical proof of the ability of the freed negro to secure for himself that material prosperity which, more than anything else, will raise him to a condition of self-dependence.

abstract: Good Faith--Their Conscription Act
snippet: Good Faith--Their Conscription Act
lead_paragraph: The rebel Congress has lately given a fresh illustration of the fidelity with which the traitor chiefs observe the sanctity of public pledges and promises. We lately commented on the resolution to which they have come to retain the present rebel armies in the field by a sweeping legislative act providing that all persons now in the Confederate service shall continue so till the end of the war. They have now come to the resolve to put into the ranks all who have hitherto furnished substitutes. These unfortunates probably fancied when they hired, at inonstrous prices, men to fill their places that this would exempt them from service -- at least it was "so nominated in the bond". But they are now having their eyes opened. The Richmond chiefs know a trick worth two of that. Some of the rebel papers are making a how over this piece of despotism and the people are hugely stirred up about this little matter. What folly How can they help themselves? They had only the promise of their "authorities" to go on, and they now know what that is worth.

abstract: Homesteads for Soldiers' Bill
snippet: Homesteads for Soldiers' Bill
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, yesterday, Mr. DOOLITTLE introduced a resolution providing that in all sessions of committees to take testimony concerning the conduct of any Department of Government, the head of such department shall be requested to employ some competent person to cross-examine such witnesses. The resolution was referred. The Pension and amended Homestead Bills were then taken up and passed. The latter enables the families of soldiers and sailors to perfect their claims in the absence of the head of the family. On motion of Mr. WILKINSON, the President' was requested to inform the Senate whether any part of the appropriation for purposes of colonization has been expended, and what steps have been taken to execute the law of Congress on that subject. The resolution for the expulsion of Senator DAVIS was then taken up. Messrs. CLARK, FOSTER, HOWARD, FESSENDEN, JOHNSON and WILSON severally spoke on the subject. Mr. WILSON was eloquently severe in his final reply, which was followed by the withdrawal of the resolution for expulsion. The Senate, after briefly considering the bill to encourage enlistments, adjourned until Monday.

abstract: The Board of Councilmen met yesterday. The session was spent in passing upon general orders, which comprised ordinances for the laying of Belgian pavement in Maiden-lane and Liberty-street, also in Morris-street; and for curbing, guttering and flagging in some up-town streets. The several ordinances for Belgian pavement were amended, previous to their passage, by a provision imposing half the cost upon the City and the other halt upon the property to be benefited by the improvement. The ordinance to lay Belgian pavement in Houston-street, east of the Bowery, was lost, for the reason that it was deemed inexpedient to put down such pavement there, while there is a probability of a railroad passing through a part or the whole of the street. There was an interesting discussion upon the propriety of continuing to buy the Belgian pavement by piecemeal. Mr. JACQUES argued for a discontinuance of the work till a general plan, such as has been proposed by Mayor GUNTHER, shall be determined upon. Messrs. HAGERTY, BRANDON and others reasoned that the work ought to go on, and the streets continue to be improved without awaiting the uncertainty of the adoption of a general plan. The Board adjourned to 1 o'clock P. M. next Monday.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen yesterday adopted a resolution in favor of the appointment of a joint special committee to report some measure to obviate the present difficulties to general travel, consequent upon the manner in which street railroad tracks are now laid. The Corporation Counsel was requested to give his opinion whether the piers and bulkheads can be leased in any other manner than is provided by section 1 of the Charter, [which is by auction.] The Mayor transmitted to the board the report of the "Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art," (Cooper Institute,) for 1863. The receipts, including a balance of $177 32 from 1862.

abstract: A domestic in surrection seems to have broken out among the Abolition ultraists of Boston. WENDELL PHILLIPS, it seems, has been vehemently denouncing President LINCOLN, and calling on the people to make CHASE President, BUTLER Secretary of War, and FREMONT Commander of the armies. He thinks we have a right to demand that the war shall not be closed until Slavery is extirpated, and his chief complaint against the President is, that he seems willing to close it sooner. Mr. GARRISON warmly and sharply criticised Mr. PHILLIPS, and seemed Inclined to vindicate and sustain the President. He will come to be called a conservative by-and-bye, if he is not careful -- and then where will he go to when he dies?

abstract: One Hundred and Second Regiment; Honors to
snippet: One Hundred and Second Regiment; Honors to
lead_paragraph: While so much is done for the soldier upon the battle-field. more attention is demanded to their families at home. All over our City are families living in cellars and garrets who are called daily to contend sharply with adversity, and many of them fall unknown and unhonored in the arms of death. Only a few weeks since a case came to light through the efforts of the Christian Alliance. In Eight-street, in a small back room of the fourth story of a tenement house, lived the widow of a soldier who fell in the battle of Fair Oaks. For over a year she slaved almost day and night on starvation prices, with her needle, to keep Her children from want, and to maintain a decree of respectability. She was a German woman, with all the feelings and susceptibilities that characterize those who have seen better days. One of her children, the eldest, a beautiful little girl of eleven Summers, was seized with disease about the heart. For months she lingered, while the mother slaved on, battling with poverty and affliction, until her own system gave evidence of wasting energies and crushed hopes: at last the little sufferer terminated her earthly existence, amid the sobs and tears of the mother and the surviving little sisters. Hours rolled a way, and no steps were taken to place the lifeless remains in its last resting-place. The mother was without means, without friends, and like Rachel of old, weeping and mourning, and would not be comforted because her child was not. Steps were at last taken for interment by the means provided by, the City. This, however, was horrifying to the mother, and lacerating to her already wounded spirits. A coffin, some ten or twelve inches too short, rough and untrimmed on the inside, with paint to green on the outside as to cover the hands of those who rough it; and then to have the little form crammed in, nailed down and borne off by a colored man, and put on board the night boat and carried away, no one knows where, was more than that sensitive, broken hearted mother could endure. If ever the tender sensibilities of humanity should be regarded, it is under such circumstances. It is a wonder the City does not perform this last act for the poor a little more in accordance with the dictates of humanity. The case mentioned was brought to the notice of the society above named; an undertaker was employed; the ladies aided in the little necessary arrangements, and after nearly two days the little one was placed in a neat trimmed coffin and brought to hope Chapel in a hearse, where services were conducted by Rev., Mr. Goss. The Sunday school children were assembled, and the scene was very impressive. The remains were borne to the Lutheran Grave-yard, the family following in a carriage, and placed in a grave where lay a brother previously interred. The expenses of the funeral amounted to $23 30, but it greatly contributed to the comfort of a sorrowing, broken-hearted mother. The surviving children are now constant attendants of the Christian Alliance Sunday-school, and the mother of the church services. Thus was the last act of kindness shown to a soldier's child, while the family is now often made comfortable by attention and sympathy. This is only one instance of scenes that are constantly occurring among us -- scenes hidden from the gaze of the world, but which wring the heart with bitterness of those who are exercised thereby.

abstract: Assistant-Secretary of the Navy, G.V. Fox, Esq., arrived in this City yesterday for the purpose of making arrangements for the great naval race between the United States steamer Eutaw and the steamer Kin Kiang, built for the China trade. No sooner had the announcement of Mr. Fox's arrival been made known than the Navy-yard and alt the rendezvous and naval offices in the City were crowded with persons inquiring what were the prospects of the race, who could set on board the vessels. &c. Our reporter called on Mr. BLUNT last evening for information regarding: the success attending Mr. Fox's visit, and learned that nothing definite had been determined on in consequence of the Assistant-Secretary having matters to attend to at Washington, for which place he started last evening.

abstract: The judgment pronounced by the Court of Exchequer in the Alexandra case, refusing a new trial, has the force of reaffirming the previous verdict in favor of the defendants  a verdict which makes it not unlawful for British merchants to build, fit out and sell to the rebels war-vessels, provided they are not armed and equipped; but it is far from settling the question.
lead_paragraph: The judgment pronounced by the Court of Exchequer in the Alexandra case, refusing a new trial, has the force of reaffirming the previous verdict in favor of the defendants a verdict which makes it not unlawful for British merchants to build, fit out and sell to the rebels war-vessels, provided they are not armed and equipped; but it is far from settling the question. It is in the power of the Crown to carry the case to the Court Exchequer Chamber, and finally up to the house of Lords. This will, without doubt, be done, for the British Government has it really at heart, we think, to have the Foreign Enlistment Act so construed as to put a stop to the fitting out of war-vessels for the rebels. Should it be found impossible to do so, we have the promise of Earl. RUSSELL to call for new legislation on the subject, if the law, as it now stands, is insufficient. The point of to us is, that the Alexandra being a test case, no more Alabamas or Floridas will be allowed to escape until her fate is. And it may be found the most politic way to keep the ship in a kind of legal blockade by the " law s delay" and the resources of the circumlocution office till the war is over -- a course which will present the double advantage of satisfying justice toward the United States, while it will save the British Government from the embarrassment of making a decision to which their fears might seem to have in part contributed.

abstract: Longstreet's Movement upon
snippet: Longstreet's Movement upon
lead_paragraph: The news to-day from East Tennessee brings swifter confirmation than we could wish of the interpretation put by us yesterday upon the rebel movements in that region. There now remains no room to doubt that the rebels are in the act of executing a determined movement for the capture of Knoxville and the repossession of East Tennessee. An encounter of some magnitude is reported to have taken place on the 15th between two heavy bodies of the two armies at Danbridge, forty miles East of Knoxville. On the Union side was the whole cavalry corps under Gen. STURGIS, with a portion of the infantry under Gen. PARKE; and on the side of the rebels were the divisions of HOOD and BUSHROD JOHNSON, with HAMPTON's cavalry. The fight is reported to have gone adversely to us, causing a loss of a hundred and fifty men, till a cavalry charge turned the fortunes of the day, and enabled our forces to fall back to Knoxville. On the 19th, the cavalry force, with the corps of Gen. GORDON GRANGER, moved out to intercept LONGSTREET as far as possible from Knoxville, and a battle was momentarily expected at a point which the telegraph calls Lewisville, but which we take to be Sevierville, twenty-five or thirty miles from Knoxville.
headline: {'main': 'Longstreet Before Knoxville Military Prospects in East Tennessee.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Longstreet Before Knoxville Military Prospects in East Tennessee.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ITALIAN OPERA. -- Mr. MARETZEK's coming season promises to be one of the most brilliant on record. Although the ticket office has only been open for a couple of days, the demand for seats has been quite unprecedented. Without offering any peculiar inducements to subscribers, the subscription list is already larger than it has ever been before. It was apprehended that four performances a week, instead of three, as heretofore, would be rather a severe tax on the subscribers; but such is the desire for Italian opera, they seem to be rather pleased with the arrangement than offended at it. The opening opera is PETRELLA's "lone" -- a work which does not seem to pall on the public appetite. Mr. MARKTZEL's repertoire is almost exhaustless, and we are glad to hear that he has made a very Important addition to his company in the person of Signor BRIGNOLL.

abstract: Three days later news from Europe reached this port yesterday, brought by the steamship Australasian, from Liverpool on the 16th, an Queenstown on the 17th inst. The circumstances attending the fitting out and departure from Sheerness of the rebel privateer Rappahannock had been the subject [???] official inquiry on the part of the British Government, and the result was the apprehension of Commodore RUMBLE, one of the principal officers[???]the dock-yard, on a charge of gross neglect [???]duty, coupled with an unwarrantable violation[???] the neutrality laws. The accused gave heavy bail to answer. The case of the Pampero, a vessel built on the Clyde, and suspected to be for the rebel service, has gone into the Court [???] Sessions as an Exchequer cause. The notorious steamer Sumter was sold at auction in Liverpool for £4,500. At the same sale the Great Eastern was put up and bid in by her owners for, £130.000. Three Liverpool ship chandlers were summoned to appear in the Police Court on the 15th inst., to answer a charge of enlisting men for the Confederate service. Only one of the defendants came forward, and he was held in his own recognizance for $300 and two sureties of $250 each for trial. In the Schleswig-Holstein affair Austria and Prussia had decided upon the important step of the military occupation of Schleswig, in opposition to the Federal Diet. The British Minister at Dresden had addressed a warning note to the Saxon Government against the invasion of Holstein, which Saxony complains of is being offensive. One of the latest rumors was, that hostilities had actually commenced between the Danish and Federal troops, but it lacked confirmation and not much importance was attached [???]thereto. The discussions in the French Legislature on the elections were of great interest, A Madrid dispatch of Jan. 16, says that in consequence of the vote of the Senate on the bill for constitutional reform, the Spanish Ministry has tendered its resignation, which has been accepted by the Queen. abstract: Our neighbor, the Tribune, is in the habit of speaking of WENDELL PHILLIPS, and those who concur with him in sentiment, as unconditional loyalists; while yesterday morning it refers to REVERDY JOHNSON as a conditional supporter of the Union. If it be not too much trouble, we should be glad to have it explain the grounds of this distinction. To the best of our knowledge and belief, the boot, figuratively speaking, seems to be on the other leg.

abstract: Many complaints are made by a number of our brave reï¿½nlisted men, who are now in this City or furlough, at their utter inability to produce the County bounty. When the men were remustered into the service of the United States for the continuance of the war, the mustering officer neglected furnishing them with the papers crediting them to the quota of New-York City. Consequently, the Supervisors Committee refuse to pay them the bounty, and many men remain in the City, unable to return to their homes to enjoy their brief holiday of thirty days, more than half of which, in many cases, have already expired. Provost-Marshal-General HAYS has endeavored to arrange the matter, but he has been refused the power of any action until the men have received their proper mustering in papers. It is stated that one whole regiment, on account of their want of system, that would otherwise have been credited to New-York City, was taken to Queens County, and there paid the bounty without any difficulty.

abstract: And Japan; Important News from
snippet: And Japan; Important News from
lead_paragraph: The letters from our correspondents at Pekin and Yokohama, published this morning, will be read with interest. Civilization does not seem to be making much progress in these benighted Empires. The Chinese Mandarins have summarily dismissed the entire Anglo-Chinese fleet, which was sent out with so much parade to aid in the suppression of the Taiping rebellion -- ships, officers and all to go home, and the ships to be sold to pay the expenses of the expedition. The causes of this action are not fully explained, but it is undoubtedly induced by a fear on the part of the Chinese authorities that such a strong allied force might not only crush the Taipings, but the Mandarins also -- a fear, of course, purely imaginary. So they TUB the risk of prolonging the rebellion indefinitely, rather than accept the strong aid of the British Government, and have it done with at once. The British Minister was at first disposed to regard this action as a breach of faith, but subsequent investigation by our Minister, Mr. BURLINGAME, convinced the former that the Chinese had really acted in good faith, and that their envoy to England had exceeded his instructions. Japanese matters do not promise further difficulties. The Damios evidently fear war since the fight at Kagesima, and Prince SATSUMA had promised indemnity to the extent of $100,000, and that vigorous efforts should be made to bring the murderers of Mr. RICHARDSON to justice. But these things are only promised, and our next letter may bring us news that these fickle-minded barbarians have changed their purposes and are again as perverse as ever.

abstract: Calhoun's Doctrine of Sectional Equilibrium; Prospects of in the Future
snippet: Calhoun's Doctrine of Sectional Equilibrium; Prospects of in the Future
lead_paragraph: One of the earlier doctrines of Mr. CALHOUN was the political necessity of an equilibrium between the North and the South in the Senate. He held that there could be no security of the Union without it -- that the stronger section would exercise its power over the weaker, so as to make perpetual contention. His proposed safeguard was to maintain a perfect sectional equality in the Senate by never admitting new States except by the pair, one Northern and one Southern. For a long time there was, in fact, a general recognition that this was desirable, and the balance was preserved, until the immense progress of the Northwest made it no longer practicable. At the time of the "secession," there were four more Free States than Slave, giving the Free States a preponderance of eight in the Senatorial representation.
headline: {'main': 'The Future Sectional Equilibrium.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Future Sectional Equilibrium.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Magazines for February
snippet: Magazines for February
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic Monthly (Boston, TICKNOR & FIELDS,) wears rather a graver espect than usual. Fiction is represented by two articles only, "A Half Life and Half a Life," by Miss E.H. APPLETON; a New-England sketch, unfolding psychologically the blossoming of a girl's mind and heart, under the influence of affection: and No. 2 of Mrs. SDOWE'S graphic " Home and House Papers." Of a more serious cast are "Genius," by BROWNLEE BROWN, the opening paper; and "The Relation of Art to Nature." a valuable contribution to the Philosophy of Art, illustrating the proper connection of painting and sculpture with actual nature and the ideal, by a survey of their progress from the days of the Greeks to the great masters of early Christian art. The author is J. ELIOT CABOT, who will complete the subject in another article. "The Convulsionists of St. Medard" is a careful paper on a very disagreeable incident in the Jansenist controversy in France, It is treated by R. DALE OWEN in relation to the general question of the power of mind over the body. "Annesley Hall and Newstead Abbey" adds little or nothing to the usual tourist's record. "Bryant" is a critical estimate, executed with taste and judgment, of the poet, by GEORGE S. HILLARD. The articles bearing on present events are "Northern Invasions." by EDWARD EVERETT HALE, and a stirring Lyric by Dr. HOLMES, "The Last Charge," arousing all to the necessity of a grand and final effort " for country, for freedom, for honor, for life," that shall settle the reeling giant of rebellion with "one blow in his forehead." The other poetry of the number is contributed by ALICE CAREY, Mrs. AKEES and J.T. TROWBRIDGE, and does not call for any particular remark. The Reviews and Literary Notices are full and discriminating.
headline: {'main': 'The Magazines for February.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Magazines for February.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Bryant's, W. C., Thirty Poems; Halleck, Fitz Greene. Young America; Longfellow, H. W. Tales of a Wayside Inn
snippet: Bryant's, W. C., Thirty Poems; Halleck, Fitz Greene. Young America; Longfellow, H. W. Tales of a Wayside Inn
lead_paragraph: It is something to record the visit to our book-table this season of the honored triumvirate of our elder bards,BRYANT, LONGFELLOW and HALLECK. They come after long silence of the Muse, during which the din of war may be presumedto have drowned their minstrelsy; and we may accept their arrival as an indication that the waters of the great deep aresubsiding, and Peace again, with her arts and refinements, is to be welcomed in the land. Not that war is altogetherunfriendly to the poet. On THIRTY POEMS. By WILLIAM CULLEN BR YANT. APPLENTON & CO.

abstract: The Raleigh Progress, of Tuesday week, says: "We regret to learn that the steamer A.D. Vance was run on the beach, under the guns of Fort Caswell, in attempting to enter the port of Wilmington. It is supposed that the crew are safe, and that the cargo will be saved, but the ship, of course, will be lost. This is a severe loss to the State, and is to be much regretted; but it was one of the risks that had to be encountered, and murmurings and fault-findings will amount to nothing now, and we hope to hear nothing of it.

abstract: Tucker vs. Various Insurance Companies. Value of Stock Insured
snippet: Tucker vs. Various Insurance Companies. Value of Stock Insured
lead_paragraph: William Tucker vs. The Mechanics' Fire Insurance Company; The Same vs. The New-York Fire and Marine Insurance Company; The Same vs. The Jefferson Fire Insurance Company; The Same vs. The Clinton Fire Insurance Company; The Same vs. The Peoples' Fire Insurance Company. The plaintiff in the above cases insured the stock and fixtures of his store, No. 325 Pennsylvania-avenue, upon policies of $5,000 each in each of the above Companies, defendants in this action. The stock and fixtures were worth $27,400, and the whole amount of insurance was $25,000. On the 7th of April, 1862, the store burned down, and the entire stock was destroyed by fire. The plaintiff notified the Companies of the loss and demanded payment of the amount insured. After the receipt of this notification, Thomas Morrill, the President of the Jefferson Insurance Company, came on to Washington, and announced to plaintiff that he came to investigate the matter of the fires, that he was his friend and advised him to settle with the insurance companies and with his creditors. Plaintiff refused, stating that he intended to pay his creditors in full. Morrill went back to New-York, and the insurance companies refused to pay on the policies, alleging as a reason that the stock in the store at the time of the fire had been reduced in value and amount by sales and other causes, and that it was not worth the sum for which it was insured. The plaintiff swears that it was worth $27,400, and brings this suit against the companies upon the respective policies. The evidence of Thomas Morrill, President of the Jefferson Fire Insurance Company, showed a curious agreement between himself, on the part of the insurance companies, and a detective named Allen, whom he employed in Washington to hunt up evidence against Mr. Tucker. He swears that he arranged to give Allen $250, and agreed to give him a contingent fee of $1,000 if a settlement could be effected with plaintiff for $6,000, and another $1,000 it a verdict could be obtained against Mr. Tucker for fraud. This Allan was also sworn as a witness, but his testimony is not yet taken. The case has occupied the attention of the Court for several days, and will be on all next week, the term of the Court having been extended until the second Monday in February for the purpose of finishing it. It has attracted considerable attention from the high standing of the plaintiff and the large interest at stake.

abstract: Policy of; to Europe; European Conference the, Proposed
snippet: Policy of; to Europe; European Conference the, Proposed
lead_paragraph: The position of the French Emperor in the new European complications is, as suits his temperament, somewhat enigmatical and mysterious. His diplomatic and administrative career for the last year, it will be remembered, has not been especially brilliant. The Mexican War, though it has maintained the honor of the French arms, is evidently not considered either a gain or a success in France. The French are indifferent to such distant conquests, and they dread the possible complications and expense of life and means which they may entail. On the question much nearer to their heart, the Polish, they have beheld their Emperor boldly snubbed by the Russian diplomats and the traditional position of France, as the defender of Poland, ingloriously abandoned. Still another effort to become the arbiter of Europe, by invoking a European Congress, has been quietly brought to nought by the opposition of England, and French diplomacy is again defeated. Such defeats as these are dangerous to any French ruler, and above all to one who rests, as does NAPOLEON, on the prestige of success. Still more, the Budget is presenting alarming features, and a constitutional opposition are arising who thus far confine themselves to such safe and definite subjects as the figures of the tax and the deficit, but who may become dangerous to an absolute Emperor in the future.
headline: {'main': 'The Policy of France to Europe.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Policy of France to Europe.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We are still having snug winter weather, although it has much moderated from the severecold. The city is now in "winter quarters," but there is much activity in all departments, while the social machine is in full operation, such as balls, lectures, parties, concerts, theatres, ,  We are to have Prof. AGASSIZ, who is to deliver a course of three lectures next week before the Young Men's Association.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: ROBBERY. The store of Mr. JOHN GERGEN, corner of South-first and First-streets, Brooklyn, E.D., was entered on Wednesday night and robbed of a quantity of hams and pork. The robbers were discovered yesterday morning, about 2 o'clock, by Sergeant DOUGHTY, of the forty-fifth Precient Police, and one of them, named GEO. MULRONY was secured with two large bags of the stolen articles. Justice COLOHAN sent him to the Grand Jury. The other thief escaped.
lead_paragraph: ROBBERY. -- The store of Mr. JOHN GERGEN, corner of South-first and First-streets, Brooklyn, E.D., was entered on Wednesday night and robbed of a quantity of hams and pork. After some cross-examination by Mr. NELSON TAYLOR, the counsel for the defence, the Court adjourned to Wednesday next, at 10 A.M.

abstract: The Situation in
snippet: The Situation in
lead_paragraph: -- The news from Knoxville is eight days later than that on which we based our speculations of yesterday coming up to the 28th inst. The military plans of the rebels develop themselves slowly, and thus far the engagements that have taken place have been confined to the cavalry of the two armies. Gen. FOSTER reports an encounter between our forces and the enemy's cavalry on the 27th, near Sevierville, which resulted in a complete victory to the Union side. The locality of the fight indicates that LONGSTREET is still making for Knoxville, though his approach has not been as rapid as might have been expected. Both the cavalry fights that have thus far marked the approach of LONGSTREET have been decidedly to the disadvantage of the rebels, and justify what we have already known of the superiority of our Western troopers to the rebel cavalry. We fear, however, that the fate of East Tennessee will be decided, not by cavalry fights, but by heavy battalions of infantry. The best hope we can safely indulge is that the approach of LONGSTREET will be obstructed with as much skill and energy as seems to have thus far characterized the conduct of Gen. FOSTER; and if so, there is good reason to believe that the reinforcements which have already been forwarded to Knoxville will have reached their destination. It is encouraging that the Government seems to be fully alive to the critical character of the situation in that region, and is taking active measures to add all the force that may be needed to make it secure beyond a doubt.

abstract: England and the Taeping War
snippet: England and the Taeping War
lead_paragraph: The views of England in relation to China seem to have undergone a very important modification. She no longer aims at merely protecting the lives of her citizens and their commercial interests. She no longer confines herself to exacting the assent of the Pekin Government to the opium traffic, or is satisfied with punishing it for violation of treaties. Her object now is evidently to get that government completely under her control -- to possess herself, as it were, of the person of the Chinese Emperor, as PIZARRO did of the Peruvian Inca, in order that when the proper time comes for throwing off the mask and setting about the conquest of the country, she may be able to turn the influence of the Brother of the Sun and Moon against all recusants and rivals.
headline: {'main': 'England and China The Tae-ping War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'England and China The Tae-ping War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: GREENE C. BRONSON, formerly Chief Judge of this Court, departed this life on the third day of September, 1863, at Saratoga Springs. His public career is closely interwoven with the judicial history of the State. Among the official positions filled by him, those of Attorney General, from 1829 to 1835, of Justice of the Supreme Court, from 1836 to 1847, and of Judge of the Court of Appeals, from 1847 to April, 1851, are prominent.

abstract: case of peculiar hardship, and interesting to all literary men, was yesterday called for trial before Judge QUINN, of the First Judicial District, but adjourned at the request of the defendant to 9th of February.
lead_paragraph: -- A case of peculiar hardship, and interesting to all literary men, was yesterday called for trial before Judge QUINN, of the First Judicial District, but adjourned at the request of the defendant to 9th of February. The defendant, BUTLER, proprietor of one of the "sensation" places of amusement advertised in the morning papers of Oct. 28 and Nov. 1, 1863, a reward of $250 for the best prize drama handed in to him before the 6th November; the play to be original, and in one or two acts. Plaintiff composed a drama called "Fitzboodle's Voyage," which was accepted, and played by the defendant as the prize play. It was announced as such, and performed to crowded houses; but when the author modestly suggested payment, it was at first derided, and then refused, except as to a small sum paid on account, which the defendant pleads was in-ended to be in full. It is just such subterfuges as this that literary men have to contend against, but the laws are, happily, quite sufficient to protect them. In the court-room were many well-known members of the literati.

abstract: FATAL AFFRAY IN A DRINKING SALOON ONE MAN KILLED AND ANOTHER MAN SEVERELY IN INJURED.  A severe fight occurred on Friday night in a liquorstore in Water-street, which was subsequently adjourned to the street, and resulted in the death of a man named ALBERT COLEMAN.
lead_paragraph: FATAL AFFRAY IN A DRINKING SALOON ONE MAN KILLED AND ANOTHER MAN SEVERELY IN INJURED. A severe fight occurred on Friday night in a liquorstore in Water-street, which was subsequently adjourned to the street, and resulted in the death of a man named ALBERT COLEMAN. It appears that deceased was with some friends drinking in some of the saloons in Water-street, and that a man named DOYLE, an acquaintance of his, was also drinking in CHRISTY's saloon. While thus engaged, four men, named MCCLUSKEY, MEYERS, CHRISTHOFFER and one unknown came in, one of them assaulting DOYLE by striking him a powerful blow on the head. He ran into the street, followed by the assailant. In about ten minutes ALBERT COLEMAN came running back into the saloon, covered with blood, and exclaiming I am killed. An officer was called and arrested CHARLES MEYERS, but the others escaped. The wounded man was taken to the New-York Hospital, where he died. Coroner NAUMAN held an inquest upon the body, and the evidence shows that the parties had an encounter in the street, which resulted as above stated. The jury rendered a verdict that "deceased came to his death by fracture of the skull by a blow inflicted by JOHN MCCLUSKEY, CHARLES MEYERS, or one of two others whose names are unknown to them. They further believe GEORGE CHRISTHOFFER to be an accessory after the fact." MEYERS and CHRISTHOFFER, being the only ones in custody, were locked up. MEYERS says he is a boatman, 29 years of age, a native of Ireland and lives at No. 344 Water-street. He claims to be entirely innocent; says he was not present when deceased was clubbed, and that he never saw him until he saw him dead at the hospital. Deceased was a boatman 22 years of age, and a native of Canajoharie, Montgomery County, New-York.

abstract: Foster, Stephen C., Composer
snippet: Foster, Stephen C., Composer
lead_paragraph: STEPHEN C. FOSTER, the composer, died in this City on the 13th inst., and his funeral took place at Pittsburgh on Thursday, Jan. 21. He was born on the 4th of July, 1826. His father, W.B. FOSTER, Sen., was a native of Virginia, and settled in Pittsburgh in the year 1796. STEPHEN, at a very early age, manifested musical talents of an unusual order. At the age of seven years a flageolet was placed in his hands, and within a wonderfully short time he had, unaided, mastered its stops and sounds, so as to play with effect several familiar airs of the day. He never, however, aspired to greatness as a performer, either vocal or instrumental, though the taste and sweetness with which he brought forth the most touching tones of the piano and flute could fix his audience in wrapt attention.

abstract: -- Gen. GANTT, of Arkansas, late of the rebel army, is to deliver an address at the Cooper Institute on Monday evening for the benefit of the destitute refugees from the rebel despotism of the Southern States. There is a much larger number of this class of persons at the North, and their condition is much more painful, than is generally known. Most of them have lost all the property they ever possessed, and have been driven from their homes in a state of absolute destitution. The object of the meeting, which is to aid in relieving these persons, is one which ought to commend it to general sympathy; and the reputation and services of Gen. GANTT will doubtless assure a full audience.

abstract: Capt. BOGGS, in to-day's TIMES, says that I did not answer his letter correcting my statement made in a note to the text of my speech at Washington, in which I attributed his "shore duty" to the fact that he had offended the Navy Department by expressing his dissatisfaction with the Sacramento, and he accuses me of discourtesy for that omission. I regret exceedingly that any such conflict of opinion should exist between Capt. BOGGS and myself as to the proper course for a "gentleman" to pursue under the circumstances of this case; but after reading his publication I still think I was right in not answering his note. And my reason was, and is, that it was couched in such peremptory language as o deprive me of the privilege of answering it at all, which I certainly should have been happy to do if I could have done it with any degree of self-respect. I am sorry to differ with Capt. BOGGS (whose gallant services have justly entitled him to the admiration of the country) on a point of etiquette; but I think that the tone of command which is very proper on the quarter-deck was hardly appropriate to this occasion. I expressed this opinion to Capt. BOGGS' friend, (who was my author for all I said in print,) a gentleman of high character here, and I hoped that Capt. BOGGS would have acted on the suggestion and withdrawn his note, so that I might have made the explanations which would have entirely justified me in all I had said; but he prefers to appeal to a newspaper controversy, which I regtet we cannot avoid.

abstract: ATTEMPT TO PERSONATE A HUSBAND, AND ASSAULT AND BATTERY. A man named HENRY F. MAAKENS, residing at Union Hill, was arrested by Capt. MONK, of the Hoboken Police, yesterday, and taken before Judge Pope on a charge of violently assaulting and beating Mrs. MARGARET MOLL. It appears from the affidavit of Mrs. MOLL, that late on the night of the 27th inst, she was awakened by a violent ...
lead_paragraph: ATTEMPT TO PERSONATE A HUSBAND, AND ASSAULT AND BATTERY. -- A man named HENRY F. MAAKENS, residing at Union Hill, was arrested by Capt. MONK, of the Hoboken Police, yesterday, and taken before Judge Pope on a charge of violently assaulting and beating Mrs. MARGARET MOLL. It appears from the affidavit of Mrs. MOLL, that late on the night of the 27th inst, she was awakened by a violent kicking and knocking on the door of the house opposite, occupied by HENRY SOMERS, and also by the wife of said SOMERS, screaming and calling for help. Mrs. MOLL opened the window and looking across the street recognized MAAKENS, and asked him what he was doing. Accused used abusive language in reply and told Mrs. SOMERS that he was her husband, and demanded that she should let him in. Mrs. MOLL dressed herself and went down to the front door, when MAAKENS crossed over, and seizing hold of her hair, pulled several tufts out, and beat and kicked her in a violent manner until her husband came to her assistance. It appears that that night MAAKERS and SOMERS attended a German ball in the neighborhood, and the former took advantage of the husband's absence to gain admittance to the house.

abstract: The Savannah Republican, in a late number, says that the telegraph has brought late intelligence of the shooting down in cold blood of a number of Confederate troops by the Union soldiers in Tennessee, for no other reason than that the poor fellows (!) had captured a clothing wagon, and were covering their nakedness with its contents. If such outrages be allowed, then we might as well have no government at all, for it will have failed to protect its own citizens who are fighting its battles. As many men as fell under the inhuman order should be forthwith taken from the Richmond prisons, and without a word of threat or boast made to pay the penalty and atone for the inhuman act. Will it be done?

abstract: THE CONDITION OF THE STREETS. The recent contracts for cleaning the streets of the Western District of Brooklyn were awarded to three or four men. The work in some of the wards is progressing during this fine weather; but in others the contractor appears to do little or nothing. Complaints in relation to the condition of the Tenth and Twelfth Wards have already been made to the Mayor, and special officers have been ...
lead_paragraph: THE CONDITION OF THE STREETS. The recent contracts for cleaning the streets of the Western District of Brooklyn were awarded to three or four men. The work in some of the wards is progressing during this fine weather; but in others the contractor appears to do little or nothing. Complaints in relation to the condition of the Tenth and Twelfth Wards have already been made to the Mayor, and special officers have been directed to ascertain the facts, from which it appears that two or three men, with a cart, are placed in locations which have not been cleaned for a year, and where the dirt is in some cases heaped up several feet high. With such a small force it will take another year to place a single Ward in decent condition. The Mayor expresses his determination to enforce the contracts, and with that view is ascertaining the condition in which the streets are in, so that he can compel the delinquents to do their duty. One of the Aldermen has already notified His Honor that if something was not done soon for his Ward he would order the work to be done, and make the expense a charge against the contractor.

abstract: The New-Haven Journal is informed that the whole number of volunteers received at the Provost-Marshals' offices on the Connecticut quota of 5,432 on the last call, was 3,001. This is exclusive of the renlistment of veterans, and of enlistments made by the recruiting officers of regiments in the field.
lead_paragraph: The New-Haven Journal is informed that the whole number of volunteers received at the Provost-Marshals' offices on the Connecticut quota of 5,432 on the last call, was 3,001. This is exclusive of the renlistment of veterans, and of enlistments made by the recruiting officers of regiments in the field. In the five regiments now home on furlough there are about 1,400 reenlisted veterans, and the recruiting agencies for regiments in the field have sent to Fort Trumbull about 1,000 men. This makes 5,400 men enlisted on the last call. A young Englishman, with a large scar on his check, was accepted and sworn in as a recruit at New-Haven, the other day, who was a soldier in the Crimea, and was one of the famous six hundred, immortalized by TENNYSON, that made the charge at Balaklava.

abstract: The news from East Tennessee this morning is later by several days, and puts a more encouraging face on affairs there. Gen. FOSTER telegraphs from Knoxville on the 28th, that on the 27th, our cavalry, under Gen. STURGES, achieved ...
lead_paragraph: The news from East Tennessee this morning is later by several days, and puts a more encouraging face on affairs there. Gen. FOSTER telegraphs from Knoxville on the 28th, that on the 27th, our cavalry, under Gen. STURGES, achieved a decided victory over the rebel cavalry at a point ten miles east of Sevvierille, which is about twenty miles east of Knoxville. Our cavalry made a brilliant charge, driving the enemy from the field, with a loss of over 100 prisoners and two steel cannon, beside many killed and wounded. Gen. STURGES hoped to be able to make the rout complete.

abstract: England, alarmed at the martial attitude of Germany, and at the peril of Denmark, is  anxious that a conference of the Powers which signed the Treaty of London should be held, in order that an effort may be made to bring the Schleswig-Holstein disputants to terms, and to avert from Europe the evils of a general war.
lead_paragraph: England, alarmed at the martial attitude of Germany, and at the peril of Denmark, is anxious that a conference of the Powers which signed the Treaty of London should be held, in order that an effort may be made to bring the Schleswig-Holstein disputants to terms, and to avert from Europe the evils of a general war. France, on the contrary, takes this Dano-German squabble coolly, and mindful of Earl RUSSELL's recent contumacy, evidently enjoys the alarm of England. NAPOLEON does not, indeed, absolutely refuse his assent to the conference in question, but he asks the British Government to explain the nature of the propositions to be discussed there, and has addressed a circular to the German States, in which he declares that if a conference be held, "it must assume as its starting point the state of things now existing in Holstein, and must not be in opposition to the Federal Diet." Hence it is plain that, though the French Emperor does not decline being a party to the project, he yet has no intention of supporting the views of England, or essaying to maintain intact the stipulations of the London Treaty. He means, beyond doubt, to espouse the cause of Germany, and to aim at harmonizing "the duties of sovereigns bound by international conventions with the legitimate aspirations of the peoples. His Majesty cares not a cent for the pretensions of the House of Schleswig-Holstein-Louderburg-Glucksburg, or the claims of King CHRISTIAN, and will propose that the problem should be solved, and peace secured by an appeal to the ballot-box. England, we know, has an inveterate objection to this mode of adjudication, and yet what more rational, humane or equitable agency could be employed? Let the people of the Duchies, who certainly have the deepest interest in the matter, decide for themselves. The Confederation will thus gain Holstein, and if Schleswig should, by the same instrumentality, be confirmed to Denmark, it will be proof that the majority of her population desire to remain part and parcel of the Cimbrian realm.

abstract: -- Between 1 and 2 o'clock. Thursday morning, two burglars effected an entrance to the store of Mr. PETER MICHAELS, NO. 761 Sixth-avenue, by means of a "jimmy" and false keys. They ransacked the premises for some time, selecting such goods as most suited them, and were about to take them away when their noise aroused the proprietor. The latter at once ran toward them shouting for the police. Whereupon one of the burglars drew a revolver and threatened to shoot him if he made any more noise. MICHAELS seized a musket and tried to fire upon them, but the weapon missed its aim. He was then at their mercy. They fired three shots from pistols in rapid succession, and then fled down Forty-third street. One of them, named QUINN, was afterward arrested by Officer MOONEY, and committed for examination, Fortunately Mr. MICHAELS was uninjured.

abstract: Piracy; Responsibility for Rebel Naval Depredations; China, British Designs in
snippet: Piracy; Responsibility for Rebel Naval Depredations; China, British Designs in
lead_paragraph: It has seemed to us quite remarkable, in looking, over the correspondence between Mr. ADAMS and Earl RUSSELL, extracts from which we have published, to see the arguments that have been advanced by the British Government in their efforts to maintain themselves against the steady pressure of remonstrance, based on ever new facts, and backed by ever varying argument, which Mr. ADAMS continually brought to bear upon them. The very excuses which they gave oftentimes condemned them; the very defences which they set up were really but so many weapons easily to be used against them. We find a noticeable example of this in the answer of Earl RUSSELL to a letter of Mr. ADAMS of Nov. 20, 1862, in which he called the attention of the British Government to the depredations of the Alabama, and, after arguing the case, concluded with a request for redress of the injuries sustained by our merchants from that roving buccaneer.

abstract: -- An expedition has just been organized in England for the scientific exploration of the Holy Land and Syria. It is under the management of Rev. H. TRISTRAM, a naturalist of some eminence, known as the author of Travels in Algeria and the African Zahara, published by Mr. MURRAY. Researches will be made in zoology, geology, botany, &c., and the Zoological Society have furnished the expedition with an efficient taxidermist, to prepare and preserve specimens of natural history. A photographic artist accompanies the party, who are expected to be absent about a year.

abstract: -There will be no Hamburg steamship from Hamburg and Southampton of Jan. 26, in consequence of the ice in the River Elbe. The first steamer due from those ports is the Hammonia, which will leave Southampton on the 9th of February.

abstract: CONFEDERATE BONDS. Eight Cent. bonds coupon, due 1876 to 1881. $112@$118.50. The highest price bid yesterday was for bonds falling due in 1877. A bond for $1,000, maturing in 1881, brought only  $117, while bonds of this date brought on Wednesday $119.50.

abstract: BROADWAY AMPHITHEATRE. -- Mr. LENT announces decidedly the most attractive entertainment that he has yet presented his patrons, at the Circus, to-night, having effected an engagement with the Arab Troupe, twelve in number, who will appear in their extraordinary feats of posturing and gymnastics, in conjunction with the regular company attached to the Amphitheatre. Madame TOURNAIRE continues to delight the admirers of elegant equestrianism, appearing in two acts at each entertainment, and numerous other features of the highest attractive power will be found included in the programme. The Arabs will perform every night this week, and on Wednesday and Saturday afternoons.
lead_paragraph: BROADWAY AMPHITHEATRE. -- Mr. LENT announces decidedly the most attractive entertainment that he has yet presented his patrons, at the Circus, to-night, having effected an engagement with the Arab Troupe, twelve in number, who will appear in their extraordinary feats of posturing and gymnastics, in conjunction with the regular company attached to the Amphitheatre. Madame TOURNAIRE continues to delight the admirers of elegant equestrianism, appearing in two acts at each entertainment, and numerous other features of the highest attractive power will be found included in the programme. The Arabs will perform every night this week, and on Wednesday and Saturday afternoons.

abstract: We are pained to announce that Mr. HIDELL, Secretary to Vice-President STEPHENS, yesterday,received a telegram from Augusta, announcing the sudden and serious illness of Mr. STEPHENS, at his home at Crawfordville, Ga. He was attacked on Monday morning, and sent on that day to Augusta for a physician. This attack, with the known state of his health during the Winter, has created serious apprehensions in the minds of his friends.
lead_paragraph: From the Richmond Enquirer, Jan. 19.
